In support and furtherance of its findings and determination that the historical, cultural and aesthetic heritage is essential to the promotion of the health, prosperity and general welfare of the people; and in order to stimulate revitalization of the business districts and historic neighborhoods and to protect and enhance local historical and aesthetic attractions to tourists and thereby promote and stimulate business; and in accordance with the ordinance to establish a historic preservation commission in the city; to provide for the designation of historic districts; to provide for issuance of certificates of appropriateness; to provide for an appeals procedure; to repeal conflicting ordinances; and for other purposes, the city council hereby declares it to be the purpose and intent of this article to designate a historic district in a geographically definable area containing buildings, structures, sites, objects, landscape features and works of art or a combination thereof which have special historic and aesthetic value or interest in representing one or more periods, styles or types or architecture typical of one or more eras in the history of the city, the county or the state. (Code 1990, § 9.5-60; Ord. No. 344, 5-13-2003) Sec. 50-128. - Designation of historic district. There is hereby created and designated in and for the city the Downtown Montezuma Historic Business District with boundaries as follows: Commencing at the corner of Drayton Street and Church Street, going east across Dooly Street, following the northern boundary of the Dairy Queen property (Block D, Lot 1) until it intersects with the Budget Inn Motel property (Block D, Lot 9). Follow the northern and easterly boundary of the Budget Inn Motel property to West Railroad Street. Go on a straight line east to the intersection of East Railroad Street and Seed Road (Gladys Hair Street). Continue on Seed Road (Gladys Hair Street), both sides, to Spaulding Road, both sides, to the levee. Follow the levee in a south-southwesterly direction across South Dooly Street at the Beaver Creek Bridge continuing west to the end of the levee. Follow a straight line north from end of the levee to the southwest corner of the Felton Cemetery property. Follow the boundary of the cemetery to Oglethorpe Road. Follow Oglethorpe Road, both sides, in an easterly direction to Drayton Street. Follow Drayton Street (east side only) north to where Drayton intersects with Church Street. (Code 1990, § 9.5-61; Ord. No. 344, 5-13-2003) Sec. 50-129. - List of properties in the historic district. A list on file in the office of the chief administrative officer indicates properties that are located within the historic district as created herein and the owner thereof is set forth beside the name of each property. (Code 1990, § 9.5-62; Ord. No. 344, 5-13-2003) Sec. 50-130. - Zoning map. Upon designation, the historic district shall be shown on the official zoning map of the city and kept as a public record to provide notice of such designation. This district shall be known as the downtown historic business district, DHBD-1. (Code 1990, § 9.5-63; Ord. No. 344, 5-13-2003)

div.head: Chapter 54 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Law enforcement generally, O.C.G.A. § 35-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 54-1. - Flexibility and stability of organization. The ability of the department to make organizational adjustments to meet changing needs is essential in obtaining the maximum benefit from the expenditure of assigned resources. However, to ensure stability, the basic department structure should not be changed in the absence of the demonstrated need or to satisfy temporary requirements. There must be continuing staff inspections to ensure those departments organizational needs are being meet. In addition, each commanding officer has the responsibility to maintain the organizational viability of his command through constant evaluation. Sec. 54-2. - Chain of command; accountability. Any organization, including a law enforcement agency, cannot function without an organizational structure that assigns responsibilities or functions to specific individuals or groups of individuals. Each person employed by the department is responsible for certain functions and tasks. Additionally, each employee is held accountable for those tasks for which he is responsible. The function of an employee holding supervisory responsibilities is to see that people under his control are performing the tasks assigned to them. Sec. 54-3. - Speed traps, entrapment against policy. It is contrary to the policy of the department to engage in any practices resembling speed traps or luring persons into violations of the law. Such activities are not only unfair to the public, but arouse a direct resentment against law enforcement authorities and discredits the individuals concerned and the department permitting the same. Secs. 54-4—54-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 54-25. - Composition and rank. The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such other officers and personnel as the mayor and council shall prescribe. Following the police chief in rank shall be the captain, the lieutenants, and the policemen, in order of seniority in each group. Sec. 54-26. - Oath. Prior to entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all officers of the police department shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by the city council. Sec. 54-27. - Police chief. (a) The police chief shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, and shall be the chief administrative officer of the police department, subject always to the orders and regulations of the mayor, the city council, and the city's chief administrative officer. (b) In the exercise of his duties, the police chief shall have the power to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the government of the members and employees of the department, which rules shall, however, be consistent with this Code, all other resolutions and ordinances of the city, and the laws of the state. (c) In the event of resignation, removal, death, or disability of the police chief, the officer next in rank shall perform the duties of the chief until removal of such disability or until a successor has been duly appointed. Sec. 54-28. - Duties of police chief. The police chief shall have the following duties: (1) To attend upon request meetings of the city council and trials before the municipal court; (2) To see to the proper service of all summonses, subpoenas, citations, executions, attachments, and rules of the city council and of the municipal court; (3) To appoint, upon approval by the city council, the clerk of the municipal court; (4) To see to the collection of all fines and costs imposed by the municipal court; (5) To see that the ordinances, rules, and regulations of the city and all statutes applicable therein are faithfully enforced; (6) To preserve the public peace, prevent infractions of the law, and arrest violators thereof; (7) To protect the rights of persons and property; (8) To oversee the conduct of the officers and men of the police force, and to be held strictly responsible for such conduct and for the general good order of the department; (9) To keep adequate records of all personnel and equipment of the department including a log of all questions, activities, and investigations; (10) To submit a monthly report to the city council outlining the number and type of arrests for state offenses, the number and type of cases involving violations of municipal ordinances, and the number of arrests made and cases reported by each police officer; (11) To submit monthly to the state department of public safety the uniform crime report prescribed by state law O.C.G.A. § 35-3-36; (12) To designate when necessary certain vehicles as emergency vehicles, provided that such vehicles are registered with the police and in the records of the city; and (13) To discharge such other duties as may be required of him by the mayor, the city council, or the city's chief administrative officer. Sec. 54-29. - Qualifications of police officers. Any person employed by the city as a police officer shall have the following qualifications: (1) Be at least 18 years of age; (2) Be a citizen of the United States; (3) Have a high school diploma or its recognized equivalent; (4) Not have been convicted, by any state or by the federal government, of any crime, the punishment for which could have been imprisonment in a federal or state prison or institution; nor shall he have been convicted of sufficient misdemeanors to establish a pattern of disregard for the law; (5) Be fingerprinted and a search made of local, state, and national fingerprint files to disclose any criminal records; (6) Possess good moral character as determined by investigation procedure established by the Georgia Peace Officers Standards and Training Council; (7) Have an oral interview with the chief and an interview board to determine such things as applicant's appearance, background, ability to communicate, and must pass a written examination; (8) Be found, after examination by a licensed physician or surgeon, to be free from any physical, emotional, or mental conditions that might adversely affect his exercising the powers or duties of a police officer and must successfully pass a polygraph examination and a psychological test; (9) Complete satisfactorily the law enforcement academy within 12 months of the date of his appointment as a police officer, except that an extension may be granted by the Georgia Peace Officers Standards and Training Council on account of illness, injury, military service, or other reasons deemed sufficient by said council; and (10) Hold no other job without the permission of the police chief. Sec. 54-30. - Duties of police officers. It is the duty of the officers of the police department to acquire a full knowledge, of and to enforce all of the ordinances of the city and all statutes applicable therein, to become familiar with the rules and regulations established by the police chief concerning the discipline, good order, proper conduct, care, and management of the police department, and to respect and obey all orders of the police chief not in conflict with the law or ordinances of the city. Sec. 54-31. - Officer conduct. Every member of the police department shall conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner at all times and shall avoid the use of unnecessary force. Prohibited conduct shall include, but not be limited to the following: (1) Absence from regular hours of duty without permission; (2) Sleeping on duty; (3) Insubordination or disobedience of orders; (4) Drinking any malt or intoxicating beverage while on duty or in uniform; (5) Willful maltreatment of any person or prisoner; (6) Using profane language; (7) Giving out or releasing any information covering the affairs, business or operation of the police department without the consent of the police chief; (8) Receiving or accepting a reward from any person, firm, or corporation for any services rendered in the line of duty; (9) Accepting bribes of money, gifts, or other articles of apparent or actual value, or accepting any fee, reward, or gift of any kind from a person arrested or from any friend on his behalf while he is in custody or after his release or discharge; or (10) Active participation in any political campaign to the neglect of his official duty. Sec. 54-32. - Penalties for improper conduct. Any police officer violating the rules or regulations of the police department or of this Code, upon conviction therefor by the city council, after due notice and hearing, or upon the plea of guilty, shall be reprimanded, fined, suspended, or dismissed by the city council. Any one or more of said penalties may be imposed in the discretion of the city council. Sec. 54-33. - Weapons and uniforms. (a) Each officer and member of the police department shall be furnished with such uniforms, arms, and police equipment as provided for by the city council. Uniforms shall be kept clean and pressed and shall be worn on duty at all times, unless otherwise ordered by a superior officer. The equipment, arms and uniforms furnished by the city shall be and always remain the property of the city and shall be, when a change is ordered on retirement from office, returned to the city. The members of the department shall be liable for any loss or careless destruction of or damage to their arms and uniforms. (b) Officers may supply a personally owned weapon for their own use while on duty, but only upon express approval of the chief of police, including an inspection and approval of the weapon proposed for use. However officers using their own weapon must qualify with the said weapon and it must be recorded with the training officer. Sec. 54-34. - Authority to arrest. Police officers of the city may make arrests for violations of this Code, municipal ordinances, and state laws when such violations are committed in their presence or when they have obtained a valid arrest warrant from the judge of the municipal court or from some other proper authority. In exercising such power of arrest, all police officers shall see that all necessary warnings are given to the accused as required by law. Sec. 54-35. - Entering private dwellings. No police officer shall enter a private dwelling without a search or arrest warrant unless he is in pursuit of a fugitive who the officer has personal knowledge or probable cause to believe has committed or attempted to commit a felony. Sec. 54-36. - Disposition of stolen, abandoned, or impounded property. Disposition of all personal property seized or abandoned and in the custody of the police department shall be disposed of only in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 17-5-54. Secs. 54-37—54-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TOWING ROTATION
Sec. 54-61. - List of towing services established. The police department maintains a list of towing companies qualified pursuant to this article to provide towing services upon request of the city's police department. Any towing service meeting and complying with the provisions of this article shall be placed on the list. The rotation list shall be maintained by the Middle Flint Emergency 911 Center. Sec. 54-62. - Procedure for contacting towing companies. When the city police department requires towing services, it shall contact the first towing company on the rotation list and move that responder to the bottom of the list. Requests for towing services shall continue in the same manner, with each responder rotating in turn. If the first company on the list cannot be contacted, it shall nevertheless be rotated to the bottom of the list. Sec. 54-63. - Liaison with towing services. The city will designate a police officer as the primary liaison between the towing services and the city. The liaison officer will schedule and notify each service and the communications dispatcher of the rotation calendar. At dispatch, the city will notify the towing service of the type of call and the types and numbers of vehicles and equipment involved. Sec. 54-64. - Response time. (a) The company must be available for call on its assigned rotation based on the following schedule: (1) From 8:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. The company must be in route within ten minutes of receiving a call from the police department and on the scene within ten minutes thereafter (a total of 20 minutes from the time of notification until the company is at the scene). (2) From 8:00 p.m. until 8:00 a.m. The company must be in route within 15 minutes of receiving a call from the police department and on the scene within 15 minutes thereafter (a total of 30 minutes from the time of notification until the company is at the scene). (b) In the event the company fails to respond within the time limitations provided, the company's name will be moved to the bottom of the rotation list, and the next company on the list will be contacted. Sec. 54-65. - Responsibilities of tow truck operator. (a) The first towing company dispatched to a scene shall be the primary service and will clean all debris from the scene, if necessary. (b) The driver or operator for the service will sign an impound inventory sheet when requested by the impounding officer. (c) The service will assume all responsibility for the vehicle and contents. (d) No service, primary or back-up, will "call jump," but will respond only when properly requested by the officer at the scene. (e) The city reserves the right to call other equipment or services for special events or circumstances. Sec. 54-66. - Unavailability of towing company. If the primary service determines he is unavailable for his rotation day for any period of time, he will immediately notify the city's radio dispatcher at the 911 Center. The city's dispatcher will notify the next service on the rotation list. This service will then become primary and will respond per the above schedule. Sec. 54-67. - Impoundment. (a) After impound of a vehicle at the request of the city, the city will notify the impounding service within seven days that the vehicle is to be seized pursuant to condemnation procedures. (b) The impound service will charge the initial tow fee, per the schedule of permitted towing fees maintained by the police department. (c) The company shall charge no impound fee for the first ten days. Thereafter, the city will pay a maximum of $3.00 per day. (d) Seized vehicles held for impound will be placed in secure areas with restricted access as much as practicable. Sec. 54-68. - Inspections; business license to be displayed. All facilities on the city's rotation list will be subject to inspection at all reasonable times to ensure compliance with this article. All facilities on the city's rotation list shall maintain a current city business license that shall be displayed at the primary business location. Sec. 54-69. - Company to sign compliance statement. To be placed on the rotation list, services shall sign an acknowledgment by which a declaration is made that the company, its operators, and its employees are familiar with the provisions of this article and that the company will adhere to strict compliance while remaining on the rotation list. Sec. 54-70. - Business facility, impound lot requirements. All towing companies who participate in the city's rotation list must maintain a 24-hour telephone line and have a fulltime, staffed business facility, located in the city or within the county, with regular weekday business hours. The business facility must include an impound lot secured by a chainlink fence with a minimum height of six feet and with a locking gate. The impound lot must be adequately lighted 24 hours per day. At the discretion of the city, signs may be posted giving notice that the lot is an impound site having limited access. Sec. 54-71. - Compliance with state laws required. Each towing company participating in the city's rotation list shall comply with all applicable state law regarding equipment, licenses, insurance, light permits, and PSC permits. Sec. 54-72. - Insurance requirements. Each towing company participating in the city's rotation list shall obtain and continuously maintain in full force and effect the following insurance: (1) Commercial liability insurance in the amount of $100,000.00 on any vehicle operated from the place of business. (2) On-hook coverage in the amount of $50,000.00. (3) Cargo and contents coverage in the amount of $100.000.00. (4) Garagekeeper's legal liability in the amount of $300,000.00. This coverage must cover any and all vehicles in the custody of the towing service. Sec. 54-73. - Equipment requirements. Each company participating in the city's rotation list shall be required to maintain in good condition and repair a minimum of the following equipment: (1) One rollback vehicle. (2) On each vehicle, a broom, a shovel, absorbent compound, triangle flares, debris receptacle, fire extinguisher with current inspection tag, and a flashlight. (3) For each employee, a minimum of 500 square inches of blaze orange clothing sufficient to identify the employee as an emergency roadside worker. Sec. 54-74. - Complaints. (a) Upon receipt of any complaint against a service, the named service will be notified by the police department within three days. All complaints are to be in writing. (b) The named service will have the first opportunity of investigating the complaint. (c) The complaint and investigation, if any, will be reviewed by the police department within ten days and a determination made with regard to whether action by the city is necessary. Notice of the determination shall be provided to the towing company. Sec. 54-75. - Removal from rotation list. In the event it is determined that a service is not in compliance with this article, the city shall provide notice to the service and remove the service from rotation. Removal from rotation will be by the chief of police or his designee. If removed from rotation, the towing service may within ten days appeal the decision to the chief administrative officer. The decision of the chief administrative officer will be final. Services may be removed from the rotation list for the following reasons: (1) Excessive unresolved complaints. (2) Unsatisfactory response for service requested by the police department or the city. (3) Failure to comply with any part of this article or state laws. (4) Complaints of excessive fees. (5) Any business practice that reflects discredit upon the city or the police department as an endorsing agency. (6) Any other good and just cause. Sec. 54-76. - Maximum fee schedule. (a) Charges for service requested by the city in the furtherance of its duties to the public shall be confined within the fee parameters established from time to time by resolution of the city council, upon advice of the police chief and chief administrative officer, and available for public inspection at the city's police department. A copy of the fee schedule shall be provided to each company on the city's rotation list at the request of the company. (b) Companies on the city's rotation list may petition the police department once annually during the month of January for increase in the maximum fee schedule. After reviewing the petition, the chief of police shall consult with the city's chief administrative officer and make his recommendation to the city council regarding disposition of the petition.

div.head: Chapter 58 - MANUFACTURED AND MOBILE HOMES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; factory-built structures generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-110 et seq.
Sec. 58-1. - Penalty for violations. (a) Applicability in general. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall punished as provided in section 1-8. Any violation which continues to exist for more than ten days after the notice of the existence of such violation shall be considered to be a separate offense for which the imposition of separate and additional punishment will be authorized. (b) Applicability to park operator. In addition, any licensed operator of a mobile home park who violates any provisions of this chapter shall be subject to having his license revoked, and his mobile homes and other structures removed from the geographical limits of the city. (Code 1990, 12-1; Ord. No. 76, § 7, 11-9-1965) Sec. 58-2. - Compliance with chapter required. No person shall maintain within the geographical limits of the city any mobile home, or other similar structure used for human habitation, except as provided in this chapter. (Code 1990, 12-2; Ord. No. 76, § 1, 11-9-1965; Ord. No. 88, § 1, 8-22-1968) Sec. 58-3. - Mobile home year model restriction. (a) Homes exceeding ten years of age prohibited. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, no mobile home that is more than ten years old shall be moved into or relocated within the city. This restriction applies to individually situated homes and homes located within mobile home parks. (b) Grandfather provision. This provision shall not apply to existing, fully set-up mobile homes located within the city prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived; provided, however, that such homes must comply with all current state and city manufacturing specifications and building and zoning requirements. If any home excepted pursuant to the terms of this section is relocated, it must be moved outside the city limits and may not be again set up within the city. (c) Intent. It is the intent of this section to protect the public health and safety by phasing out all mobile homes within the city that are more than ten years of age and any homes that are not in compliance with current manufacturing standards. Sec. 58-4. - Storage of mobile homes. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit the storage of a mobile home or other similar structure for any reasonable length of time when the structure is not used for living or sleeping purposes, does not otherwise constitute an unsightly condition, does not prejudice the health and safety of other buildings located in the vicinity or persons residing in the vicinity, and complies with all city zoning and land use regulations. (Code 1990, 12-3; Ord. No. 76, § 3, 11-9-1965) Sec. 58-5. - Making mobile homes immobile. (a) Permit required. Removal of wheels or other transporting devices from any mobile home or other structure, so as to affix the structure permanently to the ground in any location is prohibited unless a permit for such location is obtained from the city on the same basis as a permit required for the construction of a new building. (b) Compliance with building and zoning regulations. Any alteration, moving, relocation or conversion shall be construed as converting the mobile home or other structure into a building in such manner as to be subject to the building codes of the city and to the requirements of its zoning and building ordinances. Occupancy for sleeping or other residential purposes of any mobile home or similar structure which has been rendered immobile by the removal of wheels or the placing of the structure on a foundation or on the ground, is prohibited unless such mobile home or other structure, and the location upon which it is situated, complies with the ordinances relating to the construction, wiring, plumbing, sewerage facilities and other regulations applicable to single-family dwellings. (Code 1990, 12-4; Ord. No. 76, §§ 1, 2, 11-9-1965) Sec. 58-6. - Mobile home parks. (a) License required. No person shall establish, maintain, or operate any mobile home park in the city without having first obtained a license therefor. (b) Application for license. Application for a license for such operation shall be made in writing to the city administrator, shall comply with the ordinances relating to license applications generally, and shall contain the name of the applicant, the location of the proposed park, and the number of mobile homes to be accommodated. Each such application shall be accompanied by a plat or sketch showing the size and location of all existing and proposed buildings and structures, including the proposed location of any mobile homes to be accommodated. (c) L icense fee. The annual fee for mobile home park licenses shall be as established by resolution of the city council and shall consist of a base fee plus a fee for each mobile home over five for which accommodations are furnished. (d) Water, sewer connections. No mobile home park shall be established in the city unless there has first been provided permanent water and sewerage connections in compliance with ordinances existing in this city. (e) Site, size, location on site and set-up requirements. Within the mobile home park, each mobile home shall be allotted a site of not less than 1,000 square feet of space, and no mobile home shall be parked closer than ten feet to another mobile home or to the boundary of the abutting property. All mobile homes placed in mobile home parks must be underskirted with materials approved by the Manufactured Homes Association and approved by state and local fire officials for use for such purposes (e.g., vinyl, aluminum and masonite). Said underskirting material must match or coordinate with exterior mobile home color scheme. Underskirting must be completed prior to hookup of all utilities. (f) Compliance with chapter and other ordinances. All mobile home parks, whether used for transient owners of mobile homes, for rental of mobile homes, or for location of mobile homes on a semi-permanent basis, shall comply with all of the provisions of this chapter relating to the location of the mobile home parks and shall otherwise comply with all of the other ordinances of the city relating to the health and safety of its citizens. (Code 1990, 12-5; Ord. No. 76, §§ 5, 6, 11-9-1965; Ord. No. 88, § 2, 8-22-1968; Ord. No. 294, 1-14-1997) Sec. 58-7. - Permitted locations of mobile homes. Location of mobile home parks must be specifically approved in advance by the city council. Any mobile home located in any area other than as approved by the city's zoning regulations shall be deemed to be in violation of this section and subject to immediate removal. Such structures shall also be removed immediately upon any change of occupancy or ownership, unless all of the provisions of this chapter and any applicable city zoning restrictions are met by the new owner or occupant. (Code 1990, 12-6; Ord. No. 88, §§ 3, 4, 8-22-1968; Ord. No. 171, 3-22-1983) Sec. 58-8. - Sale or rental of mobile homes. (a) License required. No person shall display for sale, rental, or other disposition any mobile home or other similar structure without first obtaining from this city an appropriate license to engage in such business pursuant to chapter 26. (b) Standards for issuance of license. No business license for operation of such business shall be granted by this city until the applicant shall have identified the proposed location of such business, and unless such location is demonstrated to have sufficient space for the orderly display of such structures and conduct of such business. Maintenance of junk, debris or structures failing to meet the minimum housing standards of this city will not be allowed. (Code 1990, 12-7; Ord. No. 76, § 4, 11-9-1965)

div.head: Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; crimes generally, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 62-1. - Bows and arrows. (a) Intent. The intent of this section is to protect the welfare, health and safety of the citizens of the city from the accidental and irresponsible act of discharging a bow within congested areas under unsafe conditions. (b) Prohibition. It is unlawful to discharge an arrow, wood, metal, plastic or of any type construction from a bow, compound bow, crossbow, or any other type of device, within the limits of the city unless it is done so within an enclosure that has been approved by and licensed by the city council as a firing range or is done in the act of self-defense or the protection of private property. (c) Exceptions. There is excepted from the provisions of this section all arrows that are sheathed or made of such construction as not to pierce the human skin or cause injury to any human. (Code 1990, 11-3; Ord. No. 226, §§ 1—4, 1-23-1990) Sec. 62-2. - Disorderly conduct. It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to violate any of the following provisions of this section, and the following acts shall constitute disorderly conduct: (1) A violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear of safety of his life, limb or health; (2) A violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged; (3) Causing, provoking or engaging in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another; (4) Without provocation, using to or of another person in such other person's presence, opprobrious or abusive words which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace, that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person in such other person's presence, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words"; (5) Without provocation, using obscene and vulgar or profane language in the presence of or by telephone to a person under the age of 14 years which threatens an immediate breach of the peace; (6) Assembling or congregating with one or more persons for the purpose or with the intent in gaming; (7) Frequenting any public place with intent to obtain money from other persons by illegal and fraudulent schemes, artifices or devices; (8) Assembling for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in the city or who shall aid or abet therein; (9) Accosting or forcing one's company upon any person; (10) Frequenting any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages, narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated; (11) Violent interference with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; (12) Congregating with one or more persons in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and who refuses to clear such public way when ordered by the city police or other lawful authority; (13) Any person who shall disrupt, by excessive noise or disorderly actions, the undisturbed activities of any institution of learning, house of worship or any hospital; (14) Throwing any bottle, paper, can, glass, stick, stone, missile or any other debris on public property; (15) Committing an act of public indecency tending to debauch the morals of any person; (16) Committing any act against public safety, morality and decency, or who exhibits any other conduct that is manifestly disorderly that tends to disturb other persons anywhere in the city. (Code 1990, 11-5; Ord. No. 240, § 1, 3-26-1991) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39. Sec. 62-3. - Public drunkenness. It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear in an intoxicated condition in any public place or upon any private property not his own other than by virtue of the owner or lawful occupant, which conditions made manifest by boisterousness, intoxicated condition or act, or by vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language. (Code 1990, 11-6; Ord. No. 240, § 2, 3-26-1991) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Sec. 62-4. - Loitering on business property. (a) Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: Loitering means remaining idle in one location, including walking around aimlessly, and sitting or standing in or out of a motor vehicle. (b) Loitering prohibited. No person shall loiter on private property that is customarily used by the public as an integral part of a commercial venture in such a manner as to: (1) Disturb the peace as defined by state law; (2) Obstruct the free passage of pedestrian or vehicle; (3) Obstruct or interfere with any person lawfully seeking access or the use of the commercial enterprise conducted on the property or adjacent or contiguous to said private property. (c) Notice to be given. No person shall be guilty of a violation of this section unless: (1) The property owner or tenant shall post the property with "NO LOITERING" signs or other notices of like meaning at the entrance to the property and at intervals of not less than 15 feet on such property. Property of 50 feet or less may contain only one sign; and/or the property owner has asked the city, in writing, to enforce the law upon their property. (2) The person to be charged with loitering has been asked by the owner or tenant of the property, by an employee of the owner or tenant, by security officer or law enforcement officer to leave the property and has failed to leave. (Code 1990, 11-8; Ord. No. 262, 10-12-1993) Sec. 62-5. - Resisting, obstructing, following police. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to resist any member of the police department, or any other person duly empowered with police authority, while in the discharge or apparent discharge of official duty, or in any way interfere with, obstruct or hinder such officer or other person in the discharge of official duty. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to follow any police officer while in charge of any prisoner, after such person has been commanded to desist such following, or after any crowd has been commanded to disperse. (Code 1990, 11-10; Ord. No. 273, 3-14-1995) Sec. 62-6. - Compliance with orders and directions of police. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer of the city. (Code 1990, 11-11; Ord. No. 273, 3-14-1995) Secs. 62-7—62-32. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - NOISE
Sec. 62-33. - Excessive noise and excessive vibrations. (a) Restrictions. The following acts are prohibited and are declared to be public nuisances: (1) The making, creating or permitting of any unreasonably loud or unnecessary noise in the city is prohibited. (2) The making, creating or permitting of any such noise, sound or vibration of such intensity, duration, frequency or character which would be harmful and detrimental to the health, welfare and safety of the inhabitants of the city is prohibited. (3) It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make or continue or cause to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise which disturbs the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitiveness residing in the area, which would include business areas, as well as public streets and sidewalks. (4) It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make or continue or cause to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise by or within a motor vehicle which disturbs the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitiveness in the area, which would include business areas, as well as public streets and sidewalks. Included within this restriction are loud or no mufflers on motor vehicles and sound reproduction or amplification equipment in or on motor vehicles, such as radios, tape or cassette players and megaphones, as well as any other device that transmits sound. (b) Standards. The standards which may be considered in determining whether a violation of the provisions of this section exists may include, but not be limited to, the following: (1) The level of the noise; (2) The nature of the noise and whether it is usual or unusual; (3) Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural; (4) The level and intensity of the background noise, if any; (5) The proximity of the noise to residential sleeping facilities, hospitals, churches, facilities for the care of the elderly, ill or mentally ill, as well as any other area which historically is treated by the community as a quiet area; (6) The density of the inhabitation of the area within which the noise emanates; (7) The nature and zoning of the area within which the noise emanates; (8) The time of day or night the noise occurs; (9) Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent, or constant. (c) Measurement of sound. For purposes of this section, excessive noise shall include sound from any source which registers 85 decibels or more on a sound level meter or other instrument designed to measure sound level. Noises or sounds created inside a building or dwelling shall be measured at the property line of that building or dwelling. For purposes of motor vehicles, sound or noise shall be measured ten feet from such motor vehicle. (d) Amplified sound from motor vehicles. In addition to the other restrictions and standards contained in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person operating or occupying a motor vehicle on a public street or other public property or other property used by the public to operate or amplify with sound produced by a radio, tape player, or other mechanical sound-making device or instrument from within the motor vehicle so that the sound is plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from said motor vehicle. The term "plainly audible" is defined as any loud unnecessary or unusual noise which disturbs the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitiveness residing in the area which includes the business area as well as public streets and sidewalks in the city. This prohibition is in addition to and not exclusive of the other provisions of this chapter. (e) Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any law enforcement or emergency vehicle in the performance of lawful duties or to the noise made by a horn or other warning device as required by O.G.C.A. § 40-8-70 or to any motor vehicle used for business or political purposes which in the normal course of such business uses sound-making devices. (Code 1990, 11-4; Ord. No. 221, §§ 1—3, 9-27-1989; Ord. No. 243, 5-28-1991) Secs. 62-34—62-54. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MINORS
Sec. 62-55. - Curfew. (a) Persons under 16 prohibited from streets at night; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any person under 16 years of age to be or remain upon any street or alley or other public place in the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. unless such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian or other responsible adult having custody of such minor or unless such person is in the performance of duty directed by such parents or guardian or other responsible person having custody, or unless such person is in the lawful employment, or on a lawful errand, or returning home from an approved school activity, making it necessary to be in such a place between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. (b) Permitting violation of curfew unlawful. It shall be unlawful for anyone having the legal care and custody of any person, as described above, to allow or permit such person to go or be upon any public street, alley or other public place in the city after 10:00 p.m. as restricted in the preceding section, except in case of necessity. (c) Detention of violator. Every certified member of the police force is hereby authorized to detain any such minor willfully violating the provisions of subsection (a) of this section until the parent or guardian of the child shall take him into custody; but such officer shall immediately upon taking custody of the child communicate with the parent or guardian. (d) Delinquent or mendicant children. If it shall appear that any child taken into custody for violation of subsection (a) of this section is growing up in mendicancy or vagrancy, or is incorrigible for lack of proper parental care, or has no home, proper proceedings shall be taken to have such child placed in care of a state institution as provided by statute. (Code 1990, 11-9; Ord. No. 262, 10-12-1993; Ord. No. 307, 2-10-1998) Secs. 62-56—62-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - E911 STREET ADDRESS SIGN REQUIREMENT
Sec. 62-71. - Purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of this article is to provide a uniform system of assigning addresses for all properties and buildings throughout the city in order to facilitate provision of adequate public safety and emergency response service, and to minimize difficulty in locating properties and buildings for public service agencies and the general public. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-72. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Address program administrator means the official of the city charged with the administration of this article, including his/her authorized representative, the police chief or such person as may be designated by the city council, shall serve as the address program administrator. Address program administrator assistant means the official of the city charged with assisting the address program administrator. The address program administrator assistant shall be the city clerk or such other person as designated by the city. Building means a structure having a roof supported by columns or walls for the shelter of persons for residential or business use. When separated by division walls from the ground up without openings, each such enclosure may be deemed a separate building. Buildings without divisions, as described in the article, that are used as a multifamily or multiuse facility may, at the discretion of the address program administrator, be assigned more than one address. Concurrence [means] the mayor and council shall have the right to disapprove any action of the address program administrator by a majority vote. If the mayor and council shall fail to act within two regular meetings after the action of the address program administrator, the mayor and council shall be deemed to have concurred with the action. Driveway means a private way, beginning at the property line of a lot abutting a public road, private road, easement or private right-of-way, and leading to a building, lot or physical location. Private road means any one-way or two-way road for ingress and/or egress, serving two or more properties, but not for use by the general public. Public road means any road, street, highway, thoroughfare, or other way of passage that has been irrevocably dedicated to the public or in which the public has acquired rights by prescription, without regard to whether it is open for travel. Road address means the combination of numbers and road names assigned under the terms of this article which identifies a particular building, lot or other physical location. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-73. - Administration and application. The address program administrator and program assistant, with concurrence of the mayor and council will be responsible for interpretation and administration of the article including: (1) Assigning all numbers for properties and buildings. (2) Maintaining a database of addresses of each property and building. (3) Designation of individuals unit addresses within multiple housing units in conformity with this article. (4) Recommending to the mayor and council such changes to this article or to the road name system as may be necessary to facilitate the perpetuation and efficiency of the address system. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-74. - Enforcement. Owners or occupants already constructed which do not comply with this article will be notified and requested to meet the requirements within 60 days from the date of notification. A warning notice will be issued by registered mail or certified mail after the 60 days if the requirements have not been met. The owner or occupant who does not comply with this article within 30 days after delivery of a warning notice shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished. Violation of this article may also be enforced by seeking an order to compel compliance of civil remedies against the violators. Prosecution for violation of this article shall be upon citation, as provided in O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-62 and 15-10-63, in the municipal court of the city. Any person, business, establishment, congregation, group, hunting camp or other legal entity violating any of the above ordinances may be given a summons and tried in municipal court of the City of Montezuma, Georgia. The address program administrator is authorized to issue citations for the enforcement of the provision contained within this article, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-75. - Display of road address numbers. Each location noted on the master address list for E911 shall be required to purchase an address sign as described herein. The city shall bill the residents or owner of the business the sum of $15.00 for each sign installed. The signs shall be installed on a metal post and metal sign with the display of official reflective address numbers so that they are clearly visible from the street or road on which the driveway to the property is on. No other signs will be allowed to be displayed. The following criteria shall be used to properly display the numbers. (1) Address numbers must meet the minimum size requirements indicated as follows: a. Post upon which they are mounted must bear reflective letters four inches in height. b. Residences and businesses, in the incorporated areas of the City of Montezuma, Georgia, must place post bearing a six-inch by 12-inch sign with white reflective address numbers four inches in height, and in immediate proximity to the driveway or private road that leads to such residence or business. (2) Numbers for a multiple dwelling complex or nonresidential building shall be four inches in height and shall be placed on a post. Individual units within a multiple dwelling complex shall be required to display on a unit reflective number, which is four inches in height on the front door or immediately adjacent to the door. (3) On corner lots, the house number shall face the street named in the address. (4) The address program administrator and program assistant, with the concurrence of the mayor and council, will have the right to authorize and approve alternate methods of displaying numbers which meet the intent of this article when strict adherence to these standards cannot be met or impractical. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-76. - Types of numbers. The following two types of numbers are to be used under this article: (1) A primary number is to be assigned to each street frontage of each improved property. The primary number must be posted on that property if the property is occupied by a dwelling unit; structure or active use and the owner, occupant or person in charge is notified. (2) Secondary numbers may be used when a number of units, structures and uses coexist on the same parcel of land. Examples of secondary numbers include apartment projects, mobile home parks, office parks, planned unit developments, recreational vehicle parks, recreational areas, shopping centers and other used where the use of secondary numbers would clarify the location of a unit or use for public safety purposes. To provide secondary numbers, the address program administrator shall work with the owner, manager or person in charge of the project to determine a logical numbering system. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-77. - Roads. Exempt and excluded structures: (1) The intent of this section is to exclude from this article those structures that do not present a significant danger to human life if destroyed by fire or other events. (2) The following structures shall be excluded from the provision of this article. a. Agricultural buildings not requiring a separate mailing address, such as a barn, poultry house, outbuilding or equipment storage building. b. Storage and accessory buildings for use of the occupant of another building on the same property. Buildings used as dwelling unit, offices or the nominal workstation of an employee or such building that requires a separate mailing address, shall be exempt. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-78. - New road names. (a) No new public roads in the incorporated area of the city shall be named without approval of the mayor and council. (b) No private road names shall be recognized by this article or added to the city's list of road names without the approval of the mayor and council. (c) The name of any public and/or private road shall not duplicate or be confusingly similar to an existing road name. This restriction shall not apply to extensions of existing roads. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-79. - Numbers for future structures and lots. Following the adoption of this article, all utility services regulated by the state public service commissioner or any utility cooperative service organization providing service in the incorporated area of the city shall withhold service from any building, dwelling, mobile home or other structure not exempt under this article until the owner or other requesting party has furnished the utility with a valid assigned number. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012) Sec. 62-80. - Implementation by city departments. Every department and official under the jurisdiction of the mayor and council shall withhold non-emergency service until the occupant, owner, or requesting individual has provided the department with a valid assigned number. Non-emergency service includes any service except law enforcement, fire, rescue, or emergency medical service. (Ord. No. 385, 9-11-2012)

div.head: Chapter 66 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; municipal recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.; parks, historic areas, memorials, and recreation, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 66-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Cemetery means any burial location owned and operated by the city. The following are existing city-owned cemeteries as of August 1, 1998:
Municipal park means any plot of land which the city owns or controls and on which is located playground equipment, fountains or other recreational features or devices. The following are existing parks as of August 1, 1998:
(Code 1990, 16-1; Ord. No. 309, § 1, 9-8-1998) Sec. 66-2. - Park hours. No persons or organizations shall utilize or occupy any city park, cemetery or recreational facility after 10:00 p.m. or before 6:00 a.m., unless written authorization is obtained from permitting office. The permitting office is located at city hall. (Code 1990, 16-2; Ord. No. 309, § 2.1, 9-8-1998) Sec. 66-3. - Permit to use city facilities. Upon written application for an activity permit, an individual or organization may obtain a permit to hold public functions at the municipal parks. The permit shall include the starting and ending time for each function. Permitting authority may allow a waiver of the regular park hours. (Code 1990, 16-3; Ord. No. 309, § 2.2, 9-8-1998) Sec. 66-4. - Policy to govern use of city facilities. The mayor and city council may adopt policies and procedures to govern the use of city facilities. (Code 1990, 16-4; Ord. No. 309, § 2.3, 9-8-1998) Sec. 66-5. - Park maintenance. Any applicant permitted to use the parks shall leave the facility free of litter or debris. Any user of the parks who allows litter or debris to remain after any activity shall be subject to denial of future permits and penalties as provided in section 1-8. (Code 1990, 16-5; Ord. No. 309, § 3.1, 9-8-1998)

div.head: Chapter 70 - PERSONNEL[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— General authority over officers and employees, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-34-2, 36-35-4.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 70-1. - City personnel system. The city personnel policies establish a system of employment which recognizes that the employees covered by the system should be selected and promoted according to their knowledge, skills and abilities, and that employees who perform satisfactorily should be retained in their positions as long as the positions exist and regardless of factors extraneous to their performance and conduct. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-2. - Establishment of policies. These personnel policies have been established by the governing authority of the city to provide a fair, equitable, and productive work environment for those employees covered by the system. This system and these policies have been enabled by ordinance adopted by the governing authority of the city. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-3. - Purpose. The purpose of the personnel policies is to establish a system of employment that implements and perpetuates the six recognized principles of public employment. Those principles are: (1) Recruiting, selecting and advancing employees on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge and skills, including open consideration of qualified applicants for initial appointment; (2) Providing equitable and adequate compensation; (3) Training employees, as needed, to ensure high-quality performance; (4) Retaining employees on the basis of the adequacy of their performance, correcting inadequate performance and separating employees whose inadequate performance cannot be corrected; (5) Assuring fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of personnel administration without regard to political affiliation, race, color, national origin, sex, religious creed, age or disability, and with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional rights as citizens; and (6) Assuring that employees are protected against coercion for partisan political purposes and are prohibited from using their official authority for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the results of an election or a nomination for office. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-4. - Security of employment. O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2 permits municipal governing authorities to adopt personnel systems which establish the tenure of the employees. It is the intent of these policies to give regular employees the expectation of continued employment unless dismissed for cause, and a right to a hearing if dismissed. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-350; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-5. - Coverage. These policies apply to the covered employees in all departments under the administration of the chief administrative officer. Federal equal employment law recognizes that neither elected officials nor members of their personal staff should be covered by legislation creating permanent positions. Therefore, the governing authority will determine which positions in the city are policy making, personal staff or appointments for specified terms, and exclude those positions from coverage by these policies. All other regular fulltime and regular parttime positions will be covered, and those positions will be included in the city's classification plan. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-400; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-6. - Administration. The chief administrative officer, as the chief executive officer, is responsible for administering these policies. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-500; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-7. - Policy changes. The governing authority reserves the right to amend these policies at any time, by resolution, if the change does not take away the employees' expectation of continued employment except when dismissed for cause. If amended or repealed, changes that adversely affect a property interest will apply only to those employees who are employed after the changes become effective and to those employed before the changes become effective who are voluntarily promoted or transferred to new positions after the changes become effective. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-600; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-8. - Printing and distribution. The city personnel policies and procedures will be printed and distributed to each covered employee of the city. Each department head will be responsible for reviewing the policies and procedures with each employee in that department. Each employee will be required to acknowledge by signature that he has received and reviewed a copy of the policies and procedures. That signed acknowledgement will be filed in employee's personnel file. (Code 1990, app. A, § 1-700; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-9. - Penalties. Any person who willfully violates any provision of the personnel policies will have one or more of the disciplinary actions specified herein taken against them. (Code 1990, app. A, § 18-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-10. - Amendment of personnel policies. As needed the chief administrative officer shall submit recommendations for revised or additional policies to the governing authority. A notice of the proposed changes must be posted in a conspicuous place in city hall for a period of at least 14 days prior to consideration by the governing authority. After the required 14 days have elapsed, and the amendment receives majority vote of approval by the city council, the proposed change shall have the full force and effect of law. (Code 1990, app. A, § 18-600; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-11. - Adoption of nondiscriminatory provisions. There is hereby adopted by reference as the policy of the city, in all regards pertaining thereto, the provisions of Federal Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 USC 1981 et seq. and the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 USC 12101 et seq. that especially apply to local governments. (Code 1990, app. A, § 18-700; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-12. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adverse action means an action taken against a regular employee, by the appointing authority or his designee, for cause that results in a suspension without pay, salary reduction, demotion or dismissal. Adverse effect means the result of an action or decision which deprives the employee of income or the opportunity to earn more income. Anniversary date means, for recordkeeping purposes, the date of original appointment in a new position or annual occurrence of the date of original appointment. Appeal hearing officer means the attorney retained to conduct appeal hearings. Appointing authority means the person who has, among other authorities, the authority to appoint and discharge covered employees. As per the city Charter, the mayor is the appointing authority for the city. The mayor may delegate his responsibility as appointing authority to the chief administrative officer. For this to happen, the mayor must state in writing that he wishes to exercise this right of delegation and indicate the specific length of time that the delegation will be in effect (for example, length of mayor's term of office, calendar year, fiscal year, etc.). However, the mayor will continue to be responsible for all actions of his appointee. Covered employees means all regular fulltime employees, regular parttime employees, probationary fulltime employees and probationary parttime employees in positions covered by this policy. The following positions are not covered by this policy: (1) City councilmembers and other elected positions; (2) Members of any elected or appointed boards and commissions, judges, the city attorney, and all fulltime department heads. Days means, as a method of counting, calendar days unless stated otherwise. Designee means the person to whom the appointing authority delegates certain authority for the administration of the city. Disability means, with respect to an individual, a person with a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activity, who has a record of an impairment, or who is regarded as having an impairment. Exempt employee means an employee who is exempt from coverage by the overtime provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act. The city determines those positions that are not covered by the Act. Governing authority means as defined by the city Charter, the mayor and council are the governing authority of the city. Immediate family includes the employee's spouse, children, parents, brothers and sisters. The definition is extended to any other person who resides in the employee's household and who is recognized by law as a dependent of the employee. May is conditional, and implies that there is discretion as to whether a condition exists or an act or action will take place. Nonexempt employee means an employee who is not exempted from coverage of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act. Regular employee means a covered employee who has achieved regular status by completing all employment requirements including the working test. Shall/will are unconditional and imply that a condition exists or an act or action will take place. Unlawful discrimination means employment practices which are prohibited by state and federal laws, and which include discrimination because of race, color, sex, religion, creed, national origin, age, disability and political affiliation. Working test means a period of time, usually six months, during which a new employee or an employee who has been promoted to a higher position or transferred to a different class is being tested on job capability and performance. (Code 1990, app. A, ch. 2; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 322, 12-21-2000; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004; Ord. No. 389, 3-14-2017) Secs. 70-13—70-42. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - STANDARDS OF CONDUCT
Sec. 70-43. - Purpose of standards. (a) Responsibilities of employees. Employees who work for the city are in a special category. They are not only employed by the city government; more importantly, they are paid by city taxpayers. Consequently, they have an obligation not only to their immediate supervisor, their department head, the chief administrative officer, and the mayor and council, but also to city taxpayers to ensure that they "get their money's worth." As a result, city employees live in a "glass house" and must adhere to high moral and ethical standards in work relationships and conduct. (b) General guidelines. It is virtually impossible to set out specific rules to govern each employee's conduct in all duties of his job. This is not the intent of these standards. Rather, this is an attempt to present some frequent or common situations which arise and to provide general guidelines to assist in carrying out duties in a business like manner. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-44. - Use of privileged information. (a) Prohibitions. Some city employees deal with matters of significant public interest. In this position, the employee should not use this privileged information to his own advantage or to provide friends or acquaintances with any advantages. (b) Conflict of interest. If the employee has any outside financial interests which could be affected by city plans or activities, the employee should immediately report the situation to his supervisor. Each employee is responsible for ensuring that he does not release information relating to city business except upon approval of the chief administrative officer. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-101; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-45. - Outside activities. Employees are encouraged to engage in outside activities, including civic organizations. However, unless officially authorized by the chief administrative officer, all the activities shall be done on the employee's own time. In participating in outside activities, the employee should not disclose information that is not available to the public unless disclosure of the information has been authorized. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-102; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-46. - Attitude and common courtesy. When dealing with the public in any situation, especially on city business, city employees must do so in a courteous manner. No employee shall use profane language or show any sign of ill feeling, anger or disrespect. No employee shall engage in unnecessary conversation or gossip while on duty. Employees are prohibited from releasing news pertaining to the city's business, except upon approval of the chief administrative officer and pursuant to law. Every employee shall, at all times, conduct himself in a manner that reflects credit upon his department and the government of the city. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-103; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-47. - Channel of communication. (a) Chain of command. For all matters to go before the mayor and council from any employee or department of the city, the following channel of communication shall be followed: The employee shall pass the communication or matter to be considered to his immediate supervisor; the supervisor shall pass it to the department head; the department head shall pass it to the chief administrative officer for appropriate action. If it is appropriate to pass it on to the mayor and council, the chief administrative officer shall do so. No communication shall be stopped by the supervisor or department head without the knowledge of the employee. (b) Exceptions. Exceptions to this policy shall be complaints of harassment, unlawful discrimination or other unlawful acts by a supervisor or department head; in that situation, an employee may communicate the complaint directly to the chief administrative officer. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-104; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-48. - Outside employment. (a) Service to city not to be adversely affected. No employee shall engage in any other employment, in any private business, or in the conduct of a profession during hours for which he is employed to work for the city, or outside the hours in a manner or to an extent which, in the opinion of the chief administrative officer, adversely affects his service to the city. (b) Written approval required. Any outside employment requires written approval by the mayor upon recommendation of the employee's department head. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-105; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-49. - Voting rights. No employee shall be given or refused employment, suspended, discharged or disciplined because of his vote or failure to vote in any election. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-106; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-50. - Prohibited activities. Because public employees are in positions created for the public and funded by the public, the public has the right to expect that the incumbents in the positions will not abuse the trust placed in them by the public. The employees of the city are expected to observe and honor the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city and the county. The following are some of the activities that are specifically prohibited: (1) Acceptance of gifts and gratuities. No covered employee shall accept significant gifts or gratuities from anyone who might expect to receive anything in return from the city. (2) Use of city-owned property, equipment and supplies. a. Employees are entrusted with the use of public equipment and supplies. Disciplinary actions will be taken against employees who abuse or misuse city equipment or supplies or otherwise damage city property through negligence. b. No employee shall take or use for personal purposes any city property, equipment or supplies. City property, equipment and supplies shall be used only in the manner authorized by mayor and council. Exceptions to this rule may occur in bona fide instances of emergency and can only be granted by the chief administrative officer. c. Employees who are on call or on city business may be authorized by the chief administrative officer to take city vehicles to their residences. d. License requirement. Employees driving city vehicles are required to have valid driver's licenses for the vehicles being driven as is required by state law, irrespective of whether the employee drives the vehicle on a regular, occasional or other basis, and whether or not this requirement is included or omitted in the job description of the class to which the employee was appointed. Violations, citations, fines or other actions taken by any police jurisdiction against any employee while driving a city vehicle in violation of rules shall be the responsibility of the employee and may be cause for disciplinary action. e. Seat belt requirement. 1. City employees shall use the safety belts installed by the vehicle manufacturer properly adjusted and securely fastened when operating or riding in any city vehicle so equipped. 2. Lap belts must be properly secured in those city vehicles equipped with automatic safety belt systems that require the lap portion of the belt to be manually secured. 3. Drivers of city vehicles are responsible for insuring compliance by all occupants of the city vehicle that they are operating. Approved child safety restraints shall be used for all children of age, size, weight for which the restraints are prescribed by law. 4. No person shall operate a city vehicle in which any safety belt in the driver's seating position in inoperable. No person shall be transported in a seating position in which the safety restraint is inoperable. 5. No person shall modify, remove, deactivate or otherwise tamper with the vehicle safety belts except for vehicle maintenance and repair and not without the express authorization of the department head. 6. Personnel who discover an inoperable restraint system shall immediately report the defect to the appropriate supervisor. 7. Any person under arrest and being transported in city vehicles is required to be secured in the vehicle by a safety belt in all seating positions for which safety belts are provided by the vehicle manufacturer. 8. An officer operating in an undercover capacity may be exempt only if the officer believes that the use of the safety belt will compromise their identity. 9. When arriving at an emergency call or making a vehicle traffic stop, the operator may remove the safety restraint just prior to stopping for quick exit. (3) Use of intoxicants. Employees shall not possess, be under the influence of, or consume any intoxicating drug such as alcohol during work hours. Employees shall not possess, consume, manufacture or distribute illegal controlled substances at any time, for those activities are unlawful. Failure to comply with this policy will lead to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. (4) Causing garnishments. Employee indebtedness is a personal concern of the employee, but garnishments of multiple debts create administrative difficulties that will lead to disciplinary action. (5) Sexual harassment. Unlawful sexual harassment will not be permitted in any department of the city. If anyone feels that unwelcome sexual advances or language is interfering with his productivity or comfort at the work place, or feels that any terms or conditions of employment depend on sexual favors, the employee should report to the appointing authority immediately. It should be understood that a claim of sexual harassment bypasses the normal grievance procedure, and that the claim can be expressed privately to the appointing authority. If the claimant feels that reporting to the appointing authority may adversely affect his employment, the claim may be expressed, in writing, through the chief administrative officer, to the city attorney, who shall advise the city council. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 295, 4-15-1997; Ord. No. 346, 2-10-2004; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-51. - Code of ethics. (a) Persons subject to the code of ethics. The following persons are subject to the code of ethics: (1) All employees of the city. (2) The heads of all agencies who are appointed by the city. (3) Any other employees of officials, departments, boards, bureaus, agencies, commissions, councils, authorities, corporations, entities, or instrumentalities of any kind, and others as may be designated by the city, to the extent that the designation does not conflict with state law. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Agency means any department, board, bureau, agency, commission, council, authority, corporation, entity, or instrumentality of any kind, and others to the extent that the designation does not conflict with state law. Agency head means the executive head of an agency. Charitable organization means as defined in O.C.G.A. § 45-20-51. Employee means any employee or elected official of the city and any employee of any agency as defined herein. Family member means a spouse, parent, grandparent, child, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, nephew, niece, first cousin, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepparent, stepchild, stepbrother, stepsister, half-brother, or half-sister. Gift means anything of value exceeding $100.00, including, but not limited to, food, lodging, transportation, personal services, gratuities, subscriptions, memberships, trips, loans, extensions of credit, forgiveness of debts, or advances or deposits of money. Lobbyist means as defined in O.C.G.A. § 21-5-70(6). Officer means the elected officials and the heads of all agencies or departments who are appointed. For purposes of this section, all officers are also employees as that term is defined herein. Person means an individual, partnership, committee, association, corporation, labor organization, or any other organization or group of individuals. Value means the actual retail price or cost attributable to a gift, less applicable taxes and gratuities or a reasonable estimate based upon customary charges for like good or services in the locality. A series of tickets to sporting, entertainment, or similar events shall be valued as one gift. Entrance fees, admission fees, or other tickets shall be valued at the face value of the ticket or fee, excluding any portion attributable to a charitable contribution, or provided by a charitable organization. (c) Ethics officer. (1) The city shall designate an ethics officer. The ethics officer shall take appropriate measures to ensure that the agency's employees become familiar with applicable ethics laws and policies, including the policies set forth in this section. (2) The chief administrative officer is hereby designated the ethics officer for the city. (d) Conflicts of interest. (1) An employee of the city shall make every effort to avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest. An appearance of conflict exists when a reasonable person would conclude from the circumstances that the employee's ability to protect the public interest or perform public duties is compromised by personal interests. An appearance of conflict could exist even in the absence of a true conflict of interest. (2) An employee of the city shall excuse himself from any proceeding in which the employee's impartiality might reasonably be questioned due to the employee's personal or financial relationship with a participant in the proceeding. The term "participant" includes, but is not limited to, an owner, shareholder, partner, employee, resident, or agent of a business entity involved in the proceeding. If the employee is uncertain whether the relationship justifies excuse, then the employee shall disclose the relationship to the person presiding over the proceeding. The presiding officer shall determine the extent to which, if any, the employee will be permitted to participate.
