If the affected employee is the person presiding, then the vice-chair or the other substitute presiding officer shall make the determination. (e) Gifts. (1) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no employee, nor any person on his behalf, shall accept, directly or indirectly, any gift from any person with whom the employee interacts on official business, including, without limitation, lobbyists and vendors. If a gift has been accepted, it must be either returned to the donor or transferred to a charitable organization. (2) Where appropriate for purposes of tradition, ceremony, or inter-governmental relations, or when acting as a representative of the city, an employee may accept a gift on behalf of the city. If the gift retains value after its acceptance, the employee must: a. Maintain custody of the gift no longer than reasonably necessary to arrange for the transfer of custody of the gift to the city or a charitable organization on behalf of same; b. File a report with the designated ethics officer no later than 30 days after receipt of the gift containing a description of the gift, the approximate monetary value thereof, the name and address of the person making the gift, the date the gift was made, and the disposition of the gift. (f) Honoraria. No employee may accept any honoraria whatsoever. (g) Nepotism. (1) When family members work within the same department, potential conflicts of interest can arise. In order to prevent these conflicts, the city prohibits two or more relatives to be employed within the same department. (2) No employee shall advocate for or cause the advancement, appointment, employment, promotion, or transfer of a family member to an office or position with the city. No member of a supervisor's immediate family may work in the supervisor's chain of command. (3) In the event a conflict prohibited by this subsection occurs, the appropriate city management personnel shall have the following options for resolving the conflict: a. Voluntary movement of either or both employees based on availability of positions in other departments and qualifying skills of the employee; b. Involuntary reassignment of either or both employees to an available position of equivalent status/grade; c. Resignation by one or both the employees involved; d. Dismissal of one or both employees from city service; or e. Any combination of these options. (h) Fraternization. (1) Romantic or sexual relationships between a manager/supervisor and a directly reporting employee can cause real or perceived conflicts of interest. In order to prevent these conflicts, the city prohibits such relationships or any conduct that is intended or may reasonably be expected to lead to the formation of a romantic or sexual relationship between a manager/supervisor and an employee in a directly reporting relationship. This policy applies regardless of whether or not both parties freely consent to such relationships. Should a manager desire to date or become involved with a directly reporting employee, the manager should first resign from their position with the city. (2) Should two employees within the same department but not in a directly reporting relationship desire to become involved in a romantic relationship, they should disclose the relationship to the department director who shall then make a decision regarding the effect of the relationship on work product and work flow within the department. If in the judgment of the department director, the relationship between two employees within the department creates a negative effect on departmental operations, then one of the two will be asked to transfer or resign their position with the city. (3) By its prohibition of romantic and sexual relationships, the city does not intend to inhibit the social interaction (such as lunches or dinners or attendance at entertainment events) that are or should be an important part or extension of the working environment. (i) Lobbying. (1) The use of lobbyists will not be required or preferred as a way to obtain access to employees. Employees will strongly encourage any lobbyist wishing to meet with the city official or staff regarding his client or principal to bring a principal of his client to the meeting. (2) Former employees should not use their former positions for financial or other personal gain or to influence legislation or procurement decisions. Employees shall decline to communicate on official government matters with any lobbyist who was an officer within the preceding one-year period. (3) No agency shall be permitted to contract with any person to provide lobbying services, as the term "lobbying" is defined in O.C.G.A. § 21-5-70(5), on behalf of that agency. (4) Employees who promote or oppose the passage of any legislation by the city, or any committee thereof shall coordinate all the activities with the office of the chief elected official. (j) Fair and equal access. Employees are required to afford all constituents fair and equal opportunity to express their concerns and ideas regarding city programs and policies without regard to their political affiliation, sophistication, or affluence. Recommendations and decisions made by employees in the performance of their duties shall be made without bias. (k) Employment/board service. Employees may serve for compensation on any company or nonprofit organizations so long as services to the organizations would not have the potential to create a conflict and do not impair the employee's ability to discharge his public duties fully, faithfully, and impartially. (l) Political activities. (1) Employees wishing to take part in political activities are responsible for complying with applicable federal and state law. (2) Employees are prohibited from soliciting or knowingly accepting any campaign contribution in a governmental building or office. The term "accept" means to receive a contribution by personal hand-delivery from a contributor or his agent. This does not apply when a government-owned building or any portion thereof is rented for the specific purpose of holding a campaign fundraiser. (3) Employees are permitted to express their opinions on political subjects and candidates and to take an active part in political campaigns outside of working hours, including the wearing of badges or buttons and displaying of bumper stickers and posters. However, no city employee shall publicly endorse or actively support or campaign for any candidate for any city office, or for any other candidate while on duty, wearing a city uniform or driving a city vehicle. Employees are encouraged to vote. (4) No employee shall seek or hold a compensated elected public office in the city. (m) Personal use of telephone and Internet access. (1) Personal long-distance calls shall not be charged to city telephones. Employees must use their personal long-distance credit card or other personal resource for this purpose. Employees may not use a city cellular telephone for personal calls. (2) City-provided Internet access is intended for public business. Employee use of the Internet may be recorded and monitored. No employee is permitted to use or access the Internet for pornographic, obscene, or other improper purposes. (n) Waivers. There may be unique or compelling circumstances warranting exceptions to or waivers from these policies in certain individual cases. In those instances, prior written approval of the designated ethics officer is required. (o) Sanctions. Each chief elected official shall make a copy of the code of ethics available to all employees and shall institute procedures for its enforcement consistent with all applicable state laws. Employees who violate the code of ethics are subject to disciplinary action, including termination of employment, subject to review as provided for in this Code. The agency head of each agency shall be responsible to the chief elected official for the faithful enforcement of the code of ethics, and shall report all alleged violations. (Code 1990, app. A, § 3-205; Ord. No. 346, §§ 1—14, 2-10-2004; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Secs. 70-52—70-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS
Sec. 70-76. - Use. (a) Systems enumerated; privacy; ownership. Electronic communication systems is defined as Internet, electronic mail, telephone, voice mail, facsimiles, pagers, mobile phones, 800 mhz radios, computer and computer networks, directories, and files. Employees will not have privacy rights with respect to any activity using these systems. All data, including e-mail messages composed, sent and received are the property of the city. (b) Professionalism. At all times, users have the responsibility to use computer resources in a professional, ethical, and lawful manner. Users should use the same care in drafting e-mail and other electronic documents as they would for any other written communications. Users should always strive to use good grammar and correct punctuation, and keep in mind that anything created or stored on the computer system may be reviewed by others and the quality of communications is a direct reflection upon the city. (c) Appropriate use. Personal use of the computer and electronic communications system is a privilege that may be revoked at any time. Occasional, limited, and appropriate personal use of the computer and electronic communications system is permitted if the use does not: (1) Interfere with the user's work performance; (2) Interfere with any other user's work performance; (3) Compromise the integrity of the computer and electronic communications system; (4) Violate any other provision of this policy or any other policy, guideline, or standard of the city. (d) Inappropriate use. Under no circumstances should the city's computer and electronic communications system be used for sending, transmitting, intentionally receiving, copying, or storing any communication that is fraudulent, harassing, racially offensive, sexually explicit, profane, obscene, intimidating, defamatory, or in the city's sole opinion otherwise unlawful or inappropriate. Users encountering or receiving this kind of material should immediately report the incident to their supervisor and IT (information technology) manager. Exceptions are limited to police investigations into criminal activities, which may require the use of the Internet for information and intelligence gathering. This is permissible with the prior approval of the public safety director. Other prohibited uses of the city's computer and electronic communication systems, include, but are not limited to: (1) Sending chain letters; (2) Sending copies of documents, messages, software, or other materials in violation of copyright laws; (3) Compromising the integrity of the city and its business in any way; (4) The advertisement of personal business or conducting personal business activities. Sec. 70-77. - Prohibitions regarding software. (a) Violation of copyright. Users who become aware of any misuse of software or violation of copyright law should immediately report the incident to the IT manager. (b) Downloading files from outside city sources. Users should never download files from the Internet, accept e-mail attachments from outsiders, or use disks from non-city sources without first scanning the material with city-approved virus checking software. Files obtained from sources outside the city include disks brought from home, files downloaded from the Internet, files attached to e-mail; and files provided by citizens or vendors. These files may contain dangerous computer viruses that can damage the city's computer network. If a user suspects that a virus has been introduced into the city's network, they should notify the IT manager immediately. (c) Copying, installing, altering software. Without prior written authorization from the IT manager, users may not do any of the following: (1) Copy software owned or provided by the city for use on their home computers or to other computers; (2) Provide copies of software to any independent contractors of the city or to any third person; (3) Install software on any of the city's workstations or servers; (4) Download any software from the Internet or other online service to any of the city's workstations or servers; (5) Modify, revise, transform, recast, or adapt any software; (6) Reverse-engineer, disassemble, or decompile any software; (7) Divulge passwords. Authorized users will be given a login name that allows access to the network. The user will have a personalized password, which should be obscure in nature and not divulged to others. Any user with knowledge of any password not their own shall report it to their supervisor immediately. No employee shall attempt any unauthorized access to the system. Secs. 70-78—70-95. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SEXUAL HARASSMENT
Sec. 70-96. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Harassment means as defined by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), unwelcome conduct that is based on race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, and/or age. Harassment becomes unlawful where: (1) Enduring the offensive conduct becomes a condition of continued employment; or (2) The conduct is severe or pervasive enough to create a work environment that a reasonable person would consider intimidating, hostile, or abusive. Hostile environment means and includes any lewd sexual conduct, pictures, words, or touching that interferes with a person's job performance or creates an intimidating, offensive working or public service environment, even if there are no occurrences of tangible or economic loss. Prohibited behavior means and can include, for purposes of this policy, unwelcome sexual remarks or compliments, sexual jokes, sexual innuendo or propositions, sexually suggestive gestures or facial expressions, sexual remarks about a person's clothing or body, exhibiting sexually explicit publications or materials, kissing, touching, and sexual contact. Quid pro quo literally means "this for that" and exists when submission to, or rejection of, such conduct is used as a basis for employment decisions such as raises or promotions or affects public services. Sexual harassment means, as defined by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), unwelcome sexual advances, request for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature when this conduct explicitly or implicitly affects an individual's employment, unreasonably interferes with an individual's work performance, or creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive work environment. Sec. 70-97. - Complaint procedure and investigation. (a) Reporting. If the employee feels that this policy has been violated, regardless of whether it is by a fellow worker, a supervisor, or a member of the general public, he employee should report the incident immediately to their department director and the human resources manager. If the human resources manager is involved in the behavior, the report should be made to the director of operations. Any supervisor who receives a complaint related to harassing or offensive behavior or who has reason to believe that such behavior is occurring shall report these concerns to the human resources manager or to the director of operations. All reports of harassing or offensive behavior will be investigated promptly, fairly and discreetly. Investigatory procedures may vary from case to case depending upon the circumstances. (b) Confidentiality of investigation. The investigation will be conducted as confidentially as possible. All employees have a responsibility both to cooperate fully with the investigation and to keep the matter confidential whether the employee is the accused person, the complainant or merely a potential witness. Persons who are interviewed are prohibited from discussing the matter with co-workers, friends or management. The city will keep the information it gathers as confidential as possible, consistent with state and federal laws and the needs of the investigation. Sec. 70-98. - Corrective action. If management concludes that a complaint of harassment has merit, appropriate action will be taken. Resolutions can include, but not necessarily be limited to, an apology, a transfer, direction to stop the offensive behavior, counseling or training, verbal or written warning, suspension with or without pay or termination. In the event that harassment or offensive behavior reoccurs, it should immediately be reported to the human resources manager or to the director of operations. Employees may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. Nonemployees may be reported to the appropriate law enforcement agency and/or barred from the premises. Secs. 70-99—70-120. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT
Sec. 70-121. - Work hours. The minimum work week for covered employees will be 40 hours. Because of the differences in job requirements in the different departments, the required work week will vary from job to job and department to department. (Code 1990, app. A, § 4-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-122. - Overtime. Nonexempt employees whose work period is one week will be paid at the rate of 1½ the normal rate for all hours worked over 40 hours per week. Public safety departments will establish work periods and overtime policies separately as a part of the departmental operating policies. The established work period for police officers and firefighters at the time this policy is enacted is 28 days. Exempt employees will receive their normal salary for any work period. Exempt positions are chief administrative officer, public works chief, fire chief, librarian, chiefs over water and wastewater operations, and police chief. No overtime will be worked (except in emergency cases) without prior written approval of the department head. In emergency cases, written approval must be obtained prior to the end of the pay period in which it occurs. Failure to comply with overtime policy may result in disciplinary action being taken. (Code 1990, app. A, § 4-101; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-123. - Compensatory time. Compensatory time will be offered for hours worked over the maximum number of hours permitted by the Fair Labor Standards Act. Compensatory time will be earned at the rate of 1½ the actual overtime hours worked or according to departmental policy for administering overtime. All nonexempt employees will be paid overtime unless they specifically request, in writing, to receive compensatory time off instead. Public safety employees who have accrued overtime shall receive compensatory time until maximum number of compensatory hours, as provided in this chapter, has been reached. The remainder, if any, of the employee's overtime remuneration shall be compensated by overtime pay, according to policy. (Code 1990, app. A, § 4-102; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-124. - Surrender of property. At any time an employee is separated, prior to final payment the employee shall transfer all records, assets and other items of city property to his department head, (including any uniforms, badges, flashlights, belts, belt keepers or any other city equipment that the employee may have in his possession), and certification to this effect shall be signed by the employee and the department head. Any amount due because of a shortage in the property shall be withheld from the employee's final paycheck. (Code 1990, app. A, § 4-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Secs. 70-125—70-146. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES
Sec. 70-147. - Objectives. The objectives of establishing the following employment practices are: (1) To comply with the accepted personnel principles as listed in article I of this chapter; and (2) To enhance the employment conditions in the city with the belief that fair and equitable employment practices lead to greater job satisfaction and productivity. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-148. - Types of appointments. Department heads shall examine applications and applicants for employment and recommend applicants for appointments to vacancies existing within their departments. Appointments shall be made on the basis of ability, training and experience without regard to age, race, creed, sex, color, religion, handicap status or national origin. A person employed by the city shall be given one of the following types of appointments: (1) Probationary. The initial six-month work test period during which an employee is observed for effective job performance. (2) Regular fulltime. An employee who has satisfactorily completed the six-month test period and who regularly works at least 30 hours per week. (3) Regular parttime. An employee who has satisfactorily completed the six-month work test period and who regularly works at least 20 hours per week. (4) Temporary. Temporary appointments may be made to fill positions, which are authorized and established for a specific period of time; or when the work of the jurisdiction requires the service of one or more employees on a seasonal or intermittent basis; or in case of emergency. (5) Competitive appointments. Competitive appointments are the normal practice of the city. When a vacancy occurs, a recruitment plan will be developed and implemented by the appointing authority. An applicant must be considered qualified for the job to be employed, and generally, the best qualified applicant will be employed. (6) Noncompetitive appointments. The city may promote from within whenever possible. Noncompetitive promotions shall be consistent with equal employment guidelines. This type of appointment also applies to temporary and parttime employees who are not covered by these policies. (7) Retired—parttime—limited benefits. An employee who has retired directly from city service and the city desires their continued services at a rate of not more than 30 hours per week. Employees who are given this type appointment are not eligible for any additional retirement benefits, and cease earning sick, vacation and holiday leave. Employees of this type will be paid by the hour for the number of hours worked each pay period and are not guaranteed any number of hours. Departmental need as determined by the department chief, will dictate number of hours employee will work. Group health and life insurance benefits paid by the city are available to any employee who retires directly from city service. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 320, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 327, 8-14-2001; Ord. No. 337, 9-10-2002) Sec. 70-149. - Rehired employees. Employees who voluntarily leave the city service and are subsequently rehired at a later date shall be paid at a step within the approved pay range not to exceed the maximum for that grade even if the pay rate that employee left at was above the maximum for that pay grade and shall be considered a new employee. This means that all benefits accrued during the period of employment are forfeited and the length of service will be calculated from the most recent employment date. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-203; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 337, 9-10-2002) Sec. 70-150. - Announcements. Except when employment development needs take priority, and as along as these needs do not deprive protected groups of an equal opportunity, job opening announcements will be posted in conspicuous public places or announced via appropriate public communications media. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-151. - Security clearance. In employment areas such as public safety and finance where the public has a compelling interest in the security of property and life, applicants for employment, promotion, and transfer may be asked to supply personal information that would not be needed in other employment areas. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-400; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-152. - Working test. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter as a final test of employability, the first six months of employment in positions of original appointment, promotion or transfer to a class that has different qualifications shall be a working test. During this period, the employee has no right to expect continued employment in that position and employment can be separated at any time without cause. The grievance and appeal procedures described in article XI of this chapter are available to all employees, including qualified persons with a disability, who claim that unlawful discrimination has resulted in their being adversely affected. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-500; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-153. - Job mobility. It is possible for employees to voluntarily move upward, downward, or laterally in the organization. It is also possible for the employee to be involuntarily moved in any of the three directions. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-600; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-154. - Transfer. If a position is open at an equivalent pay grade, an employee may request transfer to that position. If the knowledge, skill and abilities required for that job are not the same as for the present job, the employee will be tested and interviewed for the new position, and will be on working test for the new job if transferred. The appointing authority may transfer an employee to any position, at any pay grade, if the employee is qualified to do the work and if his salary is not changed. A temporary transfer to a higher position may be made for up to 90 days without giving a salary increase. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-601; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-155. - Promotion. It will be the policy of the city to promote from within when possible. The promotions will be consistent with fair employment practices, and candidates for promotion will be tested and interviewed for the open position. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-602; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-156. - Performance appraisal. The appointing authority will implement a performance appraisal system for the city. (1) Instrument. The appointing authority will select performance appraisal instruments for the jobs in the city. The instrument may be the same as for all jobs, or the appointing authority may select special instruments which apply to a particular class series. (2) Frequency. A performance appraisal will be performed on working test employees prior to completion of six months in the new position. For regular employees, a performance appraisal will be performed yearly in conjunction with budget preparation. More frequent appraisals may be performed, if department head feels it is necessary. (3) Interview. Each time a performance appraisal is performed for an employee, the appraising supervisor will hold a private interview with the employee to explain the rating and the reasons for the rating. (4) Signature. After the interview, the employee will sign the appraisal instrument, indicating that the appraisal and rating have been explained. The signature does not necessarily indicate that the employee agrees with the appraisal or rating. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-700; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 357, 8-14-2007) Sec. 70-157. - Separations. An employee may voluntarily resign, abandon a job, be separated in a reduction-in-force, or be dismissed for reasons as described in section 70-218. Working test employees may be separated at any time, without cause. If separated in good standing, the employee is entitled to all accrued benefits. If not separated in good standing, the employee may not receive all accrued benefits because of administrative and other expenses. (1) Voluntary resignation. An employee may voluntarily resign from employment with the city. When possible, the resignation shall be in writing, and shall be submitted at least 14 days prior to the effective date of the resignation to be considered a resignation in good standing. For purposes of compensation for accrued leave and other benefits, death will be treated as a voluntary resignation. (2) Job abandonment. Employees who are absent from work for three or more consecutive days without having received leave approval or without having called in to report the absence may be considered as having voluntarily abandoned their jobs. The separation will not be in good standing, and may affect the receipt of accrued benefits. (3) Reduction-in-force. A reduction-in-force may be necessary when a position or group of positions must be closed because of reorganization, lack of work, or lack of funds. Employees who are separated in a reduction-in-force will be treated as if they were on leave-of-absence for one year and will receive preference in rehiring should a position for which they are qualified open within that year. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-800; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-158. - Compensation. (a) Annual salary ranges. The annual salary ranges for employees are established as a guideline for the class or position in which a person is employed. In arriving at salary ranges, consideration will be given to prevailing rates for comparable work in other public employment and private business, the current cost of living, responsibilities of the position and the city's financial condition and policy, the higher end of the ranges are for consideration of the factors as performance, longevity and qualifications. Adopted pay plan is adopted as part of the annual budget each year and is kept on file in the chief administrative officer's office. (b) Pay steps. For each class of positions, a pay range is assigned. Initial employment is normally at the first pay step for that position but in exceptional circumstances based upon experience or unusual qualifications of an applicant, an employee may be hired at a higher pay step. (c) Maximum pay. When an employee attains the maximum step in the salary grade for his position, the employee shall not receive further salary increases unless: (1) The position is reclassified; (2) The employee is promoted to another position having a higher salary range; (3) A general increase or cost-of-living increase is granted to all employees; or (4) Longevity pay is approved. (d) New appointments. Generally, a new employee will be paid at the minimum of the approved salary range for the position for which the new employee is appointed. In exceptional cases a new employee may be appointed at the second or a higher pay step. (e) Promotions. When an employee is promoted to a higher position in a higher class, the employee's salary shall be increase to the minimum rate for the higher class. In the case of overlapping ranges, the promoted employee shall be increased to the step immediately above the employee's present salary. (f) Transfers. The pay range of an employee transferred to another position of the same pay range shall remain unchanged. (g) Demotions. The pay of an employee demoted to a position of lower range shall be reduced to a step within the range to which the employee was demoted. (h) Administrative salary adjustments. The salary of each employee shall be reviewed annually at budget preparation time by the department head for the purpose of determining which employees shall be recommended to receive increase in pay. Personnel records, performance and length of service will be considered in making recommendations, with major emphasis on evaluation of services rendered by the employee. Based on the employees' evaluation, the department head will make appropriate recommendations to the chief administrative officer for consideration by the mayor and council. Any salary increases approved by mayor and council will be effective with the new budget year. (Code 1990, app. A, § 5-900; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Secs. 70-159—70-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - ATTENDANCE, LEAVE, AND HOLIDAYS
Sec. 70-181. - Types of leave. The city recognizes nine types of leave that are available to employees. They are: annual leave, sick leave, military leave, court leave, leave of absence, leave without pay, administrative leave, family and medical leave and holiday leave. Sec. 70-182. - Annual leave. (a) Defined. Annual leave is leave that is earned to be used for vacations, personal business activities, funeral leave and other personal activities. Accrual of annual leave is an earned right. Taking annual leave is a privilege that must be approved by the department head or his designee. (b) Eligibility. All covered employees, both regular and working test, shall accrue annual leave from the date of employment in a covered position. Working test employees may not use any annual or sick leave during the first six months of employment. If work test period is not completed successfully, employee forfeits all leave earned. (c) Accumulation rate. For the first five years of employment, eligible employees shall accrue annual leave at the rate of three hours per pay period for a total of 78 hours per year. After five years, the accumulation rate shall be at the rate of five hours per pay period, for a total of 130 hours per year. After 18 years of employment, the accumulation rate shall be at the rate of seven hours per pay period for a total of 182 hours per year. Any employee paid on any other pay cycle or work cycle more or less than 40 hours per week shall receive pro rata annual leave converted from the above to the pay cycle. (d) Maximum accumulation. Annual leave up to 120 hours may be carried forward to the next fiscal year, except that personnel working more or less than 40 hours per week will have this amount prorated. Excess annual leave hours, at fiscal year end exceeding 120 hours, will be converted to sick leave if employee has not reached the maximum sick leave hours accrued or donated to a lesser paid employee, upon written notice by employee. Upon separation, an employee will be paid for all accumulated annual leave up to 120 hours if separated in good standing, except that personnel working more or less than 40 hours per week will have this amount prorated. (e) Donating annual leave. An employee may donate all or any part of his earned annual leave to another employee by giving written notice thereof to the city's personnel department and providing such additional information as the department may require to accomplish the transfer of the donated hours. The donation of annual leave may be made only by an employee whose pay scale is greater than that of the employee receiving the donation. [f] Request for leave. Employees must request all annual leave, in writing on approved leave request forms. The leave must be approved by the department head or designee before the leave is taken. (Ord. No. 389, 3-14-2017) Sec. 70-183. - Sick leave. Sick leave is leave accumulated to be taken for bona fide illness or injury, or other medical-related necessities such as physician appointments, medical examinations, and dental appointments. Sick leave is available for the employee's personal health care as well as for the care of members of the immediate family. (1) Eligibility. All covered employees, both regular and working test, shall accrue sick leave from the date of employment in a covered position. (2) Accumulation rate. Sick leave will be accumulated at the rate of three hours per pay period, for a total of 78 hours per year. Any employee paid on any other pay cycle or work cycle more or less than 40 hours per week shall receive pro rata sick leave converted from the above to the pay cycle. (3) Maximum accumulation. Sick leave may not be accrued in excess of 720 hours. Personnel working more or less than 40 hours per week will have this maximum amount prorated. Employees will not be paid for accumulated sick leave upon separation except if separation is due to retirement or reduction in force lay off. (4) Reporting. The employee shall report any sick leave absence prior to his scheduled work time if possible, and if not, the employee shall see that his absence is reported within one hour after the scheduled time for the employee to begin work. (5) Approval. Sick leave requires the approval of the department head or his designee. (6) Physician's certificate. A medical statement signed by a licensed physician may be required to substantiate sick leave for: 1. Absence of three or more consecutive work days; 2. To support a request for sick leave during annual leave; and 3. At any time when absence recurs frequently or habitually, provided the employee has been warned. (7) Temporary disability. When a disabled employee has exhausted all accrued sick and annual leave, the employee may be placed on leave without pay, depending on the duration of the absence and the need to fill the position. A doctor's statement will be required to determine the length of leave necessary. Maternity and other temporarily disabling conditions associated with pregnancy will be treated as any other disability. (8) Reserved. (Ord. No. 389, 3-14-2017) Sec. 70-184. - Military leave. State law requires that paid leave be granted to members of the Reserve and National Guard under certain conditions, and leave of absence is required under other conditions. The city's policy is to grant leave in compliance with the law. (1) Ordered duty. In compliance with O.C.G.A. § 38-2-279, any employee ordered to military duty shall be placed on military leave with pay for a period of time not exceeding a total of 18 days in any one calendar year and not exceeding 18 days in any one continuous period of absence. (2) Declared emergency. According to O.C.G.A. § 38-2-279, in the event the governor declares an emergency and orders any employee to state active duty as a member of the National Guard, the employee shall receive pay for a period not exceeding 30 days in any one calendar year and not exceeding 30 days in any one continuous period of active duty service. Sec. 70-185. - Court leave. An employee performing court duty as a subpoenaed witness or juror will be granted leave with pay. The employee must endorse to the city all fees received from the court. Sec. 70-186. - Leave of absence. According to O.C.G.A. § 38-2-279, any voluntary member of the Reserve or National Guard shall be entitled to absent himself and shall be deemed to have a leave of absence as an employee while in attendance at any service school conducted by the armed forces of the United States for a period up to six months during any four-year period. Leave of absence may be granted in cases of temporary disability and possibly other emergency situations. In the case of a regular leave of absence (nonmilitary), leave prevents a break in service, but no benefits such as leave or time toward retirement shall accrue during leave-of-absence. For military leave-of-absence, federal guidelines on benefits will be followed. Sec. 70-187. - Leave without pay. (a) Leave without pay is normally shortterm leave similar to annual and sick leave. Leave without pay may be requested: (1) For annual leave when the employee either does not have sufficient accumulated leave; or (2) When the employee prefers to take leave without pay to avoid taking accumulated annual or sick leave. (b) In addition to the above, an employee may be placed on leave without pay when leave is taken without prior approval or when an employee is absent without authorization. No annual or sick leave may be accrued when an employee is in a leave without pay status. The employee will be required to reimburse the city for all health insurance premiums paid on his behalf during period of leave. (This provision does not apply to leave without pay under the provisions set forth under section 70-189, pertaining to family and medical leave.) Sec. 70-188. - Administrative leave. Administrative leave is leave with pay that is ordered by the appointing authority or his designee to meet a need of the organization. An employee may be ordered to be absent from the work place, with pay, while internal investigations are being conducted, while awaiting further communications or hearings, under conditions described in section 70-281, or under any other conditions where the appointing authority considers administrative leave appropriate. Sec. 70-189. - Family and medical leave. (a) Unpaid leave allowed. Effective August 5, 1993 the city will provide employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave per year for childbirth, adoption, or the serious illness of any employee or close family member. Health care coverage at the level and under the conditions coverage would have been provided if the employee had continued in employment continuously for the duration of the leave will be maintained by the city. In addition, an employee who takes family and medical leave (FAML) will be restored to his previous position or to an equivalent position with equivalent benefits, pay and other terms and conditions of employment. (b) Eligibility. In order to be eligible for FAML, an employee: (1) Must have been employed by the city for at least 12 months. (2) Have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period prior to commencement of the leave. (3) Be requesting leave for: a. The birth of a child or the placement of a child for adoption or foster care (the leave may only be taken within 12 months of that birth or placement); b. To provide care for a spouse, a child, a dependent son or daughter over the age of 18, or a parent who has a serious health condition; or c. A serious health condition that renders the employee unable to perform the functions of the employee's position. (c) Advance request required. The employee must provide at least 30 days' notice of his request for FAML if the reason is for an anticipated birth, child placement or planned medical treatment. In addition, the employee must make reasonable efforts to schedule leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt the city operations. However, these requirements may be waived if a medical emergency or other unforeseen events occur that make it impossible for the employee to comply with advance notice requirements. (d) Other leave to be exhausted. The employee must first use all of his vacation and sick leave before FAML will be granted. (e) Suspension of accruals, certain benefits. No accrual of seniority, privileges or benefits (except for health insurance) are allowed for an employee who is on FAML. (f) Medical certificate to be provided. An employee returning from FAML for his own serious health condition must provide a medical certificate signed by a physician. This certificate will be limited to the particular health condition that caused the employee's need for FAML. If the certificate is not furnished, employee will not be returned to his former position. However, if feasible, employee may be transferred to an equivalent position if it does not place an undue hardship on the city. (g) Denial of reinstatement. Certain key employees may be denied reinstatement under specified conditions. The term "key employees" is defined as those salaried employees within the highest ten percent pay bracket of the city workforce. These key employees may be denied reinstatement if: (1) It is necessary to prevent substantial and grievous economic injury to city operations; (2) The city notifies the employee that it intends to deny restoration at the time the city determines that such an injury would occur; and (3) In any case where the leave has commenced and the employee elects not to return to work within a reasonable period of time after receipt of the notice. (h) Recovery of health coverage costs by city. The city may recapture the health insurance premiums it paid for maintaining coverage for the employee on leave if the employee does not return to work after the leave period expires. However, this recovery provision does not apply to: (1) A key employee who continues leave despite notice that reinstatement will be denied. (2) An employee who fails to return to work due to the continuation, recurrence, or onset of the serious health condition of either the employee of his family members, or because of other circumstances beyond the employee's control. Sec. 70-190. - Holidays. (a) Official holidays. The following are the official holidays that will be observed:
(b) Observation. (1) Working on holidays. Employees may be required to work during the above holidays. All regular fulltime, regular parttime, and probationary shift employees (police department, fire department, etc.) shall be paid for each holiday as an extra day (eight hours) on their paycheck, due to the fact that they are required to work a definite number of hours per year and hence never really have any holidays except in the case where a shift employee is required to work on a holiday, when they shall be paid at double time for all hours worked on that holiday, but not less than eight hours. (2) Occurrence on weekends. If a holiday falls on Saturday, it will generally be observed on the preceding Friday. If the holiday falls on a Sunday, it will generally by observed on the following Monday. (3) Attendance. In order to receive pay for an official holiday, the employee must either: a. Be at work on the workdays immediately preceding and succeeding the holiday; or b. Must be on approved paid leave on those days. (Code 1990, app. A, § 6-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 332, 11-13-2001; Ord. No. 338, 9-10-2002) Sec. 70-191. - Anniversary date. In calculating the accrual of annual and sick leave, accrual begins on the day of original appointment in a covered position. If an employee takes regular leave of absence (nonmilitary), the anniversary date will be moved forward by as many calendar days as the employee was on leave of absence. (Code 1990, app. A, § 6-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-192. - Authorization and conditions required to accept outside employment. Fulltime employees are expected to devote primary attention to the requirements of their city jobs. It is permissible to obtain outside employment if the employee first gains written approval from the appropriate department head and the request to obtain outside employment is approved by the chief administrative officer. The general rules which apply to outside employment are: (1) There is no conflict between the outside job and the city job in working hours. (2) The employee's job efficiency is not reduced. (3) There is no conflict of interest that could cause embarrassment to the city or to the employee. (Code 1990, app. A, § 6-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-193. - Political activity. No city employee, while remaining employed by the city, shall actively seek city elective office. An employee who qualifies for elective office at the city level, shall resign in writing from the city service effective the date of qualification. (Code 1990, app. A, § 6-400; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Secs. 70-194—70-214. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - JOB POSITIONS
Sec. 70-215. - Promotions. (a) A promotion is the filling of a vacancy by the advancement of a regular employee from a position of lower class having a salary range lower than the salary rate of the vacant position to which the employee is being promoted. (b) No employee shall be promoted unless he has completed a six-month work test period in the higher position. (c) Promotion will be contingent upon meeting the minimum qualifications of training and experience for the higher position. (d) Promotions are recommended by the department heads to the chief administrative officer for approval. (Code 1990, app. A, § 7-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-216. - Transfers. (a) A transfer is the movement of a regular or working test period employee to another comparable position. The position to which the transfer is made may be within the same category or department or in a different category or department, provided the salary ranges are the same. (b) Interdepartmental transfers must be recommended by the department head with approval by the chief administrative officer. (c) An employee transferred in accordance with the provisions of these policies shall maintain the same status (regular or working test) as he had in the previous position. (d) In the case of a transfer to a position in a different category or department, the employee must meet the minimum qualifications of the new position. (Code 1990, app. A, § 7-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-217. - Demotion. A demotion is a reduction of a regular or working test period employee to a position of a lower category with a lower salary range. A demotion may be made as a disciplinary action or on a voluntary or involuntary basis provided the employee meets the qualifications for the position to which he is being demoted. (Code 1990, app. A, § 7-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-218. - Separations. (a) Resignations. Resignation of any employee shall be made in writing, no less than two weeks prior to the effective date, to the chief administrative officer. (b) Separation during work test period. At any time during the initial work test period of employment, an employee may be separated from his position by the chief administrative officer without the right of appeal or hearing, and without notice. (c) Dismissals. The appointing authority may dismiss any regular employee for any or any combination of the causes set forth in article X of this chapter. (d) Death. The chief administrative officer or department head shall report to the mayor and council the death of an employee and the date of the death. (e) Job abandonment. An employee who is absent from work for three consecutive days without having received leave approval or without having called in to report the absence to his supervisor will be considered as voluntarily abandoning his job. The separation will be recorded as "not in good standing" and may affect the receipt of accrued benefits. (f) Reduction in force (lay-off). (1) The mayor and council, upon recommendation of the chief administrative officer, shall lay off an employee for reasons of shortage of work funds, the abolition of a position, department or portion of a department, or other material change in duties or organization. (2) The order in which employees are to be laid off shall be determined by city needs and priorities, and the chief administrative officer shall file a written listing of employees to be laid off with the mayor and council taking the action. Laid off employees will be given preference in a recall. (Code 1990, app. A, § 7-400; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-219. - Suspension without pay. A regular employee may be suspended without pay for a disciplinary reason for a period not to exceed 15 days. (Code 1990, app. A, § 7-500; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Secs. 70-220—70-246. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - PERSONNEL RECORDS
Sec. 70-247. - Records. (a) File to be maintained for each employee. The chief administrative officer, as personnel officer, shall maintain a personnel file for each employee. An employee personnel file shall contain, at a minimum, the following: (1) Application forms, reference checks, interviewers' reports and test results; (2) Benefits administration materials (insurance choices, payroll deduction authorizations, pension plan information and leave request forms); (3) Letters of commendation; (4) Written performance evaluations; (5) Notices of suspension, disciplinary action or termination for the past three years; and (6) Attendance records, including leaves of absence. (b) Physical examination records separate. A separate file will be maintained for employee physical examination records, drug and alcohol test results, insurance claim forms and other records of employee illnesses and injuries. These records will be available only to the chief administrative officer, the employee's department head, emergency medical providers relevant to any emergency medical condition, government agencies monitoring compliance with ADA and to other only when the employee shall give his permission. (c) Right of employee to inspect and copy file. The employee shall have the right to inspect his personnel file and to copy any article in the file. (d) Exclusions from file. The personnel file shall not include records of any employee relating to the investigation of a possible criminal offense or documents which are being developed or prepared for use in civil, criminal or grievance procedures. (Code 1990, app. A, § 8-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-248. - Confidentiality of records. (a) Restricted access. All personnel files and records for city employees are confidential records. Access to the records shall be restricted to the chief administrative officer, the department head and the city employee. (b) Disclosure prohibited; exception. Any disclosure of information contained in personnel files and records to persons other than the foregoing shall require the written authorization of the employee; provided, however, that the chief administrative officer shall have the right to disclose any the information in the course of an appeal of a disciplinary action initiated by an employee. (Code 1990, app. A, § 8-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-249. - Performance evaluations. (a) Basis. The chief administrative officer shall administer a system of employee performance evaluations designed to provide a fair and equitable evaluation of the quality and quantity of work performed by each employee. (b) To be conducted annually or more frequently. The evaluations shall be prepared on forms provided by the chief administrative officer's office and shall be conducted for each employee, at least once per year, by the department head for submission with annual budget requests (usually in May of each year). Performance evaluations may be conducted on a quarterly or semiannually basis if department head so desires or when employee's performance warrants more regular assessment. (c) Before promotions. A performance evaluation shall be conducted for any employee recommended for a promotion who has not been evaluated within three months of the date of the recommendation. (d) At end of work test period. A performance evaluation shall be conducted on work test employees at three months from date of hire and prior to the expiration of the work test period. (e) Interview with employee. Each time a performance evaluation is performed, the evaluating department head shall hold a private interview with the employee to explain the evaluation and the reason for the evaluation. (f) Preparation of document. The evaluation will be drafted by the department head and discussed with the chief administrative officer before final preparation. (g) Signatures required. The evaluation shall be signed by the department head, chief administrative officer and employee and filed in the employee's personnel file. (h) Employee signature not acquiescence. The employee's signature does not necessarily indicate that the employee agrees with the evaluation, only that he has received a copy. (i) Employee copy. The employee is entitled to receive a copy of his performance evaluation. (Code 1990, app. A, § 8-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Secs. 70-250—70-276. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - DISCIPLINE
Sec. 70-277. - Progressive discipline. Progressive discipline is a process in which disciplinary action is taken in degrees of increasing severity. The city's government advocates progressive discipline when applicable. The action taken will depend on the degree and the circumstances of the violation. An employee who violates any performance or behavior code, policy, standard or reasonable expectation will be disciplined. The city recognizes six degrees of progressive actions: (1) Oral reprimand. (2) Written reprimand. (3) Suspension without pay. (4) Salary reduction. (5) Demotion. (6) Dismissal. (Code 1990, app. A, § 9-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-278. - Grounds for disciplinary action. The causes of disciplinary actions are: (1) Chronic tardiness or absenteeism. (2) Negligence in performing assigned duties. (3) Inefficiency in performing assigned duties. (4) Inability or unfitness to perform assigned duties. (5) Insubordination or uncooperative attitude, tending to lower discipline and morale (may include discussing salaries with other employees). (6) Misconduct. (7) Commission of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude. (8) Conduct reflecting discredit on the city or department. (9) Failure to report to work without justifiable cause. (10) Political activity that is prohibited by these policies or state or federal law. (11) Careless, improper or negligent use, misuse or abuse of city property or equipment. (12) Possessing or being under the influence of any intoxicating substance (drugs or alcohol) while on the job. (13) Having more than three garnishments filed against employees earnings during employee tenure with city. (14) Violations of these policies or jurisdictional or departmental rules, policies or procedures. (15) Willfully giving false statements to supervisors, officials or the public. (16) Discovery of a false statement in an application which had not been detected previously. (17) Use of profane or abusive language or discourteous treatment of the public or other employee (includes racial or ethnic comments or jokes). (18) Falsification or destruction of official records or documents or use of official position for personal benefit, profit or advantage, or for another. (19) Failure to report an occupational injury or accident during the shift on which it occurred. (20) Absence due to incarceration for a period of five working days or more. (21) Entering financial transactions with fellow employees involving or arising out of the lending or borrowing of money for profit. (22) Arrest or conviction (including a plea of nolo contendere) for a violation of any criminal drug statute of any jurisdiction (federal or state) regardless of whether the alleged violation occurred at the workplace or elsewhere. (23) Involvement in three or more wrecks or accidents involving city motor vehicles or equipment in a three-year period. With regard to this provision, the chief administrative officer may also require the employee to pay all or a portion of the costs incurred by the city to repair the vehicle or equipment. (Code 1990, app. A, § 9-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-279. - Types of disciplinary actions. The six disciplinary actions fall into two general categories: reprimands and adverse actions. (1) Reprimands. A reprimand is a formal means of communicating to the employee a warning that a problem exists and that it must be corrected. There are two degrees of formality, the oral reprimand and the written reprimand. a. Oral reprimand. In an oral reprimand, the department head will verbally and privately explain to the employee that he is being reprimanded and describe the problem and what must be done to correct the problem. Department head will document that oral reprimand occurred. b. Written reprimand. In the written reprimand, the employee will receive a written statement describing the problem and what must be done to correct the problem. The reprimand will also contain a statement describing the probable consequences of not correcting the problem. If the employee is at work, the written statement will be given to the employee during a private interview. (2) Adverse actions. An adverse action is an action taken against a regular employee by the appointing authority or his designee for cause, which results in a suspension without pay, salary reduction, demotion or dismissal. a. Suspension without pay. An employee may be suspended without pay for any or any combination of the above causes. The suspension without pay shall not exceed 30 days. b. Salary reduction. An employee's salary may be reduced from one pay step to a lower step for any, or any combination of the above causes. The salary reduction does not constitute a demotion in pay grade. c. Demotion. An employee may be demoted from one pay grade to a lower grade for any or any combination of the above causes, if a lower position is open and if the employee is qualified to perform the work at the lower position. A disciplinary demotion must include a decrease in salary. d. Dismissal. An employee may be dismissed for any or any combination of the above causes, when it is necessary to remove the employee from the work place immediately or permanently. (Code 1990, app. A, § 9-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-280. - Notification and response procedure. Once it has been determined that an adverse action should be taken, the following notification and response procedure will be observed: (1) Notice of proposed adverse action. The appointing authority or his designee will give the employee a written notification of the proposed adverse action 15 days prior to the effective date of the action. The notification will contain the following: a. The effective date of the action; b. The specific charges or reasons for the action; c. A statement informing the employee that he may respond to a named official, either orally or in writing, within ten days of the notice of proposed adverse action; d. A warning that failure to respond to the named official will result in a waiver of all further appeal rights; and e. To be included only in the case of dismissal: A statement informing the employee that he has a right to a name-clearing hearing before the governing body, even if he does not respond or appeal, if he feels that publication of the causes of dismissal will falsely stigmatize him. (2) Employee response to proposal. The employee may respond in person or in writing to the named official within ten days of receiving the notice of proposed adverse action. (3) Notice of final action. The appointing authority or designee, after considering the employee's response, if any, will give the employee a written notification of the decision on the action to be taken within two days of the effective date of the action. The notification will contain a statement informing the employee of his right to appeal the action. (4) Postponement of deadlines. If the employee responds to the named official, the official may postpone the deadline for the final notice by a specific number of days to conduct further investigation, with written consent from the employee. If the deadline for the final notice is postponed, the effective date of the final action will be postponed by as many days. (Code 1990, app. A, § 9-400; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-281. - Emergency action. The appointing authority or the designee may take immediate action against an employee under emergency situations. The immediate action will be to suspend the employee with pay, under section 70-188, administrative leave, until an investigation can be conducted. If the employee is unable to communicate or respond, the employee will be placed on leave without pay until it is determined that the employee cannot return to work or until the employee can respond. Examples of emergency situations are: When crimes of moral turpitude are committed; when an employee may be injurious to himself; fellow workers or the general public; when an employee may damage public property; or when an employee is found to be under the influence of drugs or alcohol. (Code 1990, app. A, § 9-500; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Secs. 70-282—70-310. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - GRIEVANCES
Sec. 70-311. - Communication of grievance. The grievance procedure is a communications process for hearing grievable claims of employees. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-312. - Purpose of grievance procedure. The purpose of the employee grievance procedure is to provide an orderly process for hearing the grievable claims of permanent employees and claims of unlawful discrimination by working test employees. The object of the process is to reach a fair and equitable decision in a timely manner. The employee and manager should make an effort to resolve any grievance informally before initiating a formal procedure. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-313. - Basis for grievance. A grievance is a claim by a regular employee alleging: (1) That his employment has been adversely affected by unfair treatment; (2) Unsafe or unhealthy working conditions; (3) Erroneous or capricious application of city policies and procedures; (4) Unlawful discrimination; or (5) A claim by a working test employee alleging unlawful discrimination. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-201; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-314. - Filing written grievance. An employee may file a written grievance with his immediate supervisor within 15 days after the occurrence of the event being grieved, or within 15 days after becoming aware of the event. The grievance statement must be submitted to the supervisor in writing, and it must state the specific claim and the specific relief desired. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-202; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-315. - Levels of review. The employee grievance procedure must provide for a minimum of two steps, or levels of review, for covered employees below the position of department head. Normally, the department head will hear the grievance in the first step and the appointing authority will hear the grievance in the second step. For department heads and other employees reporting directly to the appointing authority, the sole grievance hearing will be conducted by the appointing authority. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-203; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-316. - Notification and scheduling hearing. If the claim is grievable, the first hearing will be held within 20 days after the grievance is filed. The first hearing officer must notify the grievant of his decision in writing within 15 days of the hearing. If the grievant wishes to have a second hearing, he will notify the department head within 15 days after receiving the initial decision. The second hearing officer will notify the grievant of his decision within 15 days of the hearing. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-204; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-317. - Hearing procedure. The grievance hearing is intended to create a formal means for the grievant to communicate his complaint in an informal setting. Therefore, the hearing officer will not be argumentative nor present management's opinions at the hearing. The hearing officer will listen to the grievant's presentation and question the grievant to obtain pertinent facts about the claim and the situation relevant to the claim. The employee will represent himself, but may bring witnesses to the hearing to testify. Both the grievant and the hearing officer may question the witnesses. An employee with a disability may be accompanied by an interpreter when that is necessary. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-205; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-318. - Review and reporting decision. After the hearing, the hearing officer will review the claim, evidence, and requested relief, and will report his decision in writing to the grievant according to the schedule in section 70-316. The decision of the hearing officer will be the final decision in each step of the grievance process. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-206; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-319. - Nongrievable areas. The following areas are not grievable: (1) Issues which are pending or have been concluded by other administrative or judicial procedures; (2) Work assignments which do not result in a demotion or salary reduction; (3) Budget allocations and expectations, and organizational structure, including the persons or number of persons assigned to particular jobs or units; (4) The content or rating of a performance appraisal except when the employee can show that he has been adversely affected by the appraisal; (5) The selection of an individual by the appointing authority to fill a position through appointment, promotion or transfer except when the employee can show that he has been adversely affected because of unlawful discrimination; (6) Disciplinary actions other than reprimands; (7) Any matter which is not within the jurisdiction or control of the appointing authority; (8) Internal security practices established by the appointing authority or governing authority; and (9) Decisions, policies, practices, resolutions or ordinances made or passed by the governing authority or the appointing authority which are not job-related or work-related and which do not contradict these policies. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-300; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-320. - Posting procedures. The city will post a copy of the general grievance procedure. If individual departments have different grievance procedures, each department will post its particular grievance procedure for its employees. (Code 1990, app. A, § 10-301; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Secs. 70-321—70-343. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - APPEAL
Sec. 70-344. - Formal review of decision, action, condition. An appeal before an appeal hearing officer is a formal review of a decision, action or condition which exists, which adversely affects the claimant, and which is a violation of these policies, unlawful or unjust and which is listed in section 70-278. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-345. - Purpose of appeal process. The purpose of the appeal is to ensure that due process is available to permanent employees with property interests in their jobs, and to both permanent employees and working test employees who claim they have been adversely affected by unlawful discrimination. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-101; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-346. - Basis for appeal. An appeal before an appeal hearing officer may be filed as a result of: (1) An adverse action; (2) Unlawful or unjust practices that adversely affect a permanent employee; or (3) Unlawful discrimination. All reasons except subsection (1) of this section must be grieved before they can be appealed. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-102; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-347. - Filing written appeal. An appellant must file a written appeal with the appointing authority within 15 days of learning of the event or decision. The appeal shall contain a statement describing what is being appealed. The appeal hearing officer will determine if the case is appealable, with merit, and properly filed. If appealable, the appeal hearing officer will notify the appellant of the date, time and place of the hearing. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-103; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-348. - Hearing procedure. The appeal hearing officer will conduct the appeal hearing. The hearing process is intended to be less formal than a court hearing, but orderly. To ensure orderliness, the hearing procedure of a civil case in the state superior courts will be used. The appeal hearing officer will compile evidence, prepare findings of facts, conclusions of law, and issue a recommendation to the appointing authority. The hearing will be recorded. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-104; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-349. - Representation at hearing. Both the city and the appellant may represent themselves at the appeal hearing, or either may choose to be represented by an attorney. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-105; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-350. - Decision. The appeal hearing officer shall submit the recommendation to the appointing authority within 15 days after completion of the hearing, and the appointing authority will notify the appellant of the final action to be taken within seven days after receiving the appeal hearing officer's recommendation. The decision of the appointing authority will be the final decision of the city. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-106; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-351. - Further appeal. If the appellant feels that error has occurred in the above appeal procedure, the appellant may seek redress by writ of certiorari to the superior court. (Code 1990, app. A, § 11-107; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Secs. 70-352—70-375. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIII. - POSITION PLAN
Sec. 70-376. - Adoption of plan. The mayor and council have adopted a position plan for employees of the city. (Code 1990, app. A, § 12-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-377. - Purpose. The position plan was developed so that those positions which are substantially similar with respect to difficulty, level of responsibility, degree of supervision required and exercised, and training and experience required for proper performance, shall be allocated to the same grade. (Code 1990, app. A, § 12-101; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-378. - Job descriptions. (a) Contents thereof. Job descriptions are descriptive and explanatory and are not restrictive. They are designed to indicate the kinds of positions which should be allocated to the various grades and determined by their duties or responsibilities at the time they are established. They include minimum qualifications (statements of the minimum background that has been determined to be required as evidence of ability to perform the work properly); and desirable qualifications (the minimum background which is required as evidence of ability to perform the work properly except in cases where the appointee has demonstrated through proper examination techniques that, although his other experience does not correspond to the qualifications stated, he is, in fact, equivalent to or better than those prescribed). (b) Distribution. Each employee will be provided with a copy of his job description, and each department head and other supervisors will be provided with job descriptions for all positions under their supervision. (Code 1990, app. A, § 12-102; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-379. - Revisions. (a) Who may revise, in what manner. The chief administrative officer may, upon recommendation of the department head, revise the position or job description, add a new job description, or eliminate a job description in order to reflect new or changed conditions or work requirements. (b) Copy to employee. An employee affected by a revision in a job description and the employee's department head will be provided copies of the revised job description. (Code 1990, app. A, § 12-103; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Secs. 70-380—70-401. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIV. - PAY PLAN
Sec. 70-402. - Adoption. (a) Salary schedule. The mayor and council have adopted a pay plan for all positions under the city's personnel system. The plan provides a schedule of salary ranges for all positions, with the salary consistent with the functions outlined in the pay plan. (b) Basis. In establishing the salary ranges, consideration is given to rates of pay for comparable services in other public and private employment, living costs, other benefits received by the employees, the city's financial condition and policies, and other relevant factors. (Code 1990, app. A, § 13-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-403. - Approval. The pay plan shall be adopted each year along with the budget. (Code 1990, app. A, § 13-101; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-404. - Updating of pay plan. The chief administrative officer shall make recommended changes to the mayor and council for their approval at budget preparation time each year. (Code 1990, app. A, § 13-102; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-405. - Use. The pay plan constitutes the official compensation schedule for positions under the city's personnel system. Salary adjustments shall not be automatic but will be considered by mayor and council at budget preparation time and will be based upon department head recommendations. (Code 1990, app. A, § 13-103; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Secs. 70-406—70-423. - Reserved. ARTICLE XV. - SALARIES
Sec. 70-424. - Entrance salary. The salary of any employee entering employment shall normally be at the lowest level of the salary range for the position to which he is appointed. If it is determined by the department head that appointment at an advanced level is warranted, the approval of the chief administrative officer must be secured prior to hiring the employee. Advanced level appointments may, under certain circumstances, be justified when: (1) It is not possible to recruit qualified employees at the entry level; (2) An employee is being considered for employment who possesses qualifications in excess of the minimum required for appointment to the position, and when those advanced qualifications will serve to make him a more valuable and productive employee; and (3) The other circumstances exist that, in the opinion of the chief administrative officer, warrant the payment of a salary in excess of the minimum for the position. (Code 1990, app. A, § 14-100; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-425. - Salary adjustments. (a) Adoption of new salary scale. When a new or different scale of salaries is made applicable to a class of positions, persons employed in positions of that class falling below the minimum entry level shall be placed at a step above the minimum entry level for that position. (b) Reclassification of employee. Upon reclassification, an employee's salary will be adjusted to the pay grade assigned to the new position. (c) Demotion. An employee who is demoted shall have his salary reduced to the level of the new range which corresponds to the level he had attained in the higher class. Upon written request from a department head, the chief administrative officer may authorize an employee to retain the same salary after a demotion, provided the amount is not in excess of the maximum salary for positions in the new class. (d) Transfer. An employee who is transferred may have his salary placed at any level of the range applicable to the position to which he is appointed, provided that it is not a higher level than that at which he was paid at the time of his transfer. (e) Reappointment. An employee who is reappointed may have his salary placed at any level of the range applicable to the position to which he is reappointed, provided it is not a higher level than that at which he was paid at the time of termination. (f) Upon attaining certain education degrees or certifications. An employee's salary may be adjusted upon presenting evidence of having attained certain relevant education degrees or certifications subsequent to initial employment. (Code 1990, app. A, § 14-200; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 347, 1-13-2004) Sec. 70-426. - Salary increases. (a) Cost of living. The mayor and council may approve a percentage cost-of-living increase for each employee. The increases would be effective on that first day of the city's fiscal year and with funds available to be budgeted for the increases. (b) Performance-based increases. Any performance-based increases shall be based upon quality and quantity of work and upon other performance measures. Due consideration will be given to length of service, shall correspond with the salary range, and shall be limited to employees holding regular status in the position in which currently employed. Performance based increases must be recommended by the department head and submitted with performance appraisal justifying the increase along with department budget requests at budget preparation time each year. Any performance-based increases approved by the mayor and council will be effective with the new fiscal year. (Code 1990, app. A, § 13-400; Ord. No. 291, 9-10-1996) Sec. 70-427. - Salary reductions.
