d. Reduced impact on residential areas. Because residential and commercial uses generally exist in close proximity, signs should be designed and located so that they have little or no impact on adjacent residential neighborhoods. Figure SG-2
e. Sign placement to enhance facade. Place wall signs to establish facade rhythm, scale and proportion where facade rhythm doesn't exist. On buildings that have a monolithic or plain facade, signs can establish or continue appropriate design rhythm, scale, and proportion. Figure SG-3
f. Pedestrian-oriented signs encouraged. It is desirable and encouraged to include a pedestrian-oriented sign as one of the permitted signs for a business. Pedestrian-oriented signs are signs that are designed for and directed toward pedestrians so that they can easily and comfortably read the sign as they stand adjacent to the business. Figure SG-4
g. Painting directly on building. As an alternative to an attached sign, lettering may be painted directly on the building facade. However, signs should not be painted directly over ornamental and architectural features or over brick and stone surfaces of buildings. (2) Color. a. Select colors carefully. Color is one of the most important aspects of visual communication. It can be used to catch the eye or to communicate ideas or feelings. Colors should be selected to contribute to legibility and design integrity. Even the most carefully thought-out sign may be unattractive and a poor communicator because of poor color selection. Too many colors used thoughtlessly can confuse and negate the message of a sign. b. Use contrasting colors. Contrast is an important influence on the legibility of signs. A substantial contrast should be provided between the color and material of the background and the letters or symbols to make the sign easier to read in both day and night. Light letters on a dark background or dark letters on a light background are most legible. Figure SG-5
c. Avoid using too many colors. Colors or color combinations that interfere with legibility of the sign copy or that interfere with viewer identification of other signs should be avoided. Small accents of several colors may make a sign unique and attractive, but the competition of large areas of many different colors often decreases readability. d. Use complementary colors. Sign colors should complement the colors used on the structures and the project as a whole. (3) Materials. a. Sign materials. The following sign materials are recommended: 1. Wood (carved, sandblasted, etched, and properly sealed, primed and painted, or stained). 2. Metal (formed, etched, cast, engraved, and properly primed and painted or factory-coated to protect against corrosion). 3. High density pre-formed foam or similar material. New materials may be very appropriate if properly designed in a manner consistent with these guidelines, and painted or otherwise finished to complement the architecture. 4. Custom neon tubing, in the form of graphics or lettering, may be incorporated into several allowed sign types. b. Compatibility of materials. Sign materials should be compatible with the design of the face of the facade where they are placed. The selected materials should contribute to the legibility of the sign. For example, glossy finishes are often difficult to read because of glare and reflections. c. Appropriate materials. Paper and cloth signs are not suitable for exterior use (except on awnings) because they deteriorate quickly. Paper and cloth signs are appropriate for interior temporary use only. The use of interior signs on paper or cloth should be the result of careful thinking about readability and the image of the business. (4) Sign legibility. An effective sign should do more than attract attention, it should communicate a message. Usually, this is a question of the readability of words and phrases. The most significant influence on legibility is lettering. a. Pedestrian-oriented signs. Make signs smaller if they are oriented to pedestrians. The pedestrian-oriented sign is usually read from a distance of 15 to 20 feet; the vehicle-oriented sign is viewed from a much greater distance. The closer a sign's viewing distance, the smaller that sign need be. See the following table. LETTERING SIZE FOR PEDESTRIAN-ORIENTED SIGNS
Figure SG-6
b. Use a brief message. A brief message should be used whenever possible. The fewer the words, the more effective the sign. A sign with a brief, succinct message is easier to read and looks more attractive. Evaluate each word. If the word does not contribute directly to the basic message of the sign, it detracts from it and probably should be deleted. c. Space letters and words carefully. Letters and words should not be spaced too close together. Crowding of letters, words or lines will make any sign more difficult to read. Conversely, over-spacing these elements causes the viewer to read each item individually, again obscuring the message. As a general rule, letters should not occupy more than 75 percent of sign panel area. See Figure SG-7. Figure SG-7
d. Limit the number of letter styles. The number of lettering styles should be limited in order to increase legibility. A general rule to follow is to limit the number of different letter types to no more than two for small signs and three for larger signs. Intricate typefaces and symbols that are difficult to read reduce the sign's ability to communicate. Figure SG-8
e. Use symbols and logos. Symbols and logos can be used in place of words wherever appropriate. Pictographic images will usually register more quickly in the viewer's mind than a written message. Figure SG-9
(5) Sign illumination. The possible illumination of a sign should be carefully considered. Like color, illumination can provide more effective visual communication, or can confuse the message. Imaginative and innovative lighting techniques for signs are encouraged. a. Use illumination only if necessary. Consider if the sign needs to be lighted at all. Lights in the window display may be sufficient to identify the business. This is particularly true if good window graphics are used. Often, nearby street lights provide ample illumination of a sign after dark. Figure SG-10
b. Use a direct light source. If the sign can be illuminated by a direct source of light (e.g., spotlight), this is usually the best arrangement because the sign will appear to be better integrated with the building's architecture. Light fixtures supported in front of the structure cast light on the sign and generally a portion of the face of the structure as well. Direct lighting emphasizes the continuity of the structure's surface, and signs become an integral part of the facade. Direct lighting is also appropriate because it produces a more intimate ambiance on the street. The lighting of signs should be considered as an element in a building's overall lighting design. Figure SG-11
Figure SG-12
c. Shield the light source. Whenever direct lighting fixtures are used (fluorescent or incandescent), care should be taken to properly shield the light source to prevent glare from spilling over into residential areas and any public right-of-way. Signs should be lighted only to the minimum level required for nighttime readability. d. Backlighted signs. Backlighted, solid letters are encouraged. Signs consisting of opaque individually cut letters mounted directly on a structure can often use a distinctive element of the structure's facade as a backdrop, thereby providing a better integration of the sign with the structure. (Code 1990, § 18-1; Ord. No. 310, 10-20-1998)

div.head: Chapter 78 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-9-1; hazardous waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-79.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Litter means all sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, waste materials, cans, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, dead animals or discarded materials of every kind and description. Public or private property means the right-of-way of any street or highway, any body of water, any park, playground, building, conservation or recreation area, residential or farm land, whether owned by a public agency or privately owned. (Code 1990, § 21-151; Ord. No. 159, § 1, 7-28-1981) Sec. 78-2. - Billing of waste disposal fees. Fees for the collection of solid wastes shall be billed and collected as provided in article II of chapter 94, pertaining to utilities. Secs. 78-3—78-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - GARBAGE COLLECTION DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 78-23—78-42. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - MULTIFAMILY, COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL
Sec. 78-43. - Containers. (a) All multiple-family dwellings of six or more units, commercial and business establishments, industries, schools, churches, hospitals and public buildings shall provide one of the following containers and will receive sanitation service by the city: (1) Ninety-gallon roll-type container. (2) Two-cubic-yard rear-loading dumpster. (3) Four-cubic-yard rear-loading dumpster. Containers not conforming to the requirements above or trash/garbage not contained in one of the above containers will not be serviced. (b) All the containers must be furnished at the expense of the enterprises or businesses and must be approved by the city administrator. (Code 1990, § 21-153(a), (b); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-44. - Placement of containers; roll-back requirements. (a) All containers must be placed upon an accessible hard-surfaced space of sufficient size to accommodate the required garbage container for city containerized garbage pickup. Where dumpsters are utilized, there shall be sufficient driveable area to permit reasonable ingress and egress by city trucks. Otherwise, roll-type containers must be used. (b) All roll-type containers must be removed from the collection location within 24 hours of collection and placed in a location for use that does not present an obstruction to pedestrian or vehicular traffic and that does not create a public nuisance. Containers should be safely and attractively located at the rear of structures, if possible, or in such other place as best conceals them from public view. (Code 1990, § 21-153(c); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-45. - Unsafe or damaged containers. Unsafe or damaged containers shall be repaired immediately. The commercial sanitation crew or sanitation supervisor shall report any container in need of repair to the city hall. City hall shall then inform the business of the container problem within that business day. The business shall be given adequate time to replace or repair the container within the allotted time, then the city will give notice to the business that the city will repair or replace the container, and the cost of the repair or replacement will be added to their utility bill. (Code 1990, § 21-153(d); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-46. - Shared containers. Nothing herein shall prevent establishments from sharing a container provided that the container is sufficient to adequately hold the garbage and trash of the establishments sharing a container. Establishments or businesses that share a container shall pay their pro rata share of the monthly garbage collection fee on such a basis as is agreed upon between them and, in the event no agreement is made, then upon the basis as set by the city government. (Code 1990, § 21-153(e); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-47. - Dumpsters. Where it is impossible or impractical for each business to have its own dumpster or container because of lack of area, the city shall then provide a common dumpster and assign several businesses to the dumpster. Businesses assigned to the dumpster shall pay their pro rata share of the cost of garbage collection for the dumpster based upon use. (Code 1990, § 21-153(e); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-48. - Accessibility of containers. On all fenced property, the containers shall be made readily accessible to city collection crews. On all property fenced to restrain animals, the containers shall be made readily accessible to city collection crews without their entry into the fenced area. Unless space prohibits, containers shall be shielded from the sight of the street and shall be within the property building line unless the container is being shared with another establishment or business. (Code 1990, § 21-153(f); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-49. - Collection schedule. The number of pickup services per week shall be determined by the need of each business. The minimum number of pickups per week shall be two. A record of the number of pickups and the days to be serviced for each business shall be kept at city hall with a copy posted in the commercial truck at all times. (Code 1990, § 21-153(g); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-50. - Appointment for collection of wood or metal. All dumpsters or containers shall be free of any wood or metal. This material shall be picked up by appointment and charged by the ton at the rate established by resolution of the city council. (Code 1990, § 21-153(h); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-51. - Exception for churches and nonprofit organizations. All businesses, apartment units, industries, schools, hospitals and public buildings shall receive sanitation service and shall be charged for the same. Churches and nonprofit organizations will receive sanitation service by need and choice. If churches or nonprofit organizations choose not to receive sanitation service by the city, then they shall not be charged for the service. (Code 1990, § 21-153(i); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-52. - Building permit conditioned on collection plan. No building permit shall be issued by the building inspector for new construction or remodeling of existing buildings unless approved plans and specifications are submitted setting forth and complying with the requirements of this article. (Code 1990, § 21-153(j); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-53. - Penalties. Any person, corporation, business and any other establishment violating any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine of not more than $100.00 or imprisonment including working on city streets, for not more than 30 days for each violation of this section. Each day that this section is violated shall constitute a separate violation. (Code 1990, § 21-153(k); Ord. No. 162, §§ 1—6, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 234, §§ 1—11, 11-27-1990) Secs. 78-54—78-72. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - RESIDENTIAL
Sec. 78-73. - Containers. The city shall provide the first roll-type container for each residential customer free of charge. All lost, damaged or stolen containers shall be replaced or repaired by the city at the customer's expense. (Code 1990, § 21-154; Ord. No. 234, § 14, 11-27-1990) Sec. 78-74. - Landscaping waste and yard trimmings; mixed trash. The city will only accept household garbage in the designated garbage containers provided by the city. Leaves and limbs will be picked up along the curbside only. Any leaves and limbs mixed with household garbage (paper, metal, cans, etc.) will not be picked up by the city. (Code 1990, § 21-155(b); Ord. No. 282, 2-13-1996)

div.head: Chapter 82 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; authority for local regulations of streets, sidewalks, and other public places, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 82-1—82-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - USE OF SIDEWALKS
Sec. 82-19. - Regulations governing the use of sidewalks. Merchants may place their merchandise on city sidewalks on the following conditions: (1) The merchandise must be placed against the building or store front so that there will not be a gap between the merchandise and the building. (2) Such merchandise must be placed adjoining the premises of that business and not any building or premises of another business. (3) Such merchandise must be placed in a manner so as not to interfere with pedestrian traffic on the sidewalk. (4) No object which is inherently dangerous may be placed on the sidewalk. (5) No toxic chemicals or any object capable of exploding may be placed upon the sidewalks. (6) No appliance may be connected to any energy source. (7) No refrigerator may be placed upon the sidewalk unless the doors have been removed or are of a type which may be opened from the inside in compliance with federal and state safety requirements for refrigerators. (8) No objects may be stacked upon each other and no object may be placed on the sidewalk which could fall over by wind or a person putting slight pressure on the object unless it is firmly attached to the sidewalk to prevent it from being tipped over. (Code 1990, § 20-50; Ord. No. 254, § 1, 3-24-1992) Sec. 82-20. - Liability. In order to place merchandise on the sidewalk the owner of the business must first give a hold harmless agreement to the city for any injuries that might result to pedestrians from such merchandise being placed on the sidewalk. In addition the business must have liability insurance in the minimum amount of $50,000.00 which will indemnify the hold harmless agreement to the city and must present proof of same to the city. (Code 1990, § 20-51; Ord. No. 254, § 2, 3-24-1992) Sec. 82-21. - Removal of merchandise; appeals. (a) The city shall have the right to require any merchant placing merchandise on the sidewalk to immediately remove same in the event that the sidewalk is needed for the city making repairs to the sidewalk or any utilities located under or over the said sidewalk. (b) In addition, the merchant must immediately remove such merchandise that the city, through its administrative officers, including police and building inspector and chief administrative officer, deem to be dangerous or in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. (c) If such merchant does not agree that such merchandise is dangerous or in violation of any provision of this article, such merchant may appeal in writing to the city council for its determination as to whether such merchandise violates any provision of this article and such appeal must be heard by the mayor and council within 15 days of receipt of written notice of such appeal. (Code 1990, § 20-52; Ord. No. 254, § 3, 3-24-1992) Secs. 82-22—82-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS
Sec. 82-46. - Permit required. All persons desiring to excavate or to dig into the ground on a public road or street, public right-of-way or public easement on, in or under which is located a city water, sewage or natural gas line whether in the city limits or not, shall first obtain a permit from the city administrator's office authorizing such excavation or dig. The person desiring such a permit shall first identify to the city administrator the exact location of the excavation or dig, the depth, width and length of the excavation or dig. (Code 1990, § 20-1(a); Ord. No. 165, § 1, 10-26-1982) Sec. 82-47. - Fees and costs. (a) A permit shall be issued without cost provided that the excavation or dig does not interfere with any city water, sewer or natural gas line. (b) If such excavation or dig does interfere with such utility line, no permit shall be issued unless arrangements are made by such person, corporation or business to ensure the complete safety of the area upon interference with such utility lines and safe reconnection of any utility lines interfered with. (c) All costs of reconnection of utility lines must be borne by person to whom the permit was issued, and the excavation or dig shall not be refilled until inspection and approval by the city administrator and only then upon satisfactory evidence of complete and safe reconnection of such utility lines or that the lines were not interfered with. (Code 1990, § 20-1(b); Ord. No. 165, § 1, 10-26-1982) Secs. 82-48—82-67. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PARADES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 82-68. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street or other public place. (Code 1990, § 20-26; Ord. No. 66, § 1, 8-14-1962) Sec. 82-69. - Exemptions. This article shall not apply to: (1) Funeral processions; (2) Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; (3) A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. (Code 1990, § 20-27; Ord. No. 66, § 2, 8-14-1962) Sec. 82-70. - Compliance with laws and regulations. A person holding a parade permit shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. (Code 1990, § 20-28; Ord. No. 66, § 3, 8-14-1962) Sec. 82-71. - Refusal to disassemble unauthorized parade. It shall be unlawful for any person, group of persons, or organization, having once assembled for an unauthorized parade to fail or refuse to disperse upon being ordered so to do by any police officer of the city or by any other law enforcement officer of the state. (Code 1990, § 20-29; Ord. No. 66, § 4, 8-14-1962) Secs. 82-72—82-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 82-101. - Required. No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, without a parade permit issued by the city administrator. (Code 1990, § 20-41; Ord. No. 66, § 3, 8-14-1962) Sec. 82-102. - Application. (a) A person desiring a parade permit shall file an application with the city administrator on forms provided by the city administrator. Such application shall be filed not less than seven days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. (b) The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: (1) The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade; (2) If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; (3) The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct; (4) The date when the parade is to be conducted; (5) The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; (6) The approximate number of persons who and animals and vehicles which will constitute such parade, the type of animals and description of the vehicles; (7) The hours when such parade will start and terminate; (8) A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; (9) The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade; (10) The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area; (11) The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; (12) If the parade is designed to be held by and on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the city administrator a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; (13) Any additional information which the city administrator shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. (c) The city administrator, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application which is filed less than seven or more than ten days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. (Code 1990, § 20-42; Ord. No. 66, § 1, 8-14-1962) Sec. 82-103. - Standards for issuance. The city administrator shall issue a parade permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: (1) The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; (2) The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of this city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to this city; (3) The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of this city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; (4) The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of or ambulance service to areas contiguous to such assembly areas; (5) The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire; (6) The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; (7) The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. (Code 1990, § 20-43; Ord. No. 66, § 2, 8-14-1962) Sec. 82-104. - Notice of denial. If the city administrator disapproves an application for a parade permit, he shall mail a notice of his action to the applicant within three days after the date upon which the application was filed. (Code 1990, § 20-44; Ord. No. 66, § 2, 8-14-1962) Sec. 82-105. - Alternative permit. The city administrator, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall file a written notice of acceptance with the city administrator within five days after notice of the action of the city administrator. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. (Code 1990, § 20-45) Sec. 82-106. - Contents of permit. Each parade permit shall state the following information: (1) Starting time; (2) Minimum speed; (3) Maximum speed; (4) Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; (5) The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; (6) The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; (7) Such other information as the city administrator shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. (Code 1990, § 20-46) Sec. 82-107. - Revocation. The city administrator shall have the authority, after a hearing affording due process, to revoke a parade permit issued pursuant to this article upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. (Code 1990, § 20-47)

div.head: Chapter 86 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to plan, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV; zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 86-1. - Purpose and intent. This chapter is adopted for the following purposes: (1) To encourage economically sound and stable land development; (2) To ensure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to land developments; (3) To ensure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in land developments; (4) To ensure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes; and (5) To ensure that land is developed in conformity with the comprehensive plan of the city. (Code 1990, app. B, § 12; Ord. No. 154-A, § 12, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Generally. The term "shall" is mandatory. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the singular include the plural and those in the plural include the singular. Words used in the present tense include the future. City engineer means the appropriate city official designated by the mayor and city council of Montezuma and/or such appropriate official in consultation with such consulting engineer as the city may employ. Lot means a portion or parcel of land separated from other portions or parcels by description as on a subdivision plat or record of survey map or as described by metes and bounds, and intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. For the purpose of this chapter, the term does not include any portion of a dedicated right-of-way. Major subdivision. (1) The term "major subdivision" means all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into three or more lots, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy, or building development; and includes all division of land into two or more lots involving a new street, or a change in existing streets; or divisions of land involving the extension of water, sewer, or gas lines and includes resubdivisions and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided. (2) The following are not included within this definition: a. The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards of the municipality; and b. The division of land into parcels of five acres or more where no new street is involved. Minor subdivision. (1) The term "minor subdivision" means all divisions of a tract of land into less than three lots, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy, or building development, and where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or the land or area subdivided. (2) The following are not included within this definition: a. All divisions of land involving a new street; a change in an existing street; or the extension of water, sewer, or gas lines; b. The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards of the municipality; and c. The division of land into parcels of five acres or more where no new street is involved. Planning commission means the Montezuma Planning Commission. Street means a way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as an avenue, boulevard, road, highway, expressway, land, alley, or other way. For the purpose of this chapter, streets are divided into the following categories: (1) Major streets. Those streets designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan for the city. (2) Secondary street. A city street used to carry traffic from local streets to major streets, and also designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan for the city. (3) Local street. A street used primarily for access to the abutting properties. (4) Cul-de-sac. A local street with only one outlet, sometimes called a dead-end street. Subdivider means the person, firm or corporation having such a proprietary interest in the land to be subdivided as will authorize the maintenance of proceedings to subdivide such land under this chapter, or the authorized agent of such person, firm or corporation for the purpose of proceeding under this chapter. (Code 1990, app. B, art. II; Ord. No. 154-A, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-3—86-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PLATTING JURISDICTION, ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 86-23. - Platting authority. The planning commission is the official platting authority, and no plat of land subdivision shall be entitled to be recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county unless it shall have the approval of the planning commission inscribed thereon. The filing or recording of a plat of a subdivision without the approval of the planning commission is declared to be a misdemeanor. (Code 1990, app. B, § 31; Ord. No. 154-A, § 31, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-24. - Use of plat. The transfer of, sale of, agreement to sell, or negotiation to sell land by reference to or exhibition of, or other use of a plat of a subdivision that has not been given final approval by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county is prohibited, and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. (Code 1990, app. B, § 32; Ord. No. 154-A, § 32, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-25. - Opening public streets. The governing body of the city shall not accept or light any street which had not attained the status of a public street prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, unless such street corresponds to the street locations shown on an approved subdivision plat or on an official street map adopted by the planning commission, provided that the governing body may accept any street not so platted if it first submits such proposed action to the planning commission for its review and comment. Furthermore, no new street shall be accepted by the city as a public street until the provisions in article XI of this chapter have been met. (Code 1990, app. B, § 33; Ord. No. 154-A, § 33, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-26. - Erection of buildings. No building permit shall be issued and no building shall be erected on any lot in the city unless the street giving access thereto has been accepted as a public street in accordance with this article, or unless such street attained the status of a public street prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. (Code 1990, app. B, § 34; Ord. No. 154-A, § 34, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-27—86-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PREAPPLICATION PROCEDURE
Sec. 86-56. - Subdivider to consult chairman or planning commission. Whenever a major subdivision or a tract of land within the city is proposed, the subdivider is urged to consult early and informally with the chairman or a designated member of the planning commission (see article VIII of this chapter for minor subdivision plat review procedures). The subdivider may submit sketch plans and data showing existing conditions within the site and in its vicinity and the proposed layout and development of the subdivision. No fee shall be charged for the preapplication review and no formal application shall be required. (Code 1990, app. B, art. IV; Ord. No. 154-A, art. IV, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-57—86-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PROCEDURES FOR TENTATIVE APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT
Sec. 86-86. - Application for preliminary plat approval. Following the preapplication review of a proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall submit to the chairman of the planning commission, at least 15 days prior to the next regular meeting of the planning commission, the following: (1) A letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat and giving the name and address of a person to whom the notice of the hearing by the planning commission on the preliminary plat shall be sent. (2) Three copies of the preliminary plat and other documents, as specified in article V. (Code 1990, app. B, § 51; Ord. No. 154-A, § 51, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-87. - Review of preliminary plat. (a) Report to planning commission; hearing. The chairman of the planning commission shall check the plat for conformance to the rules and regulations of this chapter and report his findings and recommendations to the planning commission, which shall afford a hearing on the preliminary plat, notice of the time and place for which shall be sent by the secretary of the planning commission by registered or certified mail to the person designated in the letter requesting preliminary plat review and approval, not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing. (b) Results of hearing. Thereafter, a majority of the planning commission shall give tentative approval or disapproval to the preliminary plat. A notation of the action shall be made on two copies of the preliminary plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval if the preliminary plat is disapproved. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider or his agent and one copy added to the records of the planning commission. (c) Time limits; final plat approval separate issue. Tentative approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. It indicates only approval of the layout as a guide to the preparation of the final plat. Tentative approval shall expire and be null and void after a period of one year unless an extension of time is approved by the planning commission. However, in the event that only a portion of the land shown in the plat is approved as provided for in section 86-122, that portion of the preliminary plat depicting the contiguous area to be developed at a later time shall be considered as being approved tentatively for two years subject to changes or reconsideration by either the subdivider or the planning commission. (d) Automatic approval. If action on a preliminary plat is not taken by the planning commission within 30 days of the date of submittal, the preliminary plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. (Code 1990, app. B, § 52; Ord. No. 154-A, § 52, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-88—86-117. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PRELIMINARY PLAT SPECIFICATIONS
Sec. 86-118. - Scale. The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a scale not smaller than 100 feet to one inch. (Code 1990, app. B, § 61; Ord. No. 154-A, § 61, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-119. - Sheet size. Sheet size shall be 17 inches by 22 inches or the sheet shall be the size required by the clerk of the superior court for recording purposes. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet of this size, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. (Code 1990, app. B, § 62; Ord. No. 154-A, § 62, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-120. - Ground elevations. (a) The preliminary plat shall show ground elevations, based on the datum plane of the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey (or a datum plane approved by the city engineer). (b) All land shall be topographically mapped using a five-foot contour interval, and a tie to one or more benchmarks shall be shown. (Code 1990, app. B, § 63; Ord. No. 154-A, § 63, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-121. - Information to be provided on preliminary plat. The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: (1) Name and address of the owner of record and of the subdivider. (2) Proposed name of the subdivision and its acreage. (3) North arrow, graphic scale and date. (4) Vicinity map showing location and acreage of the subdivision. (5) Exact boundary lines of the tract by bearings and distances. (6) Names of owners of record of adjoining land. (7) Existing streets, utilities and easements on and adjacent to the tract. (8) Proposed layout including streets and alleys, easements, land to be reserved or dedicated for public uses. (9) Proposed street names, lot lines with approximate dimensions, and any land to be used for purposes other than single-family dwellings. (10) Block numbers and lot numbers. (11) Provisions for water supply, sewerage and drainage. (12) Minimum building front yard setback lines. (13) Such street cross section and centerline profiles as may be required by the city engineer or other city officials. (14) Where individual septic tanks are to be used, the county health department shall conduct percolation tests to determine minimum lot sizes to be allowed. (Code 1990, app. B, § 64; Ord. No. 154-A, § 64, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-122. - Contiguous areas. In the event that the applicant desires to develop only a portion of the land owned by him, such applicant is encouraged to include as a part of the preliminary plat any future plans for the development of the contiguous area. In such event, only the requirements of section 86-121(1) through (8) will be required for tentative approval of that portion of the plat depicting such contiguous area. (Code 1990, app. B, § 65; Ord. No. 154-A, § 65, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-123. - Certificate of tentative approval. A certificate of tentative approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission shall be inscribed on the plat as follows: (1) Pursuant to the land subdivision regulations of the city, all the requirements of tentative approval having been fulfilled, this preliminary plat was given tentative approval by the Montezuma Planning Commission on ____________ / ____________ / ____________ (date). (2) This tentative approval does not constitute approval of a final plat. This certificate of tentative approval shall expire and be null and void on ____________ / ____________ / ____________ (date).
(Code 1990, app. B, § 66; Ord. No. 154-A, § 66, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-124—86-144. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - FINAL PLAT PROCEDURE
Sec. 86-145. - Application for final plat approval. After the preliminary plat of a proposed major land subdivision has been given tentative approval by the planning commission, the subdivider may, within one year from tentative approval, submit to the planning commission: (1) A letter requesting review and approval of a final plat and giving the name and address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing by the planning commission on the final plat shall be sent. (2) Five copies of the final plat and other documents, as specified in article IV of this chapter, the original and at least one copy of which shall be drawn in permanent ink on tracing linen or its equivalent. (3) A recording fee as required by the county. (Code 1990, app. B, § 71; Ord. No. 154-A, § 71, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-146. - Review of final plat. (a) Report to planning commission; hearing. The chairman of the planning commission shall check the final plat for conformance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat, and with the rules and regulations of this chapter and report his findings and recommendations to the planning commission, which shall afford a hearing on the final plat, notice of the time and place of which shall be sent by the secretary of the planning commission by registered or certified mail to the person designated in the letter requesting final plat review and approval, not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing. (b) Results of hearing. Thereafter, a majority of the planning commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original tracing and two prints of the final plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the final plat is disapproved. If action on a final plat is not taken by the planning commission within 30 days of the date of the submittal, the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. In the event that the preliminary plat depicts an incremental development of the entire plot of land owned by the applicant, final plat requirements shall apply only to that portion of the plot that is to be immediately developed. (Code 1990, app. B, § 72; Ord. No. 154-A, § 72, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-147. - Recording of final plat. (a) Upon approval of the final plat, the chairman of the planning commission shall have the plat recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county. The subdivider shall be responsible for the payment of the recording fee at the time of submitting the final plat as provided in section 86-146. (b) Subsequent to the recording of the final plat, two copies with all certificates endorsed thereon shall be made for the records of the planning commission. The map book, volume and page numbers where the plat is recorded shall be indicated. The final plat shall then be returned to the subdivider. (Code 1990, app. B, § 73; Ord. No. 154-A, § 73, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-148—86-177. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - FINAL PLAT SPECIFICATIONS
Sec. 86-178. - The final plat specifications. The final plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the preliminary plat, with the following additions: (1) The final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn in permanent ink on tracing linen or its equivalent. Sheet sizes shall be 17 inches by 22 inches or the sheet size shall be that required by the clerk of the superior court. Where more than one sheet is required an index map shall be required on the same size sheet. (2) Bearings and distances to the nearest existing street lines or benchmarks or other permanent monuments (not less than three) shall be accurately described on the plat. (3) Municipal, county and land lot lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and angles when such lines traverse or are reasonably close to the subdivision. (4) Exact boundary lines of the tract, determined by a field survey, giving distances to the nearest one-tenth foot and angles to the nearest minute, which shall be balanced and closed with an error of closure not to exceed 1 to 5,000. (5) Name of subdivision, exact locations, widths, and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat. (6) Street centerlines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii, and lengths of tangents. (7) Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest one-tenth foot and bearings. (8) Lots numbered in numerical order and blocks lettered alphabetically. (9) Locations, dimensions, and purposes of any easements and any areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use. (10) Accurate location, material, and description of monuments and markers. (11) A statement, either directly on the plat or in an identified attached document, of any private covenants. (Code 1990, app. B, § 81; Ord. No. 154-A, § 81, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-179. - Certificates required to be on plat. The following certificates shall be placed directly on or attached to the plat: (1) An engineer's or surveyor's certification. This certificate shall be placed directly on the final plat as follows: It is hereby certified that this plat is true and correct and was prepared from an actual survey of the property by me or under my supervision; that all monuments shown thereon actually exist or are marked as "future," and their location, size, type and material are correctly shown; and that all engineering requirements of the land subdivision regulations of the city have been fully complied with.
(2) An owner's certification. This certificate shall be placed directly on the final plat as follows: Owner's Certificate State of Georgia, County of Macon The owner of the land shown on this plat and whose name is subscribed hereto, in person or through duly authorized agent, certifies that this plat was made from actual survey, that all state, city and county taxes or other assessments now due on this land have been paid.
(3) Certification of the city engineer, county health officer. a. The city engineer, or other registered engineer, shall certify that the streets, drainage, and other improvements indicated on the plat have been completed to proper specifications and per design standards. b. Where the required improvements have not been completed, the city attorney shall certify that approved bond, or security, has been posted to ensure their completion, as provided in section 86-180. c. Where septic tanks are to be used in lieu of public sewerage, the county health officer or local health authority shall certify that adequate septic tanks have been installed to specification and that the lot areas shown on the plat are adequate to accommodate individual septic tanks. (4) Water and sewer certificate. A certificate by the chief administrative officer stating that water mains will be available to or have been provided for the land to be developed. Such certificates shall describe the particular area to be served by lot number and block letter. Such certificate also shall state the same with regard to sanitary sewer expansions. This certificate shall be attached to the final plat before recording. (5) Certificate of dedication. A certificate by the owner setting forth the description of the areas and improvements he dedicates to the public and the extent of the title which he is dedicating should be attached to the final plat. Because of the legal consideration here, this certificate should be approved as to form by the city attorney. (6) Copy of official action of governing body. A copy of the ordinance adopted by the governing body accepting the streets, improvements, easements and any other property dedicated by the owner for public use, as indicated on the final plat, shall be attached to the final plat before recording. (7) A certificate of approval of the final plat by the planning commission. This certificate shall be placed directly on the plat, as follows: Pursuant to the land subdivision regulations of the City of Montezuma, Georgia, all the requirements of approval having been fulfilled, this final plat was given final approval by the Montezuma Planning Commission on ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 19 ____________ .
(Code 1990, app. B, § 82; Ord. No. 154-A, § 82, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-180. - Attorney's certification. (a) Performance guarantee requirement. If all improvements as required by the planning commission approval of the preliminary plat are not properly installed and constructed in accordance with the required standards prior to the submission of a final plat application, the subdivider shall file with the city attorney an acceptable performance guarantee to ensure future installation and construction. (b) Approval by city council. The performance guarantee must be approved by the city council and must include a specific, reasonable and satisfactory date for the completion of the necessary improvements. In no case shall the performance guarantee be valid for more than two years. When the improvements have been completed and approved for conformity with these regulations, the guarantee shall be released and returned. (c) Release or forfeiture of funds. When any portion of the required improvements has been completed and approved, a portion of the guarantee commensurate with the cost of these completed improvements may be released and returned. In the event the subdivider fails to install or construct the required improvements during the specific time allotted and in conformity with these regulations, the performance guarantee is forfeited to the city to be used for the completion of the improvements. (Code 1990, app. B, § 82; Ord. No. 154-A, § 82, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-181—86-196. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - PROCEDURE FOR REVIEW OF MINOR SUBDIVISION PLATS
Sec. 86-197. - Applicability. Whenever a minor subdivision is proposed the requirements of articles III, V, VI, and VII of this chapter shall not apply except as herein provided. The following procedures for application review and approval shall govern. (Code 1990, app. B, § 91; Ord. No. 154-A, § 91, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-198. - Application for minor plat approval. The subdivider shall submit to the chairman of the planning commission four copies of a survey (hereafter called the plat) of the proposed minor subdivision prepared by a registered land surveyor or engineer. (Code 1990, app. B, § 92; Ord. No. 154-A, § 92, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-199. - Review of minor plat. (a) Review, hearing, results. The planning commission shall check the plat for conformance to the rules and regulations of this chapter and shall afford a hearing on the plat, notice of the time and place of which shall be sent by the chairman of the planning commission by registered or certified mail to the person submitting the plat at least five days prior to the date of the hearing. After the hearing, the planning commission shall approve or disapprove the plat. A notation of action shall be made on all copies of the plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval if the plat is disapproved. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider or his agent, one copy added to the records of the planning commission, one copy sent to the city engineer, and one copy shall be recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county by the chairman of the planning commission. The subdivider shall be responsible for the payment of the recording fee at the time of submitting the minor subdivision plat. (b) Automatic approval. If action is not taken by the planning commission within 30 days from the date of submittal, the plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. (Code 1990, app. B, § 93; Ord. No. 154-A, § 93, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-200. - Minor plat specifications. The plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a suitable scale and shall contain all information normally required in an official survey with an engineer's or surveyor's certification, plus an owner's certification, certificate of dedication, and certificate of approval directly on the plat as prescribed for subdivision plats in article VII of this chapter. (Code 1990, app. B, § 94; Ord. No. 154-A, § 94, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-201—86-223. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - GENERAL DESIGN REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 86-224. - Suitability of land. Land subject to flooding, improper drainage, or erosion, or that is for topographical or other reasons unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential use or for any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health, safety, or property destruction, unless the hazards can be and are corrected. (Code 1990, app. B, § 101; Ord. No. 154-A, § 101, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-225. - Name of subdivision. The name of the subdivision must have the approval of the planning commission. The name shall not duplicate nor closely approximate the name of an existing subdivision. (Code 1990, app. B, § 102; Ord. No. 154-A, § 102, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-226. - Access. Access to every subdivision shall be provided over a public street. (Code 1990, app. B, § 103; Ord. No. 154-A, § 103, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-227. - Conformance to adopted major thoroughfare and other plans. (a) All streets and other features of the major thoroughfare plan of the city shall be platted by the subdivider in the location and to the dimension indicated on the major street plan adopted by the planning commission. (b) When features of other plans adopted by the planning commission (such as schools or other public building sites, parks, or other land for public uses) are located in whole or in part in a land subdivision, such features shall be either dedicated or reserved by the subdivider for acquisition within a reasonable time by the appropriate public agency. (Code 1990, app. B, § 104; Ord. No. 154-A, § 104, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-228. - Storm drainage requirements. (a) City standards to be met at subdivider's expense; completion before development. Storm drainage systems shall be installed within every subdivision in accordance with city standards. The subdivider shall be responsible for installing, at his own expense, all improvements necessary to provide proper drainage for his property and the drainage system of the subdivision. All drainage improvements must be complete and approved prior to the development of the subdivision. (b) Design constraints; adjoining properties. In the design of all storm drainage facilities, special consideration shall be given to preventing excess runoff onto adjacent developed or undeveloped land. When a storm drainage outlet will abut another property, the subdivider shall secure the approval, in writing, of the adjoining affected owners and submit such an approval to the planning commission. In no case may a change be made in the existing topography which would result in a slope which exceeds the normal angle of slippage of the material involved. (Code 1990, app. B, § 105; Ord. No. 154-A, § 105, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-229. - Utility system plans. The plans for the installation of a water supply system, a sanitary sewer system, and a storm drainage system must be prepared with the cooperation and approval of the appropriate utility agency, the city engineer, the county health officials, and the state department of natural resources officials. Upon completion of the water, sewer, and storm drainage systems, copies of the plans as built and approved shall be filed with the city council. (Code 1990, app. B, § 106; Ord. No. 154-A, § 106, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-230. - Large-scale developments. The requirements of this chapter may be modified in the case of a large-scale community or neighborhood unit, such as a housing project or shopping center which is not subdivided into customary lots, blocks, and streets, if the development is approved by the planning commission and if it is in conformity with the purpose and intent of this chapter. (Code 1990, app. B, § 107; Ord. No. 154-A, § 107, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-231—86-253. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR STREETS AND OTHER RIGHTS-OF-WAY
Sec. 86-254. - Continuation of existing streets. Existing streets shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. (Code 1990, app. B, § 111; Ord. No. 154-A, § 111, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-255. - Paved streets. All streets in a subdivision shall be paved in accordance with article XI of this chapter. (Code 1990, app. B, § 112; Ord. No. 154-A, § 112, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-256. - Street names. Street names shall require the approval of the planning commission. Streets that are obviously in alignment with streets already existing and named shall be given the names of the existing streets. Names of new streets shall not duplicate or closely approximate those of existing streets. (Code 1990, app. B, § 113; Ord. No. 154-A, § 113, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-257. - Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. (Code 1990, app. B, § 114; Ord. No. 154-A, § 114, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-258. - Culs-de-sac. Except where topographic or other conditions make a greater length unavoidable, culs-de-sac, or dead-end streets, shall not be greater in length than 2,500 feet or contain more than 50 housing units. They shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having a property line radius of at least 50 feet with an outside pavement radius of at least 40 feet. (Code 1990, app. B, § 115; Ord. No. 154-A, § 115, 5-13-1980; Ord. No. 297, 6-10-1997) Sec. 86-259. - Development along major streets, limited-access highways or railroad rights-of-way. Where a subdivision abuts or contains a major street, a limited-access highway, or a railroad right-of-way, the planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way either as a marginal access street or, at a distance suitable for an appropriate use to the intervening land, with a nonaccess reservation suitably planted. Due regard should be given requirements for approach grades and future grade separations in determining distances. (Code 1990, app. B, § 116; Ord. No. 154-A, § 116, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-260. - Alleys. Alleys may be required at the rear of all lots used for multifamily, commercial, or industrial developments but shall not be provided in one-family and two-family residential developments unless the subdivider provides evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys. (Code 1990, app. B, § 117; Ord. No. 154-A, § 117, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-261. - Reserve strips. Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys, and public grounds shall not be permitted unless their control is placed in the hands of the city government, under conditions approved by the city government. (Code 1990, app. B, § 118; Ord. No. 154-A, § 118, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-262. - Easements. (a) Easements having a minimum width of ten feet and located along the side or rear lot lines shall be provided, as required for utility lines and underground mains and cables. (b) Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater or drainage right-of-way of adequate width. Parallel streets may be required by the planning commission in connection therewith. (Code 1990, app. B, § 119; Ord. No. 154-A, § 119, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-263—86-287. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - STREET DESIGN REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 86-288. - Street right-of-way widths. The right-of-way width shall be the distance across a street from property line to property line. Minimum street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: (1) Major street widths as shown on the major street plan. (2) Secondary streets, 60 feet. (3) Local streets and dead-end streets, 50 feet except that a right-of-way width of less than 50 feet may be permitted where a street pavement width of not less than 26 feet is provided and where curbs and gutters are also provided along said street, or in the case of very unusual circumstances. (Code 1990, app. B, § 121; Ord. No. 154-A, § 121, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-289. - Street pavement widths. Streets shall have pavement widths as follows: local streets and dead-end streets, 18 feet except that on local streets containing less than 50 feet of right-of-way, a pavement width of 26 feet is required as well as curbs and gutters. (Code 1990, app. B, § 122; Ord. No. 154-A, § 122, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-290. - Street grades. Maximum and minimum street grades shall be as follows: (1) Local streets and dead-end streets and alleys, not in excess of 14 percent. (2) No street grade shall be less than one-half of one percent. (Code 1990, app. B, § 123; Ord. No. 154-A, § 123, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-291. - Horizontal curvature. The minimum radii of centerline curvature shall be as follows: (1) Secondary streets, 200 feet. (2) Local streets and dead-end streets and alleys, 100 feet. (Code 1990, app. B, § 124; Ord. No. 154-A, § 124, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-292. - Street intersections. Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersections shall be at an angle of less than 60 degrees, unless required by unusual circumstances. (Code 1990, app. B, § 125; Ord. No. 154-A, § 125, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-293. - Tangents. Between reverse curves, there shall be a tangent having a length not less than 100 feet. (Code 1990, app. B, § 126; Ord. No. 154-A, § 126, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-294. - Curbline radius. The curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least 15 feet. Where the angle of street intersection is less than 90 degrees, a longer radius may be required. (Code 1990, app. B, § 127; Ord. No. 154-A, § 127, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-295. - Vertical alignment. Vertical alignment shall be such that streets shall have a sight distance of at least 200 feet at six feet above ground level. (Code 1990, app. B, § 128; Ord. No. 154-A, § 128, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-296. - Street improvement specifications. All secondary and local streets within a subdivision shall be improved by the subdivider in accordance with the State of Georgia, 1957, State Highway Department Specifications, Volumes I and II or latest specifications developed by the state department of transportation. (Code 1990, app. B, § 129; Ord. No. 154-A, § 129, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-297—86-325. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR BLOCKS AND LOTS
Sec. 86-326. - Block lengths and widths. Block lengths and widths shall be as follows: (1) Blocks shall be not greater than 1,200 feet in length; except in unusual circumstances, nor less than 600 feet in length, except where necessary because of connection of a new street with an existing street or in other unusual circumstances. (2) Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting major streets, limited-access highways, or railroads or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. (Code 1990, app. B, § 131; Ord. No. 154-A, § 131, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-327. - Lot sizes. (a) Residential lots shall meet the lot width and lot area requirements of the zoning chapter. (b) Residential lots shall have a depth of not less than 100 feet, unless unusual circumstances make these limitations not practicable. (c) Commercial and industrial lots shall be adequate to provide service areas and off-street parking suitable to use intended as prescribed in the zoning chapter. (d) Residential corner lots shall have adequate width to meet building setback requirements from both abutting streets. (Ord. No. 154-A, § 132, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-328. - Lot lines. All lot lines shall be perpendicular or radial to street lines, unless not practicable because of topographic or other features. (Code 1990, app. B, § 133; Ord. No. 154-A, § 133, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-329. - Building lines. A building line meeting the front yard setback requirements of the zoning chapter shall be established on all lots. (Code 1990, app. B, § 134; Ord. No. 154-A, § 134, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-330. - Lots abutting public streets. Each lot shall abut upon a dedicated public street. (Code 1990, app. B, § 135; Ord. No. 154-A, § 135, 5-13-1980) Sec. 86-331. - Double and reverse frontage lots. Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten feet, and across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other incompatible use. (Code 1990, app. B, § 136; Ord. No. 154-A, § 136, 5-13-1980) Secs. 86-332—86-350. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIII. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
Sec. 86-351. - Requirement, approval. No portion of a subdivision plat shall be approved unless all water and sewer mains and storm drainage have been installed or provision made to ensure such installation and a certificate in accordance with section 86-179(4) has been attached to said plat. However, the planning commission may approve plats, portions of which are not served by sanitary sewers because of inability to reach existing mains by gravity flow, provided "Not Available to Sanitary Sewerage" is inscribed on the plat where applicable. (Code 1990, art. XIV; Ord. No. 154-A, art. XIV, 5-13-1980)

div.head: Chapter 90 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; traffic generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; certain powers preserved to local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 90-1. - Business district described. The business district shall include the territory lying in the downtown area bounded as follows: on the west by Drumwright Street, on the north by an alley running between RBC Bank and the Methodist Church, on the east by Engram Street and on the south by Beaver Creek. (Code 1990, § 13-1; Ord. No. 124, art. I, § 1(l), 11-13-1973) Sec. 90-2. - Obedience to traffic provisions. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. (Code 1990, § 13-3; Ord. No. 124, art. III, § 2, 11-13-1973) Sec. 90-3. - Failure to obey summons. No person shall fail or refuse to appear in court to answer for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter as directed in a summons properly served upon him. (Code 1990, § 13-4; Ord. No. 124, art. X, § 4, 11-13-1973) Sec. 90-4. - Use of bicycles restricted. No person shall operate a bicycle upon any sidewalk in the business district of this city. This section shall not prohibit children from moving bicycles on sidewalks in such area while dismounted. (Code 1990, § 13-5; Ord. No. 124, art. III, § 4, 11-13-1973) State Law reference— Authority to regulate persons on toy vehicles preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(18); bicycles and play vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-290 et seq. Secs. 90-5—46-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 90-27. - Authority of police and fire department officials. (a) It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department and such officers as are assigned by the chief of police to such duty to enforce all traffic laws of this city. (b) Officers of the fire department when at the scene of a fire may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. (Code 1990, § 13-26; Ord. No. 124, art. III, § 1, 11-13-1973) State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of police officers preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); obedience to persons directing traffic required, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. Sec. 90-28. - Traffic control devices. (a) The public works department shall place and maintain traffic control signs, signals, and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of such ordinances, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as may be deemed necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of this city or under state law. (b) The public works department is authorized to place markers, buttons, turtles, lines or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections. (c) The public works department is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right or left turn and shall place proper signs at such intersections. (d) The public works department is hereby authorized to take the following action: (1) Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as may be deemed necessary; (2) Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be deemed necessary for the protection of pedestrians; (3) Mark lanes for traffic and spaces for parking and loading on street pavements at such places as may be deemed advisable, consistent with the traffic ordinances of this city. (e) The public works department shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such street accordingly. (Code 1990, § 13-27; Ord. No. 124, art. IV, §§ 1, 4, art. VI, §§ 2, 3, art. IX, § 2, 11-13-1973) State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of official traffic control devices preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(2); traffic signs, signals, etc., O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20 et seq. Sec. 90-29. - Use of speed detection devices approved. The city council approves the use of speed detection devices. Use of such speed detection devices is authorized only upon receipt of permit to use such devices as provided by law. (Code 1990, § 13-28; Ord. No. 155, 7-8-1980) State Law reference— Speed detection devices, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-1 et seq. Sec. 90-30. - Duties of police department. It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the street traffic regulations of this city together with all state laws applicable thereto, make arrests for traffic violations, investigate accidents, cooperate with all other officers of the city in the administration of traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and carry out those duties specially imposed by this chapter and other ordinances of this city. (Code 1990, § 13-29; Ord. No. 124, art. II, § 1, 11-13-1973) Sec. 90-31. - Records of traffic violations. (a) The police department shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances of this city with which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. (b) All such records and reports shall be public records. (Code 1990, § 13-30; Ord. No. 124, art. II, § 2, 11-13-1973) Sec. 90-32. - Traffic accidents. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to investigate traffic accidents, to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents, and to file and maintain records containing such accident reports. (Code 1990, § 13-31; Ord. No. 124, art. II, § 3, 11-13-1973) State Law reference— Accidents and accident reports, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq. Sec. 90-33. - Issuance of summons. (a) Any police officer upon making an arrest for violation of this chapter shall issue a summons to the alleged offender, directing him to appear at the next session of the municipal court, as the case may be, to answer the charges against him, requiring such bond as the police department may from time to time specify, but sufficient to ensure the appearance in court of alleged offender. (b) Service of a summons upon an alleged parking offender by affixing same to the illegally parked vehicle shall be legal and sufficient service upon the alleged offender requiring him to appear in court as directed. (Code 1990, § 13-32; Ord. No. 124, art. X, §§ 3, 5, 11-13-1973) Sec. 90-34. - Impoundment and disposition of motor vehicles. (a) Any person, at the direction of the chief of police or a duly certified police officer, is hereby authorized to remove or have removed at their direction a vehicle from any public or private way or place under any of the circumstances hereinafter enumerated, the council hereby finding and determining such vehicles under such circumstances to be obstructions to traffic or public nuisances. Such vehicle is authorized to be removed under any of the following circumstances: (1) When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, subway or tunnel, or where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic; (2) When a vehicle upon a public way is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal; (3) When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street or parked illegally so as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic, or left unattended on any public street with engine running or with keys in the ignition switch or locked; (4) When any vehicle is parked or left standing upon any area or portion of a public street in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by the chief of police, provided such area or portion of such public street has been posted with an official sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such street is a towaway area; (5) When a vehicle is parked in violation of any traffic ordinance and is an obstruction or hazard or potential obstruction or hazard to any lawful function or limits the normal access to a use of any public or private property; (6) When a vehicle is left on a public way or place and appears to be abandoned or a complaint is received that it is abandoned and remains there continuously for a period of 15 days after a notice is posted on the windshield that it will be impounded, or when an automobile hulk or junker is left on public property for such a period; (7) When the driver of such vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and the vehicle would thereby be left unattended upon a street, highway or restricted parking area, or other public way; (8) When the driver of a vehicle is reasonably suspected of using license plates or license permit, unlawfully misusing a license plate or license permit issued to the driver, or a vehicle is parked without proper license plates or license permits, or with no license plates or license permit, or driven or parked with an invalid or expired license permit; (9) When the driver of a vehicle is driving without an operator's license or chauffeur's license which is current and valid, or who does not have such license in the driver's immediate possession, or who drives a vehicle contrary to restrictions imposed upon the license, or who drives a vehicle while their operator's or chauffeur's license has been denied, suspended, cancelled or revoked by the state; (10) When a vehicle is found parked on or so near to any railroad track as to block the same in any manner; (11) When any truck-tractor is found to be parked in any parking space; (12) When any semi-trailer is found to be parked in any parking space; (13) When the driver of any vehicle, or the vehicle which the driver is driving, is reasonably suspected of having been involved in any hit-and-run accident; (14) When any vehicle is reasonably suspected of being a stolen vehicle, or parts thereof to be stolen parts; (15) When the driver of any vehicle is taken into custody for a suspected felony or misdemeanor, or when the vehicle is suspected of containing stolen goods, or other contraband; (16) When any vehicle is parked or stopped in an emergency access lane in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by city ordinance, provided that such emergency access lane has been posted with an authorized sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such public roadway or private property is a towaway area. (b) The owner of any vehicle so removed and/or impounded shall be required to pay storage and other costs incurred by virtue of such removal and/or impounding, regardless of the cause of the conduct necessitating such action by the police department. (Code 1990, § 13-33; Ord. No. 124, art. X, § 6, 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 263, 10-12-1993) State Law reference— Disposition of personal property in the custody of law enforcement agencies, O.C.G.A. § 17-5-4; authority to remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-3. Secs. 90-35—90-56. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE OPERATION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.
Sec. 90-57. - State law adopted by reference. The Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. (Code 1990, § 13-2; Ord. No. 145, § 1, 11-14-1976) Sec. 90-58. - Criminal trespass by motor vehicles. O.C.G.A. § 16-7-29 is adopted by reference. (Code 1990, § 13-51; Ord. No. 124, art. VII, § 27, 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 202, 10-28-1987) Sec. 90-59. - Maximum speed limit.
