The maximum speed limit upon all streets, roadways and highways within this city shall be 25 miles per hour, except where otherwise provided in this chapter. (Code 1990, § 13-52; Ord. No. 124, art. V, § 1, 11-13-1973) State Law reference— Authority to regulate speed limits, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-371(a)(10), 40-6-183; speed limits generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-180 et seq. Sec. 90-60. - U-turns. (a) On city streets that are state highways or routes no vehicle shall be turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any curve or upon the approach to or near the crest of a grade where such vehicle cannot be seen by the driver of another vehicle approaching from the other direction, or where such turn cannot be made in safety or without interfering with other traffic. (b) On all city streets not state highways or routes, no vehicle shall be turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction. (Code 1990, § 13-53; Ord. No. 196, § 1, 7-8-1986; Ord. No. 239, § 1, 3-12-1991) State Law reference— Authority to restrict or prohibit turns preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(9). Sec. 90-61. - Processions. (a) Prohibited. There is hereby excluded from operation or use on city streets in residential areas which are not part of the state highway system trucks or other motor vehicles containing more than two axles or weighing more than five tons except for the purpose of making deliveries to or from residences or places of business located on or having access to such city streets. There is excluded from this section any street which is part of the state highway system as well as any street the majority of which is located in an area zoned commercial, industrial or agricultural. (b) Punishment. Any person convicted of violating this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than $300.00, imprisonment of not more than 30 days or any combination thereof. Each use of city streets in violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1990, § 13-54; Ord. No. 124, art. VII, §§ 3, 4, 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 242, §§ 1—3, 5-28-1991; Ord. No. 247, 11-26-1991) State Law reference— Authority to regulate processions preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(3); operation of vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7. Secs. 90-62—90-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Authority to regulate stopping, standing or parking preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.
Sec. 90-81. - Obedience to parking signs or markings. Where streets or roadways have been marked for parking, all vehicles will be parked in accordance with such markings. (Code 1990, § 13-71; Ord. No. 124, art. IX, § 3, 11-13-1973) Sec. 90-82. - Parking in area marked with yellow paint. It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to be parked on any public street or road in any area that has been painted with yellow paint by the city as authorized by the city council. Yellow paint is a marking that establishes no-parking zones. (Code 1990, § 13-72; Ord. No. 124, art. X, § 5, 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 201, 1-26-1987) Sec. 90-83. - Parking within fire lanes. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to park within any fire lane at any time for any purpose. This section does not apply to any emergency vehicle of the city or vehicle of any utility company or ambulance company providing service to any occupant of any building adjacent to a fire lane during an emergency. (Code 1990, § 13-73; Ord. No. 124, art. IX, § 6(b), 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 204, 4-12-1988) Sec. 90-84. - Parking time limits. Except as otherwise provided by resolution, no person shall park a motor vehicle in any of the locations designated in section 90-117 for more than 90 consecutive minutes. (Code 1990, § 13-74; Ord. No. 196, §§ 2, 3(b), 7-8-1986) Sec. 90-85. - Overnight parking. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing a vehicle in the business district of the city overnight. Vehicles in violation of this section are subject to immediate removal as provided herein upon the order of the chief of police. (Code 1990, § 13-75; Ord. No. 124, art. IX, § 5, 11-13-1973) Secs. 90-86—90-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
Sec. 90-116. - Parallel parking allowed. Parallel parking zones are established in the following locations: Cherry Street, south side, from Spalding Avenue to South Dooly Street. South Dooly Street, west side, from the Central of Georgia Railroad to Beaver Creek. (Code 1990, § 13-90; Ord. No. 124, art. IV, § 1(a), 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 127, 5-14-1974) State Law reference— Authority to regulate parking preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1). Sec. 90-117. - Ninety-minute parking zones. The following are 90-minute parking zones: Cabot Street. Cherry Street. Dooly Street between Railroad Street (Oglethorpe Road) and where Drayton Alley exits at the Montezuma Motor Company. State Route 224 between Spalding Road and Dooly Street. (Code 1990, § 13-91; Ord. No. 196, § 2, 7-8-1986) State Law reference— Authority to regulate parking preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1). Sec. 90-118. - No parking. Parking is prohibited in the following locations: Cherry Street, north side, from Spalding Road to South Dooly Street. (Code 1990, § 13-92; Ord. No. 124, art. IV, § 1(a), 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 127, 5-14-1974) Sec. 90-119. - One-way streets. The following are one-way streets in the directions indicated: Beaver Street between Spalding Road and South Dooly Street, westwardly. Cherry Street between South Dooly Street and Spalding Road, eastwardly. (Code 1990, § 13-93; Ord. No. 124, art. IV, § 1(a), 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 127, 5-14-1974) State Law reference— Authority to designate one-way streets, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-371(a)(4), 40-6-47. Sec. 90-120. - U-turns prohibited. No U-turns shall be permitted on any road or street within the city. (Code 1990, § 13-94; Ord. No. 196, § 1, 7-8-1986) State Law reference— Authority to regulate turning of vehicles preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(9). Sec. 90-121. - Speed limits. The following speed limits are established: (1) Fifteen miles per hour: a. Business District, unless otherwise specified. b. Cherry Street from Dooly Street to Spalding Road. (2) Twenty-five miles per hour: a. East Railroad Street from Spalding Road to Engram Street. b. Dooly Street from 300 feet north of Artesian Street, mile log 10.44, to Artesian Street during school hours of 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. c. Oglethorpe Road from Drumwright Street to Dooly Street. d. State Route 26 from State Route 49, mile log 13.33, to Beaver Creek Bridge, mile log 13.56 (3) Thirty miles per hour: a. Hamilton Road from the point directly in front of the Commodity Refrigerated Storage Building to State Route 26. b. State Route 26 from Drumwright Street, mile log 13.07, to Dooly Street, State Route 49, mile log 13.33. (4) Thirty-five miles per hour: a. State Route 26 from Beaver Creek Bridge, mile log 13.56, to State Route 90, Spaulding Street, mile log 14.56. b. State Route 224 from Engram Street to the east city limits. (5) Forty miles per hour: a. Hamilton Road from the point directly in front of the Commodity Refrigerated Storage Building to State Route 224. b. State Route 26 from a point 500 feet west of Drumwright Street, mile log 12.97, to Drumwright Street, mile log 13.07. c. State Route 26 from State Route 90, mile log 14.56, to the Seaboard Coastline Railroad Bridge, mile log 15.20. (6) Forty-five miles per hour: State Route 26 from the Seaboard Coastline Railroad Bridge, mile log 15.20, to the east city limits, mile log 15.34 (7) Fifty miles per hour: State Route 26 from the west city limits, mile log 12.53, to a point 500 feet west of Drumwright Street, mile log 12.97. (Code 1990, § 13-95; Ord. No. 124, art. V, § 1, 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 148, § 1, 11-8-1977; Ord. No. 161, § 1, 9-8-1981) State Law reference— Authority to regulate speed limits, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-371(a)(10), 40-6-183. Sec. 90-122. - Fire lanes on private property. The following are fire lanes: Flint River Plaza, Hawkinsville Road, State Route 26, a width of 20 feet extending from the edge of the sidewalk adjacent to the buildings in the shopping center into the driveway and extending the entire length of the sidewalk along the buildings. (Code 1990, § 13-96; Ord. No. 124, art. IX, § 6, 11-13-1973; Ord. No. 204, 4-12-1988)

div.head: Chapter 94 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; municipal utilities, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 94-1. - Water, sewer, garbage services required. (a) Applicability to residences. It is hereby deemed necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare of the city that all residences must be served with sanitary drinkable water, sanitary sewer service and garbage collection. Each residence in multiple residences must be serviced individually. (b) Applicability to businesses. It is hereby deemed necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare of the city that all businesses with restroom facilities must be served by sanitary drinkable water and sanitary sewage connection. In addition, all businesses must receive garbage collection. (c) Alternate sewerage services. All residences and all businesses with restroom facilities must be connected to the city sewer system and pay the rates as provided by the city council; however, any residence or business which cannot be served by gravity flow into the city system or for any other reason is unable to be served by the city sewer system is relieved of this obligation but still must have other sanitary sewerage service in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. It shall be unlawful for any person to inhabit or operate a residence or business with restroom facilities not connected to the city sewer system or an approved private sanitary sewer system. (Code 1990, § 21-1; Ord. No. 170, §§ 1, 2, 5, 4-12-1983) Sec. 94-2. - Wells. A permit to dig, sink or drill a well in the geographical limits of the city may be issued by the city council in its discretion, provided that the person desiring to dig, sink or drill the well shall agree in advance to pay the city for services of the city as a standby supplier of water to the person the monthly sum established by resolution of the city council during the time such well is being used for any purpose. The payment of the monthly fee shall obligate the city to supply water as desired, at the rates then in effect for other users, with the monthly charge not to be credited to the water bill of such person. (Code 1990, § 21-2; Ord. No. 50, §§ 1—3, 3-15-1960) Sec. 94-3. - No self-inspection of water and sewer projects. Pursuant to the authority contained in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d), self-inspection of water and sewer projects by master plumbers or utility contractors shall not be applicable within the city. (Code 1990, § 21-3; Ord. No. 287, 7-9-1996) Secs. 94-4—94-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BILLING AND COLLECTION PROCEDURES
Sec. 94-26. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Utility service means the city's water supply service, sewage collection and disposal service and solid waste collection and disposal (sanitation) service or any combination of such services. (Code 1990, § 21-26; Ord. No. 170, § 8, 4-12-1983) Sec. 94-27. - Due date for payment; cut-off date. All utility bills are due by the tenth of the month following the month services are billed and are past due after that date. Delinquent accounts not paid by the 14th day of the month will be subject to disconnection. (Code 1990, § 21-28; Ord. No. 268, 12-13-1994) Sec. 94-28. - Notice of impending termination of service. Notice of impending termination of service shall be printed on each monthly bill. No additional notice shall be given. (Code 1990, § 21-29; Ord. No. 268, 12-13-1994) Sec. 94-29. - Payment of old bills, deposit prerequisite to new service. Any person who applies for utility service from the city and is found to owe an old utility bill from a prior service, will not have utilities connected until after the old bill is paid in full and new deposits are paid. (Code 1990, § 21-30; Ord. No. 170, § 8.1, 4-12-1983; Ord. No. 182, 11-13-1984) Secs. 94-30—94-46. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WATER DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 94-47. - Supplying unsanitary, undrinkable water prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to supply to himself or any other person unsanitary or undrinkable water. (Code 1990, § 21-46; Ord. No. 170, § 6, 4-12-1983) Sec. 94-48. - Receipt of unsanitary, undrinkable water prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any residence or business to receive unsanitary or undrinkable water, and any residence or business receiving unsanitary or undrinkable water shall immediately be required to subscribe to the city water service. Unsanitary or undrinkable water shall be determined in accordance with state law or regulations. (Code 1990, § 21-47; Ord. No. 170, § 4, 4-12-1983) Sec. 94-49. - Subscription to city water service required; exceptions. Every residence or business unless exempted herein or otherwise receiving sanitary drinkable water, must subscribe to the city water service and pay such rates as determined by the city council for the use of city water. The city will provide water meters for each residence or business served but if there is no meter to that residence or business, the recipient shall be charged minimum rates as provided by the city council. (Code 1990, § 21-48; Ord. No. 170, § 3, 4-12-1983) Sec. 94-50. - Reselling, furnishing water to nonsubscribers prohibited. It is unlawful for any person who is a subscriber to the water service of the city to resell or otherwise knowingly furnish city water to the occupant or owner of another residence or business who is not a subscriber to city water services or whose utility has been disconnected for nonpayment of utility services. Nothing contained in this section shall prevent a landlord from paying for the utility services and charging the tenant for the utility services as part of the rent. Each day of violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1990, § 21-49; Ord. No. 170, § 7, 4-12-1983) Sec. 94-51. - Rates established by resolution. The water rates charged by the city shall be established from time to time by action of the city council by resolution. (Code 1990, § 21-50; Ord. No. 168, § 1, 3-8-1983) Secs. 94-52—94-75. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - WELLHEAD PROTECTION
Sec. 94-76. - Purpose. The purpose of this division is to ensure the provisions of a safe and sanitary drinking water supply for the city by establishment of wellhead protection zones surrounding the wellheads for all wells or springs which are the supply sources for the city water system and by the designation and regulation of property uses and conditions which may be maintained within such zones. (Code 1990, § 21-56; Ord. No. 352, § 1, 10-11-2005) Sec. 94-77. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Hazardous waste or material means any waste or material which because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may: (1) Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or (2) Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or to the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of or otherwise managed. Sanitary landfill means a disposal site where solid wastes, including putrescible wastes, or hazardous wastes, are disposed of on land by placing earth cover thereon. Wellhead means the upper terminal of a well, including adapters, ports, seals, valves and other attachments. (Code 1990, § 21-57; Ord. No. 352, § 2, 10-11-2005) Sec. 94-78. - Establishment of wellhead protection zone. There is hereby established a use district known as a wellhead protection zone (WPZ), identified and described as all the area within a circle, the center of which is the center of any city water supply wellhead and the radius of which is 100 feet. (Code 1990, § 21-58; Ord. No. 352, § 3, 10-11-2005) Sec. 94-79. - Permitted uses. The following uses shall be permitted within wellhead protection zones: (1) Any use permitted within existing agricultural or single-family residential districts, except that the minimum residential lot size for a lot portion of which lies within the wellhead protection zone shall not be less than one acre; and (2) Any open land use where any building located on the property is incidental and accessory to the primary open land use. (Code 1990, § 21-59; Ord. No. 352, § 4, 10-11-2005) Sec. 94-80. - Prohibited uses. The following uses or conditions shall be and are hereby prohibited within wellhead protection zones, whether or not such use or condition may otherwise be ordinarily included as a part of a use permitted hereunder: (1) Surface use or storage of hazardous materials, expressly including commercial use of agricultural pesticides; (2) Septic tanks or drainfields appurtenant thereto; (3) Impervious surfaces other than roofs of buildings and street and driveways and walks serving buildings permitted hereunder; (4) Sanitary landfills; (5) Hazardous waste disposal sites; (6) Stormwater infiltration basins; (7) Underground storage tanks; (8) Sanitary sewer lines within 150 feet of a wellhead. (Code 1990, § 21-60; Ord. No. 352, § 5, 10-11-2005) Sec. 94-81. - Administration. The policies and procedures for administration of any wellhead protection zone established under this division, including without limitation those applicable to nonconforming uses, exceptions, enforcement and penalties, shall be the same as provided in the zoning chapter for the city, as the same is presently enacted or may from time to time be amended. (Code 1990, § 21-61; Ord. No. 352, § 1, 10-11-2005) Secs. 94-82—94-105. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - WATER USE RESTRICTIONS
Sec. 94-106. - Authority and purpose. The city, under its powers pursuant to state law, has adopted this article to protect the public health and welfare. This article implements the city's authority to impose water use restrictions, conditioned upon a restricted water use period declared by the city pursuant to the terms of this division or a declared drought response level implementation declared by the state pursuant to Ga. Adm. Code § 391-3-30-.01 et seq. Sec. 94-107. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Address means the house number (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. Declared Drought Response Level (DDRL) means one of four levels of drought that may be declared by the state department of natural resources based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and four being the most severe, as provided in Ga. Adm. Code § 391-3-30-.01 et seq. (Outdoor Water Use). Even-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. Odd-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. Outdoor watering means any watering of decorative lawns, trees or shrubbery by water users. Water users means all persons or municipalities using water from any public water source irrespective of that person's responsibility for billing purposes for use of the water. Sec. 94-108. - Declaration of period of restricted water use. The chief administrative officer shall declare a period of restricted water use in either of two circumstances: (1) State DDRL announcement. In the event of imposition by the state department of natural resources of a DDRL encompassing the geographical area of the city or any part thereof, the chief administrative officer shall declare a water emergency and the level thereof. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this article shall apply to all water use within the city until the restrictions are lifted by the mayor or the city council; provided, however, that the restrictions shall remain in full force and effect until any state outdoor watering ban has been lifted. (2) Local declaration. In the event of prolonged drought, failure of equipment, or any other factor that substantially affects or may affect the supply of water to the city and the city's water users, the chief administrative officer may declare an emergency and the level thereof. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this article shall apply to all water use within the city until the restrictions are lifted. The declaration should be, where appropriate, conditioned on the identification of an emergency or water shortage by the city personnel, county personnel, state agency, federal agency, or the state governor. Sec. 94-109. - Notice of declaration. Upon declaration of a period of restricted water use, the chief administrative officer shall notify all users through news releases to the media, through notices mailed to all users, or through such other means as the chief administrative officer shall deem expedient and appropriate. Notice shall be given as soon as practical after the declaration of a period of restricted water use is made. Sec. 94-110. - Watering methods restricted. During a period of restricted water use of any level, outdoor watering is restricted to watering by bucket, can or handheld hose with automatic shutoff nozzle. The use of automatic sprinkler systems is prohibited, except for watering of newly installed landscaping as permitted herein and except for testing of a newly installed or newly repaired sprinkler system by a commercial enterprise engaged in the installation or repair of lawn irrigation systems. Sec. 94-111. - Level one restrictions. In the event of declaration of a level one period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the city: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight. (2) Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (3) Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (4) Use of hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing is prohibited. Sec. 94-112. - Level two restrictions; prohibitions. In the event of declaration of a level two period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the city: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. (2) Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (3) Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (4) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. b. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks and driveways except when necessary for public health and safety. Sec. 94-113. - Level three restrictions; prohibitions. In the event of declaration of a level three period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the city: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on the scheduled day within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. (2) The scheduled day for odd-numbered addresses is Sunday. (3) The scheduled day for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways is Saturday. (4) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. b. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety c. Filling installed swimming pools except when necessary for health care or structural integrity. d. Washing vehicles, such as cars, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, golf carts. e. Washing buildings or structures except for immediate fire protection. f. Noncommercial fundraisers, such as carwashes. g. Using water for ornamental purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls except when necessary to support aquatic life. Sec. 94-114. - Level four restrictions. In the event of declaration of a level four period of restricted water use, no outdoor water use is permitted, unless the use is exempted under the provisions of this article or specifically by the chief administrative officer. Sec. 94-115. - Exemptions. The following uses are exempt from the use restrictions of this article unless the chief administrative officer, at the time of declaration of a period of restricted water use, shall specifically designate one or more of the exemptions inapplicable, and provided that in exercising an exemption water use, conservation practices should be implemented wherever possible: (1) Capture and re-use of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable provisions of this Code and any technical code adopted by the city; (2) Re-use of gray water in compliance with applicable provisions of this Code and any technical codes adopted by the city; (3) Use of reclaimed wastewater for landscaping purposes by a designated user from a system permitted by the EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater; (4) Irrigation of personal food gardens; (5) Except during level four restrictions, irrigation of landscapes that have been installed for less than 30 days and by persons who are not certified or licensed professionals, any day of the week, but only during allowed hours for the restriction level in effect, and then only for a period of 30 days following installation; (6) For golf courses, use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater, irrigation of fairways during times of nondrought and level one restrictions, irrigation of tees during times of nondrought and level one, two or three restrictions, and irrigation of greens; (7) Professionally certified or licensed landscapers, golf course contractors, and sports turf landscapers, but during installation and 30 days following installation only; (8) Irrigation contractors, but during installation and as needed for proper maintenance and adjustments only; (9) Sod producers, ornamental growers, fruit and vegetable growers, retail garden center, hydro-seeding, power washing, construction sites, producers of food and fiber, carwashes; (10) Watering in of pesticides and herbicides on turf; (11) Use of water for firefighting, health, sanitation, and medical purposes; and (12) Other activities essential to daily business. Sec. 94-116. - Application for waiver. Any water user that considers the restrictions imposed during a period of restricted water use to adversely affect their livelihood, health or sanitation, may make written application for a waiver. Any such application should be directed to the attention of the chief administrative officer who shall make a determination regarding the waiver within five business days of receipt of the application. The determination of the chief administrative officer shall be final. Sec. 94-117. - Issuance of written warnings to violators. Persons violating water use restrictions as provided herein shall be given one warning in writing prior to the issuance of a citation, unless: (1) The period of restricted water use is declared in response to a DDRL imposed by the state and applicable in the geographical limits of the city; or (2) The declaration of a period of restricted water use specifically provides that no warnings will be given. Sec. 94-118. - Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be liable to the municipality in the amount of up to $100.00 for the first violation and up to $1,000.00 for the second violation. Third and subsequent violations shall be subject to a fine of up to $1,000.00 and imprisonment for a period of up to 90 days. In addition, third and subsequent violations may, at the discretion of the city, result in immediate shut-off of water service for such period as is deemed expedient and necessary under the circumstances, with approval of the city council. Secs. 94-119—94-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 94-150. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: BOD (biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in parts per million (one part per million equals one milligram per liter). Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. Composite means the makeup of a number of individual samples, so taken as to represent the nature of sewage or industrial wastes. Constituents means the combination of particles or conditions which exists in industrial wastes. Effluent means the discharge flow of a treatment facility. Equalizing units means those devices or structures constructed to evenly regulate either or both the strength and volumes of waste. Flammable means the same as defined by the state fire marshal. Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and disposing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. Industrial user means the same as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency. Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial processes and is distinct from domestic sewage. Influent means the wastewaters arriving at the sewage treatment plant for treatment and/or those structures associated with its initial treatment. Metered water means the amount of water consumed by the sewer customer in the city as measured by a city water meter or other approved metering device. Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. Normal and domestic mean those values taken as standards in the measurement of sewage strength as defined in this chapter. pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. Pretreatment means that physical or chemical treatment given to waste or those processes utilized for this purpose. Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. Receiving waters means those waters into which wastes are discharged. Residential user and domestic user mean a premises or person who discharges wastewaters to the city sewers which closely match normal sewage as to its volume and strength, and further, for billing purposes, is defined as a dwelling place or place of residence. Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage presently owned or afterward acquired by the city. Sewage, wastes and wastewater mean a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface waters and stormwaters as may be present. Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. Sewer service charge means the charge assessed by the city against the sewer customers that are connected to or have access to the city sewage system. Standard methods means those procedures or methods established by the latest edition of the Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Federation of Sewage and Industrial Wastes Associations, a copy of which is on file in the office of the superintendent. Storm sewer and storm drain mean a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes. Superintendent means the superintendent or manager of the sewerage works of the city or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. Surcharge rate means the additional service charge assessed against industries in the city whose waste characteristics exceed those of normal sewage. Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and that are removable by laboratory filtering. Toxic means having constituents of wastes which adversely affect living organisms, including the organisms involved in sewage treatment. Wastewater treatment facilities, sewerage works and treatment works mean all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. Water meter means those devices, approved by the superintendent of the water system for the purpose of establishing the quantity of water consumed by a premises or a person. Watercourse means a channel in which flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. (Code 1990, § 21-66; Ord. No. 158, §§ 1-10—1-20, 1-34, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-151. - Compliance with state and federal regulations. The provisions of this article shall not be deemed as alleviating compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. Specific user charge requirements shall be considered as a part of this article upon official adoption. All nonresidential users will be required to comply with pretreatment standards as outlined in Part 403 of the Code of Federal Regulations, General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution, 40 CFR 403.1 et seq. (Code 1990, § 21-68; Ord. No. 158, art. 12, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-152. - Right of officials to enter properties. The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1990, § 21-69; Ord. No. 158, § 7-01, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-153. - Prohibited deposits. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in an unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. (Code 1990, § 21-70; Ord. No. 158, § 2-01, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-154. - Prohibited discharges. It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. (Code 1990, § 21-71; Ord. No. 158, § 2-02, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-155. - Unauthorized tampering with city equipment. No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the municipal sewerage works. (Code 1990, § 21-72; Ord. No. 158, § 6-01, 7-28-1981) State Law reference— Damaging, injuring or interfering with utilities, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Secs. 94-156—94-178. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PRIVATE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS
Sec. 94-179. - Facilities intended or used for disposal of sewage. (a) Except as provided in this section, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. (b) Where a connection to a public sanitary sewer is not required, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. (c) Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the superintendent. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as deemed necessary by the superintendent. A permit and the inspection fee as set by the city shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. (d) A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the superintendent. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the superintendent when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 48 hours of the receipt of notice by the superintendent. (e) The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the department of natural resources and the state health department. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than 20,000 square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any public sewer or natural outlet. (f) At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. (g) The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city. (h) No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the superintendent. (Code 1990, § 21-73; Ord. No. 158, §§ 2-03, 3-01—3-07, 7-28-1981) Secs. 94-180—94-196. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ACCEPTANCE OF NONCONNECTED WASTEWATER
Sec. 94-197. - Acceptance of wastewater not connected to public sewer; permit. The city may accept wastewater from persons and entities not currently connected to any public sewer in the city; provided, however, that prior to each and every discharge of any wastewater into the city's system, the person or entity must obtain written authorization from the wastewater plants chief for the city. Any person or entity must make application for such permission on the forms to be provided by city hall. (Code 1990, § 21-3; Ord. No. 355, § 1, 4-10-2007) Sec. 94-198. - Authority of wastewater plants chief. (a) The city's wastewater plants chief shall have authority to determine whether wastewater will be accepted, provided that the chief must base the decision to accept or reject the wastewater based on the following criteria: (1) Whether the wastewater to be accepted complies with the requirements of this Code regarding prohibited discharges. (2) Whether the wastewater to be accepted complies with the requirements of this Code regarding pretreatment of certain wastewater; (3) Whether, at the time of acceptance of the wastewater, the wastewater is of such a nature that the acceptance of such would not cause the wastewater treatment plant to be in violation of any permit held by the city. (b) In making such determination based on the criteria listed above, the wastewater plants chief may require sampling and testing of the wastewater to be performed in order to determine whether the wastewater shall be accepted. (Ord. No. 355, § 2, 4-10-2007) Sec. 94-199. - Decision to accept or reject wastewater. The wastewater plants chief shall provide written notice of his decision to accept or reject the wastewater. Should the superintendent determine not to accept the wastewater, the person or entity requesting the acceptance of the wastewater may appeal such decision to the city council by submitting a written request for appeal to the chief administrative officer within ten days of receipt of notice of the superintendent's decision not to accept the wastewater. (Ord. No. 355, § 2, 4-10-2007) Sec. 94-200. - Discharge fees. Any person or entity discharging wastewater under this division shall be charged a fee per gallon discharged in the amount established by resolution of the city council. (Ord. No. 355, § 3, 4-10-2007) Secs. 94-201—94-223. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS
Sec. 94-224. - Permit. (a) Required. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or openings into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent. (b) Classes. There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: (1) Residential and commercial service, and (2) Service to establishments producing industrial wastes. (c) Application and fees. In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. A permit and inspection fee in the amounts established by resolution of the city council shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. (Code 1990, § 21-86; Ord. No. 158, §§ 4-01, 4-02, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-225. - Cost of connection borne by owner; indemnification of city. All cost and expense incident to the connection of the building sewer from the owner's building to the city property line shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the connection of the building sewer. Any connection from the city property line into the public sewer shall be made by the city, for which the owner shall pay the city a standard tap fee. All sewer taps shall include the following: piping from city property line to tap into main sewer; and a cleanout plug at junction of city property line with customer property line. (Code 1990, § 21-87; Ord. No. 158, § 4-03, 7-28-1981; Ord. No. 272, 2-13-1996) Sec. 94-226. - Connections on rights-of-way; sewer backups and obstructions. All costs and expenses incidental to the installation of a cleanout plug at the junction of the sewer connection at the right-of-way shall be borne by the owner if it is determined that the obstruction is not on the city side. If it is determined that the obstruction is on the city side, then the cleanout plug will be installed at city expense. Determination of location of obstruction will be by the superintendent of wastewater operations. (Code 1990, § 21-74; Ord. No. 274, 3-14-1995) Sec. 94-227. - Separate sewer required for each building, exception. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. (Code 1990, § 21-88; Ord. No. 158, § 4-04, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-228. - Old sewers used with new buildings. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this article. (Code 1990, § 21-89; Ord. No. 158, § 4-05, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-229. - Type of excavation; backfilling. All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trenchwork unless otherwise approved by the superintendent. Pipelaying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM Specification C12, except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. (Code 1990, § 21-90; Ord. No. 158, § 4-10, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-230. - Barricading, lighting of excavations; restoration of property. All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. (Code 1990, § 21-91; Ord. No. 158, § 4-13, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-231. - Materials allowed for building sewers. The building sewers shall be cast-iron soil pipe, vitrified clay sewer pipe, concrete sewer pipe, or other approved materials. Cast-iron soil pipe shall have rubber gasket joints in conformance with ASTM Specification C564. Vitrified clay pipe shall have joints conforming to ASTM Specification C-425 Type I or Type III. Concrete pipe shall have O-ring or other compression-type joints, meeting AWWA C-302 specifications. All joints shall be suitable for use with sewage. (Code 1990, § 21-92; Ord. No. 158, § 4-06, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-232. - Size and slope allowed for building sewers. The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-eighth inch per foot. (Code 1990, § 21-93; Ord. No. 158, § 4-07, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-233. - Installation standards. (a) Whenever possible the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The building sewer shall be laid on a uniform grade and in straight alignment. Changes in direction shall be made only with proper fittings. (b) No sewer line parallel with a water line shall be laid closer than ten feet from the water line. (Code 1990, § 21-94; Ord. No. 158, §§ 4-07, 4-08, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-234. - Notification of superintendent to inspect. The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. (Code 1990, § 21-95; Ord. No. 158, § 4-12, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-235. - Connection to public sewer. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the Y branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is 12 inches in diameter or less, and no properly located Y branch is available, the city shall install a Y branch in the public sewer at the location specified by the superintendent. Where the public sewer is greater than 12 inches in diameter, and no properly located Y is available, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, with entry into the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees. An ell of 45 degrees may be used to make such connection, with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the center of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the superintendent. (Code 1990, § 21-96; Ord. No. 158, § 4-11, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-236. - Lifts required for low drains. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. (Code 1990, § 21-97; Ord. No. 158, § 4-09, 7-28-1981) Secs. 94-237—94-265. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS
Sec. 94-266. - Prohibited discharges. Except as provided in this article, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer: (1) Stormwaters and drainage waters; (2) Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (66 degrees Celsius); in no case shall any discharge cause the temperature of the treatment plant influent to exceed 104 degrees Fahrenheit unless the treatment plant can accommodate such temperature; (3) Any waters or wastes which may contain more than 100 parts per million of fat, oil or greases; (4) Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquids, solids or gases; (5) Any garbage that has not been properly shredded; (6) Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tars, plastics, wood, paunch manure, lime slurry, lime residue, textile fibers, ground paper, latex, chemical residue, cannery wastes, paint residue, bulk solids or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works; (7) Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five and five-tenths or higher than nine, except upon approval of the superintendent but not to exceed 12.5, or having any corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works. (8) Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant; (9) Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant; (10) Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance. (Code 1990, § 21-111; Ord. No. 158, § 5-03, 7-28-1981; Ord. No. 368, 11-11-2008) Sec. 94-267. - Unpolluted discharges. (a) Prohibited from sanitary sewers. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. (b) Permitted with restrictions. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designed as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged upon approval of the state department of natural resources to a storm sewer or natural outlet. (Code 1990, § 21-112; Ord. No. 158, §§ 5-01, 5-02, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-268. - Discharges requiring preliminary treatment. (a) Specific discharges prohibited. The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having: (1) A five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 250 parts per million; (2) More than 250 parts per million of suspended solids; (3) Any quantity of substance with the characteristics described in section 94-266; or (4) An average daily flow greater than five percent of the average daily sewage flow of the city shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent. The owner shall either: a. Provide at the expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 250 parts per million and the suspended solids to 250 parts per million, reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in section 94-266; or b. Shall pay surcharges as set forth in section 94-296. Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the superintendent and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until such approval is obtained in writing. (b) Facility to be maintained in working order. Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. (Code 1990, § 21-113; Ord. No. 158, §§ 5-06, 5-07, 7-28-1981; Ord. No. 323, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 368, 11-11-2008) Sec. 94-269. - Grease, oil, sand interceptors. (a) Necessity determined, type required. Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, or sand or other harmful ingredients, except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent and shall be so located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. (b) Construction standards. Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperatures. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. (c) Maintenance at owner's expense. When installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. (Code 1990, § 21-115; Ord. No. 158, §§ 5-04, 5-05, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-270. - Control manhole. When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and the owner at his expense shall maintain the same as to be safe and accessible at all times. (Code 1990, § 21-116; Ord. No. 158, § 5-08, 7-28-1981) Secs. 94-271—94-290. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - RATES AND CHARGES
Sec. 94-291. - Statement of necessity. It is hereby determined necessary to the protection of the public health, safety, welfare and convenience of the city to fix and collect charges upon all premises or facilities served by sewerage connections with the sewerage of the city. (Code 1990, § 21-131; Ord. No. 158, § 9-01, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-292. - Uses of proceeds. The revenue received from the collection of sewer charges together with all other revenue derived from the operation of the sewer system shall be deposited with the municipal revenue collector and shall be used: (1) For the operation and maintenance of the sewer system and incidental expenses connected therewith; (2) To pay debt requirements on revenue bonds issued and extension of the sewer and water purification systems, facilities and appurtenances used in connection with the operation of such systems; (3) To acquire necessary easements or the purchase of land and to provide funds for the necessary reserves for debt and improvements. (Code 1990, § 21-132; Ord. No. 158, § 9-02, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-293. - Sewerage service rates. (a) Assessed to all premises. For the purpose provided in this division, there is hereby charged and assessed to each premises or facility served by connection with the sewer system of the city, or otherwise discharging sewage, industrial wastes, water or other liquids, either directly or indirectly into the sewer system, a sewer service charge at the established rate. (b) Basis for charges. The sewer service charge shall be based upon the quantity of water used by the premises or facility therein or thereon as the same is measured by a water meter there in use, or as otherwise currently established. (c) Use of private water. Water used from private sources shall be metered as required in section 94-294 and will be figured at prevailing city water rates, and the sewer service charges shall be billed accordingly. (Code 1990, § 21-133; Ord. No. 158, § 9-03, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-294. - Independent water supply. If a lot, parcel of land, premises or facility discharging sewage, industrial waste, water or other liquids, either directly or indirectly into the city's sewer system, or which ultimately enters the sewer system, is supplied either wholly or in part with water from wells, or any source other than the city waterworks, then such wells or other source or supply shall be registered with the city waterworks and if the water is not metered, the owner or occupant shall, at his own cost, install and maintain a meter on such supplies in such a location and in such a manner as is satisfactory to the city waterworks. These meters shall serve as a control for the establishment of the sewer service charge and shall be read monthly or bimonthly by employees of the city waterworks. (Code 1990, § 21-134; Ord. No. 158, § 9-04, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-295. - Additional meter for water not discharged to sewer system. Where it can be shown to the satisfaction of the superintendent that a significant portion of the water measured by the water meter does not enter the sewer system, then the superintendent may require or permit the installation of additional meters or other devices as may be deemed necessary to establish that portion that does enter the sewer system, and the corrected meter flow will be used for billing of the sewer service charge. All such additional facilities will be provided by the owner at the premises concerned or other interested parties at no expense to the city. (Code 1990, § 21-135; Ord. No. 158, § 9-05, 7-28-1981) Sec. 94-296. - Surcharge for heavier concentrations of pollutants. (a) When the five-day biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), total suspended solids (TSS), fats, oil and grease (FOG), or any other pollutant concentrations from a user are greater than the range of concentration of these pollutants in normal domestic sewage, a surcharge may be levied as follows: (1) A base surcharge of $250.00 per month for exceeding the pollutant limitations. (2) When the five-day BOD exceeds 250 parts per million, a surcharge of $0.10 per pound of excess BOD shall apply. (3) When the total suspended solids concentration exceeds 250 parts per million, a surcharge of $0.01 per pound of excess suspended solids shall apply. (4) When the fats, oil and grease concentration exceeds 100 parts per million, a surcharge of $0.10 per pound excess fats, oil and grease shall apply. (b) The monthly surcharge for each pollutant shall be computed as follows: Surcharge = 8.34 × (Q ÷ 1,000,000} × {X - C} × R
The surcharge for each pollutant shall be based on a monthly average of each pollutant or a combined daily poundage calculation for the month. The method of a monthly average or a daily calculation of poundage shall be determined by the frequency and strength of the waste. The total surcharge shall be the base monthly charge ($250.00) plus the surcharges for each pollutant that exceeds the base concentration for that month. (c) Sampling requirements: (1) The flow metering and sample point shall be located between the users last unit process and before entering the collection system. (2) The user shall meter the discharge daily with acceptable metering equipment and report totals to the city by the fifth day of the following month. (3) The city shall have access to flow metering equipment. (4) Annual calibration is required for flow measuring equipment. (5) Sampling frequency shall be determined by the amount, frequency and strength of the discharge. If the user is required to monitor pollutant concentrations under an existing industrial pretreatment permit then the user will supply a copy of the monthly results to the city. These results may be used or more testing may be required. If more testing is required it shall be preformed at the city's expense and the user shall be required to provide the city with a composite sample on a weekly schedule to be determined by the frequency and strength of discharge. Composite samples shall consist of at least five flow proportional samples over an eight-hour period, automated samplers are preferred. Sample analysis shall be performed by an EPA approved laboratory. (6) The user shall provide the city with a discharge schedule. (7) The city shall have access to the users samplers to monitor and collect samples. (Code 1990, § 21-136; Ord. No. 158, § 10-01, 7-28-1981; Ord. No. 367, § 21-136, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 371, 2-10-2009) Sec. 94-297. - Payment. Sewer service charges and surcharges provided for in this division shall be payable at the city hall or at other authorized locations at the same time as the water bill for the lot, parcel of land, building, premises or facility is payable, and payments for water shall not be accepted unless payment of the sewer service charge and/or surcharge is made at the same time. (Code 1990, § 21-137; Ord. No. 158, art. 11, 7-28-1981)

div.head: Chapter 98 - VEGETATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 98-1—98-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WEEDS
Sec. 98-19. - Growth restricted. (a) Any person who owns a vacant, developed or undeveloped property, and owners and occupants of all residential, business, commercial, and industrial premises, shall cut the grass, weeds, and other foreign growth on the property and remove all litter from it in such a manner that the public health, safety, welfare, morality, and good order are served. (b) Grass and weed growth shall not be permitted to exceed six inches in height. (c) A failure to abide by this requirement is a public nuisance which may be abated by the city in the manner provided in section 22-302(f). (Code 1990, § 15-6(c); Ord. No. 353, 7-11-2006) Secs. 98-20—98-41. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TREES[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Local ordinances governing land disturbing activities may provide for tree protection, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-4.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 98-42. - Purpose and intent. (a) The purpose of this article is to establish protective regulations for trees in the city to better control problems with flooding, soil conservation, air pollution and noise in the city and to make the city a healthier and safer place in which to live. (b) The intent of this article is to: (1) Establish a minimum landscape development requirement on publicly and privately developed land use areas with the exclusion, however, of single-family, two-family residential land uses and agricultural land uses; (2) Encourage the protection of existing trees and the planting of new trees which do and will enhance the value and beauty of property and are a valid asset to the community. It is in the public interest and welfare to protect the trees which the city stands to lose unless protective measures are taken. The intent is not punitive or to cause hardship to any individual, private or public company that uses care and diligence to protect trees within the city. (Code 1990, § 20.5-1; Ord. No. 235, § 1, 1-22-1991) Sec. 98-43. - Applicability. The terms and provisions of this article shall apply to real property as follows: (1) All undeveloped property, excluding single-family and two-family residential properties. (2) That portion of each lot that shall correspond with the portion of the lot covered by the front, side and rear yard requirements as established by the zoning chapter of the city. (3) Public rights-of-way, parks and other public lands. (Code 1990, § 20.5-4; Ord. No. 235, § 4, 1-22-1991) Sec. 98-44. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Drip line means a vertical line extending from the outermost portion of a tree canopy to the ground. Tree means any woody plant except dogwoods or other flowering trees that have a single trunk with a caliper of five inches or more at six inches above the ground. A dogwood or other flowering tree with a caliper of two inches or more at six inches above the ground is defined as a tree. Tree permit means written consent given by the city office of inspection to a person, private or public firm or agency to destroy or remove any tree within the city. (Code 1990, § 20.5-2; Ord. No. 235, § 2, 1-22-1991) Secs. 98-45—98-61. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 98-62. - Office of inspection. The office of inspection with the assistance of the city administrator shall direct, regulate and control the care of and necessary removal of all trees growing now or hereafter in the city in accordance with the guidelines set forth herein, and in coordination with the city's tree board. (Code 1990, § 20.5-3; Ord. No. 235, § 3, 1-22-1991) Sec. 98-63. - Enforcement authority. The office of inspection shall be charged with the enforcement of this article. For the purposes of enforcement of this article, the director of inspections or his designee is hereby invested with police power to do all acts necessary to ensure that the provisions of this article are not violated, including but not limited to the issuance of citations for the violation of any provisions of this article. (Code 1990, § 20.5-10; Ord. No. 235, § 10, 1-22-1991) Sec. 98-64. - Appeals. (a) Complaint to mayor and council. In the event any person is dissatisfied with the decision of the office of inspection adversely affecting such person involving the application of this article, such person may make a written request to the mayor and council which shall hear any complaints of such person. After a full and complete hearing of the complaints of such person, the mayor and council shall render its written opinion affirming, overruling or modifying the decision of the office of inspection as may be fit and proper under the circumstances. (b) Hearing on original petition. In addition to the right of appeal on any application, any applicant who desires a hearing on his original petition rather than a decision of the office of inspection shall have the right to have his original petition heard by the mayor and council and a written opinion rendered granting or denying the application for a permit. (Code 1990, § 20.5-12; Ord. No. 235, § 12, 1-22-1991) Secs. 98-65—98-82. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PERMITS
Sec. 98-83. - Required. Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall cut, remove, trim or in any way damage any tree on any property owned by the city, or shall create any condition injurious to any such tree without first obtaining a permit to do so. (Code 1990, § 20.5-3(h); Ord. No. 345, 6-10-2003) Sec. 98-84. - Exceptions. Departments of the city and companies providing utility services, including telecommunications services, to the city or its citizens, are granted emergency powers, with respect to cutting, trimming or removing trees in order to restore the delivery of services following service interruptions caused by inclement weather or other emergency situations with respect to the maintenance of utility rights-of-way. However, these agencies shall be required to follow procedures and tree maintenance techniques established by the tree board. (Code 1990, § 20.5-3(i), (j); Ord. No. 345, 6-10-2003) Sec. 98-85. - Application; public hearing; determination. (a) Applications for tree permits shall be made to the tree board on forms prescribed by it and shall be accompanied by the permit fee established by the city council. (b) The tree board shall take action on the application within ten days of its receipt. The board may delegate to one or more of its members or officers the power to review applications and issue or deny permits as, in the members' discretion, are necessary or appropriate in the circumstances, utilizing standards established by the tree board. (c) The tree board may in its discretion hold public hearings on any application and may approve all or any part of an application before it. (d) The standard to be applied by the tree board in issuing or denying permits is whether the public and private benefit that will result from granting the application outweighs the public and private benefit that will result from denying it. (Code 1990, § 20.5-3(h); Ord. No. 345, 6-10-2003) Sec. 98-86. - Exemptions. (a) Imminent danger. In the event any tree is damaged by wind, storm or other act of God or shall be in a hazardous or dangerous condition so as to endanger the public health, welfare or safety and requires immediate removal without delay, the same may be removed without obtaining a permit as herein required. (b) Emergency conditions. During any period of emergency, such as tornado, hurricane, flood or any other act of nature, the requirements of this article may be waived by the mayor and council or their designee. (c) Commercial purposes. The pruning or trimming of trees for beautification purposes or for purposes of removal of dead or diseased limbs shall be exempt from the terms and provisions of this article only in relation to those trees which are planted and/or growing for sale or intended sale to the general public in the ordinary course of business or for some other public purpose; and persons, firms, organizations, corporations or societies in the business of growing trees for commercial purpose on their own land or on the lands leased to them shall be exempt. (d) Public utilities. The pruning or trimming of trees as part of normal maintenance by public utilities maintaining lines and poles within the city shall be exempt from the provisions of this division. (Code 1990, § 20.5-7; Ord. No. 235, § 9, 1-22-1991) Secs. 98-87—98-112. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - TREE PROTECTION
Sec. 98-113. - Development plans. (a) Site plan. A site plan for the development or improvement of a tract of land located in the city shall be submitted to the city along with the application for subdivision approval, application for building permit or application for a demolition permit. The site plan shall show, in addition to the usual requirements, the following information: (1) The location of all existing trees within the tree protective zone; (2) Trees to be removed and trees to be maintained within the tree protective zone. (b) Purpose of review. The function of the office of inspection in the review of site plans and subdivision plans will be to ensure that trees are retained in lawn or paved areas within the tree protection zone. (Code 1990, § 20.5-8; Ord. No. 235, § 7, 1-22-1991) Sec. 98-114. - Tree protection during development. During any building, renovation or razing operations, the builder shall erect and maintain suitable protective barriers around all trees or groups of trees specified to be maintained so as to prevent damage to said trees. The protective barrier shall be erected no closer than one-half the distance from the dripline to the trunk of any tree or group of trees to be protected. (Code 1990, § 20.5-9; Ord. No. 235, § 8, 1-22-1991) Sec. 98-115. - Disposal of tree debris. With the exception of the city, no person, firm, organization, corporation, or entity shall be permitted to dispose of tree trucks, limbs or any other refuse in the city's designated disposal site. (Code 1990, § 20.5-9.2; Ord. No. 321, 10-7-2000; Ord. No. 340, 9-10-2002)

div.head: Chapter 102 - ZONING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Zoning authority, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV, O.C.G.A. 33-66-1 et seq.; zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 102-1. - Purpose. In pursuance of the authority conferred by the Georgia General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957, as amended, and for the purpose of promoting the health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity or the general welfare of the city; lessening congestion in the streets, securing safety from fire, panic and other dangers, providing adequate light and air; preventing the overcrowding of land; avoiding undue concentration of population; facilitating the adequate provisions of transportation; water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements; promoting desirable living conditions and the sustained stability of neighborhoods; protecting property against blight and depreciation; conserving the value of buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of land and other buildings and structures throughout the municipality, all in accordance with a comprehensive plan, the city council does ordain and enact into law the following articles and sections. (Code 1990, app. C, art. I; Ord. No. 134, art. I, 5-13-1975) Sec. 102-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. (a) Rules of construction. The following rules of construction apply to this chapter: (1) The word "lot" includes the word "lot" or "parcel." (2) The word "building" includes the word "structure." (3) The word "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, or arranged, or designed to be used or occupied." (4) The word "map" or "zoning map" refers to the "zoning districts map" of the city. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Accessory use or building means a use or building customarily incidental and subordinate to the principal use or building and located on the same lot with such principal use or building. Boardinghouse or roominghouse means any dwelling in which three or more persons either individually or as families are housed for hire with or without meals. Buffer strip, planted, means a strip of land along a property line reserved for screening purposes from adjoining properties or public rights-of-way and planted with trees and/or shrubs in such a manner as to provide such screening. Building means any structure attached to the ground and intended for shelter, housing, or enclosure of persons, animals or chattels. Business sign means an attached or freestanding structure on which is announced the business use of the premises and/or the name of the operator of the business. Centerline of street means the centerline of a street in the line surveyed and monumented by the governing body as such or, if a centerline has not been surveyed and monumented, it shall be that line running midway between the outside curbs or ditches of the streets. Dwelling means a building designated or used for permanent living quarters for one or more families. Dwelling unit means a dwelling or portion thereof providing permanent living quarters for one or more persons living as a single housekeeping unit. Family means one or more persons occupying a dwelling unit and living as a single housekeeping unit. Front yard means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot and located between the street line and the front line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. Lot means a parcel of land occupied or capable of being occupied by one or more buildings and the accessory buildings or uses customarily incidental to it, including such open spaces as are required by this chapter. Lot area means the total area, measured on a horizontal plane, included within the lot lines. Lot width means the distance between the side boundaries of the lot measured at the front building line. Major street means a street designated as a major street on the zoning districts map of the city. Mobile home. See Trailer home, mobile home, or house trailer . Nonconforming use means a structure or land lawfully occupied by a use that does not conform to the regulations of the district in which it is situated. Outdoor advertising sign means an attached or freestanding structure conveying some information, knowledge, or idea to the public. Rear yard means a yard extending across the rear of a lot measured between the lot lines and being the minimum horizontal distance between the rear lot line and the rear of the outside wall of the main building. On both corner lots and interior lots the rear yard shall in all cases be at the opposite end of the lot from the front yard. Secondary street means a street or highway designated as a secondary street on the zoning districts map of the city. Side yard means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building located between the side of the building and the side line of the lot and extending from the rear line of the front yard to the front line of the rear yard. Structure means anything constructed or erected on the ground or attached to something located on the ground. Trailer home, mobile home, or house trailer means a portable or mobile dwelling unit designed for longterm occupancy and mounted on wheels or designed to be so mounted and transported. Trailer park means a lot, portion or parcel of land designed for or which is intended to be used commercially for accommodation of two or more residential trailers. (Code 1990, app. C, art. III; Ord. No. 134, art. III, 5-13-1975) Secs. 102-3—102-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS
Sec. 102-46. - Purpose. This article is established to provide districts for the various uses of land within the city and to provide for the interpretation of district boundaries on the zoning map. (Code 1990, app. C, § 40; Ord. No. 134, § 40, 5-13-1975) Sec. 102-47. - Zoning districts. For the purposes of this chapter, the city is divided into eight districts designated as follows:
(Code 1990, app. C, § 41; Ord. No. 134, § 41, 5-13-1975) Sec. 102-48. - Zoning map. The boundaries of the zoning districts are hereby established as shown on the map entitled Zoning Districts Map—Montezuma, Georgia, dated March 1975 and certified by the chief administrative officer. Said map is hereby made part of this chapter; it shall be on file in the office of the chief administrative officer and available for public inspection. (Code 1990, app. C, § 42; Ord. No. 134, § 42, 5-13-1975) Sec. 102-49. - Map amendment. If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes are made in district boundaries portrayed on the zoning map, such changes shall be made on the official zoning map promptly after the amendment has been approved by the city council. (Code 1990, app. C, § 43; Ord. No. 134, § 43, 5-13-1975) Sec. 102-50. - Interpretation of district boundaries.
